[Lord Minchampstead]250-lord minchampstead had many reasons for patronising [Lancelot]172-lancelot . In the first place , [he]250-lord minchampstead had a true eye for [a strong man]1222-a strong man wherever [he]250-lord minchampstead met [him]250-lord minchampstead ; in the next place , [[Lancelot]172-lancelot ’s uncle]1278-lancelot ’s uncle [the banker]1279-the banker , was [a stanch Whig ally of [his]250-lord minchampstead in [the House]3485-the house]1280-a stanch whig ally of his in the house . ‘ In the rotten - borough times , [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith , ’[1279-the banker] [he]1279-the banker once said to [Lancelot]172-lancelot , ‘ [we]3740-we could have made [a senator of [you]172-lancelot]3741-a senator of you at once ; but , for the sake of finality , [we]3740-we were forced to relinquish that organ of influence . [The Tories]3742-the tories had abused it , really , a little too far ; and now [we]3740-we can only make [a commissioner of [you]172-lancelot]3743-a commissioner of you — which , after all , is a more useful post , and a more lucrative one . ’[1279-the banker] But [Lancelot]172-lancelot had not as yet ‘ Galliolised , ’[172-lancelot] as [the Irish schoolmaster]1282-the irish schoolmaster used to call it , and cared very little to play a political ninth fiddle . The first thing which caught [his]172-lancelot eyes as [he]172-lancelot entered [the drawing - room]1283-the drawing - room before dinner was [Argemone]150-argemone listening in absorbed reverence to [her]150-argemone favourite vicar,—a stern , [prim , close - shaven , dyspeptic man]1284-prim , close - shaven , dyspeptic man , with a meek , cold smile , which might have become a cruel one . [He]172-lancelot watched and watched in vain , hoping to catch [her]150-argemone eye ; but no — there [she]150-argemone stood , and talked and listened — ‘ Ah , ’[139-bracebridge] said [Bracebridge]139-bracebridge , smiling , ‘ it is in vain , [Smith]137-mr. smith ! When did [you]137-mr. smith know [a woman]3251-a woman leave [the Church]863-the church for [one of [us]3747-us [poor laymen]3748-poor laymen]3746-one of us poor laymen ? ’[139-bracebridge] ‘ Good heavens ! ’[172-lancelot] said [Lancelot]172-lancelot , impatiently , ‘ why will [they]3748-poor laymen make such fools of [themselves]3748-poor laymen with [clergymen]784-clergymen ? ’[172-lancelot] ‘ [They]3748-poor laymen are quite right . [They]3748-poor laymen always like [the strong men]3750-the strong men — [the fighters]3751-the fighters and [the workers]3752-the workers . In [Voltaire]47-voltaire ’s time [they]3748-poor laymen all ran after [the philosophers]3753-the philosophers . In the middle ages , books tell [us]3747-us , [they]3748-poor laymen worshipped [the knights errant]3754-the knights errant . [They]3748-poor laymen are always on the winning side , [the cunning little beauties]3755-the cunning little beauties . In the war - time , when [the soldiers]3756-the soldiers had to play [the world]475-the world ’s game , [the ladies]701-the ladies all caught the red - coat fever ; now , in these talking and thinking days ( and be hanged to [them]701-the ladies for bores ) , [they]701-the ladies have the black - coat fever for the same reason . [The parsons]3377-the parsons are [the workers now - a - days]3760-the workers now - a - days — or rather , all [the world]475-the world expects [them]3377-the parsons to be so . [They]3377-the parsons have the game in [their]3377-the parsons own hands , if [they]3377-the parsons did but know how to play it . ’[139-bracebridge] [Lancelot]172-lancelot stood still , sulking over many thoughts . [The colonel]504-the colonel lounged across [the room]3190-the room towards [Lord Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois , [a quiet , truly high - bred young man , with a sweet open countenance , and an ample forehead , whose size would have vouched for great talents]1287-a quiet , truly high - bred young man , with a sweet open countenance , and an ample forehead , whose size would have vouched for great talents , had not the promise been contradicted by the weakness of the over - delicate mouth and chin . ‘ Who is that with whom [you]504-the colonel came into [the room]3190-the room , [Bracebridge]139-bracebridge ? ’[241-lord vieuxbois] asked [Lord Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois . ‘ [I]241-lord vieuxbois am sure [I]241-lord vieuxbois know [his]241-lord vieuxbois face . ’[241-lord vieuxbois] ‘ [Lancelot Smith]172-lancelot , [the man who has taken the shooting - box at [Lower Whitford]48-lower whitford]3763-the man who has taken the shooting - box at lower whitford . ’[241-lord vieuxbois] ‘ Oh , [I]241-lord vieuxbois remember [him]241-lord vieuxbois well enough at [Cambridge]49-cambridge ! [He]241-lord vieuxbois was one of a set who tried to look like blackguards , and really succeeded tolerably . [They]3764-they used to eschew gloves , and drink nothing but beer , and smoke disgusting short pipes ; and when [we]3765-we established [the Coverley Club]50-the coverley club in [Trinity]51-trinity , [they]3764-they set up an opposition , and called [themselves]3764-they [the Navvies]260-the navvies . And [they]3764-they used to make piratical expeditions down to [Lynn]52-lynn in eight oars , to attack [bargemen]3766-bargemen , and [fen girls]3767-fen girls , and shoot ducks , and sleep under turf - stacks , and come [home]452-home when [they]3764-they had drank all the public - house taps dry . [I]241-lord vieuxbois remember [the man]738-the man perfectly . ’[241-lord vieuxbois] ‘ Navvy or none , ’[504-the colonel] said [the colonel]504-the colonel , ‘ [he]738-the man has just the longest head and the noblest heart of [any man [I]504-the colonel ever met]3770-any man i ever met . If [he]738-the man does not distinguish [himself]738-the man before [he]738-the man dies , [I]504-the colonel know nothing of human nature . ’[504-the colonel] ‘ Ah yes , [I]241-lord vieuxbois believe [he]738-the man is clever enough!—took a good degree , a better one than [I]241-lord vieuxbois did — but horribly eclectic ; full of mesmerism , and German metaphysics , and all that sort of thing . [I]241-lord vieuxbois heard of [him]738-the man one night last spring , on which [he]738-the man had been seen , if [you]3771-you will believe it , going successively into [a Swedenborgian chapel]3772-a swedenborgian chapel , [the Garrick]261-the garrick ’s Head , and one of [Elliotson]262-elliotson ’s magnetic soirées . What can [you]241-lord vieuxbois expect after that ? ’[241-lord vieuxbois] ‘ A great deal , ’[139-bracebridge] said [Bracebridge]139-bracebridge drily . ‘ With such a head as [he]738-the man carries on [his]738-the man shoulders [the man]738-the man might be [another Mirabeau]3774-another mirabeau , if [he]738-the man held the right cards in the right rubber . And [he]738-the man really ought to suit [you]3771-you , for [he]738-the man raves about the middle ages , and chivalry , and has edited a book full of old ballads . ’[139-bracebridge] ‘ Oh , [all the eclectics]3775-all the eclectics do that sort of thing ; and small thanks to [them]3775-all the eclectics . However , [I]241-lord vieuxbois will speak to [him]738-the man after dinner , and see what there is in [him]738-the man . ’[241-lord vieuxbois] And [Lord Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois turned away , and , alas for [Lancelot]172-lancelot ! sat next to [Argemone]150-argemone at dinner . [Lancelot]172-lancelot , who was cross with [everybody]1289-everybody for what was [nobody]3117-nobody ’s fault , revenged [himself]172-lancelot all dinner - time by never speaking a word to [[his]172-lancelot next neighbour]1291-his next neighbour , [Miss Newbroom]263-miss newbroom , who was longing with all [her]263-miss newbroom heart to talk sentiment to [him]172-lancelot about the Exhibition ; and when [Argemone]150-argemone , in the midst of a brilliant word - skirmish with [Lord Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois , stole a glance at [him]172-lancelot , [he]172-lancelot chose to fancy that [they]1292-they were both talking of [him]172-lancelot , and looked more cross than ever . After [the ladies]701-the ladies retired , [Lancelot]172-lancelot , in [his]172-lancelot sulky way , made up [his]172-lancelot mind that the conversation was going to be ineffably stupid ; and set to to dream , sip claret , and count the minutes till [he]172-lancelot found [himself]172-lancelot in [the drawing - room]1283-the drawing - room with [Argemone]150-argemone . But [he]172-lancelot soon discovered , as [I]0-i suppose [we]1295-we all have , that ‘ it never rains but it pours , ’[172-lancelot] and that [one]3305-one can not fall in with a new fact or a new acquaintance but next day twenty fresh things shall spring up as if by magic , throwing unexpected light on one ’s new phenomenon . [Lancelot]172-lancelot ’s head was full of the condition - of - the - poor question , and lo ! [everybody]1289-everybody seemed destined to talk about it . ‘ Well , [Lord Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois , ’[1298-the host] said [the host]1298-the host , casually , ‘ [[my]1298-the host girls]3776-my girls are raving about [[your]241-lord vieuxbois new school]3777-your new school . [They]3776-my girls say it is a perfect antiquarian gem . ’[1298-the host] ‘ Yes , tolerable , [I]1298-the host believe . But [Wales]264-wales has disappointed [me]1298-the host a little . That vile modernist naturalism is creeping back even into [our]1295-we painted glass . [I]1298-the host could have wished that [the artist]3180-the artist ’s designs for the windows had been a little more Catholic . ’[1298-the host] ‘ How then ? ’[1298-the host] asked [the host]1298-the host , with a puzzled face . ‘ Oh , [he]139-bracebridge means , ’[139-bracebridge] said [Bracebridge]139-bracebridge , ‘ that [the figures]3779-the figures ’[139-bracebridge] wrists and ankles were not sufficiently dislocated , and [the patron saint]1300-the patron saint did not look quite like a starved rabbit with its neck wrung . Some of the faces , [I]0-i am sorry to say , were positively like [good - looking men]1301-good - looking men and [women]3246-women . ’ ‘[1301-good - looking men] Oh , [I]0-i understand , ’ said [Lord Minchampstead]250-lord minchampstead ; ‘[1301-good - looking men] [Bracebridge]139-bracebridge ’s tongue is privileged , [you]0-i know , [Lord Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois , so [you]0-i must not be angry . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t see [my]0-i way into all this , ’ said [Squire Lavington]136-squire lavington ( which was very likely to be true , considering that [he]0-i never looked for [his]0-i way ) . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t see how all these painted windows , and crosses , and chanting , and [the deuce]3697-the deuce and [the Pope]1304-the pope only know what else , are to make [boys]468-boys any better . ’ ‘[1306-we] [We]1306-we have it on the highest authority , ’ said [Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois , ‘[0-i] that pictures and music are the books of the unlearned . [I]0-i do not think that [we]1306-we have any right in the nineteenth century to contest an opinion which [the fathers of the Church]1307-the fathers of the church gave in the fourth . ’ ‘[1307-the fathers of the church] At all events , ’ said [Lancelot]172-lancelot , ‘[1307-the fathers of the church] it is by pictures and music , by art and song , and symbolic representations , that [all nations]1308-all nations have been educated in [their]1308-all nations adolescence ! and as [the youth of [the individual]1310-the individual]1309-the youth of the individual is exactly analogous to [the youth of the collective race]1311-the youth of the collective race , [we]1306-we should employ the same means of instruction with [[our]1306-we children]1312-our children which succeeded in the early ages with [the whole world]1313-the whole world . ’ [Lancelot]172-lancelot might as well have held [his]172-lancelot tongue — [nobody]3117-nobody understood [him]172-lancelot but [Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois , and [he]172-lancelot had been taught to scent German neology in everything , as [some folks]3781-some folks are taught to scent Jesuitry , especially when it involved an inductive law , and not a mere red - tape precedent , and , therefore , could not see that [Lancelot]172-lancelot was arguing for [him]241-lord vieuxbois . ‘[172-lancelot] All very fine , [Smith]172-lancelot , ’ said [the squire]3125-the squire ; ‘[172-lancelot] it ’s a pity [you]172-lancelot wo n’t leave off puzzling [your]172-lancelot head with books , and stick to fox - hunting . All [[you]172-lancelot young gentlemen]1314-you young gentlemen will do is to turn the heads of [the poor]698-the poor with [your]172-lancelot cursed education . ’ The national oath followed , of course . ‘[698-the poor] Pictures and chanting ! Why , when [I]0-i was [a boy]1316-a boy , [a good honest labouring man]1317-a good honest labouring man wanted to see nothing better than a halfpenny ballad , with a wood - cut at the top , and [they]1318-them worked very well then , and wanted for nothing . ’ ‘[1318-them] Oh , [we]1319-we shall give [them]1318-them the halfpenny ballads in time ! ’ said [Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois , smiling . ‘[1318-them] [You]172-lancelot will do a very good deed , then , ’ said [[mine]3783-mine host]3784-mine host . ‘[172-lancelot] But [I]0-i am sorry to say that , as far as [I]0-i can find from [[my]0-i agents]1320-my agents , when [the upper classes]1321-the upper classes write cheap publications , [the lower classes]1322-the lower classes will not read them . ’ ‘[0-i] Too true , ’ said [Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois . ‘[0-i] Is not the cause , ’ asked [Lancelot]172-lancelot , ‘[0-i] just that [the upper classes]1321-the upper classes do write them ? ’ ‘[1321-the upper classes] The writings of [working men]1324-working men , certainly , ’ said [Lord Minchampstead]250-lord minchampstead , ‘[1321-the upper classes] have an enormous sale among [[their]1318-them own class]1325-their own class . ’ ‘[1321-the upper classes] Just because [they]1318-them express the feelings of [that class]1326-that class , of which [I]0-i am beginning to fear that [we]1327-we know very little . Look again , what a noble literature of [people]3181-people ’s songs and hymns [Germany]1-germany has . [Some of [Lord Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois ’s friends]1329-some of lord vieuxbois ’s friends , [I]0-i know , are busy translating many of [them]1318-them . ’ ‘[1329-some of lord vieuxbois ’s friends] As many of [them]1318-them , that is to say , ’ said [Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois , ‘[1318-them] as are compatible with a real Church spirit . ’ ‘[1329-some of lord vieuxbois ’s friends] Be it so ; but who wrote [them]1318-them ? Not [the German aristocracy]1330-the german aristocracy for [the people]1331-the people , but [the German people]1332-the german people for [themselves]1332-the german people . There is the secret of [their]1332-the german people power . Why not educate [the people]1331-the people up to such a standard that [they]1331-the people should be able to write [their]1331-the people own literature ? ’ ‘[1334-you] What , ’ said [Mr. Chalklands]265-mr. chalklands , of [Chalklands]53-chalklands , who sat opposite , ‘[1334-you] would [you]1334-you have [working men]1324-working men turn [ballad writers]1336-ballad writers ? There would be an end of work , then , [I]0-i think . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i have not heard , ’ said [Lancelot]172-lancelot , ‘[0-i] that [the young women]1337-the young women — [ladies]3255-ladies , [I]0-i ought to say , if the word mean anything — who wrote the “ Lowell Offering , ” spun less or worse cotton than [[their]1337-the young women neighbours]1339-their neighbours . ’ ‘[1337-the young women] On the contrary , ” said [Lord Minchampstead]250-lord minchampstead , ‘ [we]3785-we have the most noble accounts of heroic industry and self - sacrifice in girls whose education , to judge by its fruits , might shame that of [most English young ladies]3786-most english young ladies . ’[250-lord minchampstead] [Mr. Chalklands]265-mr. chalklands expressed certain confused notions that , in [America]54-america , [factory girls]1340-factory girls carried green silk parasols , put the legs of pianos into trousers , and were too prudish to make a shirt , or to call it a shirt after it was made , [he]265-mr. chalklands did not quite remember which . ‘ It is a great pity , ’[250-lord minchampstead] said [Lord Minchampstead]250-lord minchampstead , ‘ that [[our]3785-we factory girls]3787-our factory girls are not in the same state of civilisation . But it is socially impossible . [America]54-america is in an abnormal state . In [a young country]3788-a young country the laws of political economy do not make themselves fully felt . [Here]775-here , where [we]3785-we have no uncleared world to drain the labour - market , [we]3785-we may pity and alleviate the condition of [the working - classes]3790-the working - classes , but [we]3785-we can do nothing more . All the modern schemes for the amelioration which ignore the laws of competition , must end either in pauperisation’—(with a glance at [Lord Vieuxbois),—‘or]266-lord vieuxbois),—‘or in the destruction of property . ’[250-lord minchampstead] [Lancelot]172-lancelot said nothing , but thought the more . It did strike [him]265-mr. chalklands at the moment that [the few]1341-the few might , possibly , be made for [the many]1342-the many , and not the many for [the few]1341-the few ; and that property was made for [man]564-man , not [man for property]1345-man for property . But [he]265-mr. chalklands contented [himself]265-mr. chalklands with asking , — ‘ [You]250-lord minchampstead think , then , [[my]265-mr. chalklands lord]3694-my lord , that in the present state of society , no dead - lift can be given to the condition — in plain English , the wages — of [working men]1324-working men , without the destruction of property ? ’[265-mr. chalklands] [Lord Minchampstead]250-lord minchampstead smiled , and parried the question . ‘ There may be other dead - lift ameliorations , [[my]250-lord minchampstead young friend]3713-my young friend , besides a dead - lift of wages . ’[250-lord minchampstead] So [Lancelot]172-lancelot thought , also ; but [Lord Minchampstead]250-lord minchampstead would have been a little startled could [he]250-lord minchampstead have seen [Lancelot]172-lancelot ’s notion of a dead - lift . [Lord Minchampstead]250-lord minchampstead was thinking of cheap bread and sugar . Do [you]1346-you think that [I]0-i will tell [you]1346-you of what [Lancelot]172-lancelot was thinking ? But here [Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois spurred in to break a last lance . [He]241-lord vieuxbois had been very much disgusted with the turn the conversation was taking , for [he]241-lord vieuxbois considered nothing more heterodox than the notion that [the poor]698-the poor were to educate [themselves]698-the poor . In [his]241-lord vieuxbois scheme , of course [the clergy]1348-the clergy and [the gentry]1349-the gentry were to educate [the poor]698-the poor , who were to take down thankfully as much as it was thought proper to give [them]698-the poor : and all beyond was ‘ self - will ’[241-lord vieuxbois] and ‘ private judgment , ’[241-lord vieuxbois] [the fathers of Dissent and Chartism]1351-the fathers of dissent and chartism , [Trades’-union strikes]1352-trades’-union strikes , and [French Revolutions]267-french revolutions , et si qua alia . ‘ And pray , [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith , may [I]1349-the gentry ask what limit [you]137-mr. smith would put to education ? ’[1349-the gentry] ‘ The capacities of [each man]944-each man , ’[172-lancelot] said [Lancelot]172-lancelot . ‘ If [man living in civilised society]3795-man living in civilised society has one right which [he]3795-man living in civilised society can demand it is this , that the State which exists by [his]3795-man living in civilised society labour shall enable [him]3795-man living in civilised society to develop , or , at least , not hinder [his]3795-man living in civilised society developing , [his]3795-man living in civilised society whole faculties to their very utmost , however lofty that may be . While [a man who might be an author]3796-a man who might be an author remains [a spade - drudge]3797-a spade - drudge , or [a journeyman]3798-a journeyman while [he]3796-a man who might be an author has capacities for [a master]3799-a master ; while [any man able to rise in life]3800-any man able to rise in life remains by social circumstances lower than [he]3796-a man who might be an author is willing to place [himself]3796-a man who might be an author , [that man]3801-that man has a right to complain of the State ’s injustice and neglect . ’[172-lancelot] ‘ Really , [I]241-lord vieuxbois do not see , ’[241-lord vieuxbois] said [Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois , ‘ why [people]3181-people should wish to rise in life . [They]3181-people had no such self - willed fancy in the good old times . The whole notion is a product of these modern days — ’[241-lord vieuxbois] [He]241-lord vieuxbois would have said more , but [he]241-lord vieuxbois luckily remembered at whose table [he]241-lord vieuxbois was sitting . ‘ [I]172-lancelot think , honestly , ’[172-lancelot] said [Lancelot]172-lancelot , whose blood was up , ‘ that [we]3803-we [gentlemen]780-gentlemen all run into the same fallacy . [We]3803-we fancy [ourselves]3803-we the fixed and necessary element in society , to which [all others]3805-all others are to accommodate [themselves]3805-all others . “ Given the rights of [the few rich]3806-the few rich , to find the condition of [the many poor]3807-the many poor . ” It seems to [me]172-lancelot that other postulate is quite as fair : “ Given the rights of [the many poor]3807-the many poor , to find the condition of [the few rich]3806-the few rich . ” ’[172-lancelot] [Lord Minchampstead]250-lord minchampstead laughed . ‘ If [you]172-lancelot hit [us]3803-we so hard , [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith , [I]250-lord minchampstead must really denounce [you]172-lancelot as [a Communist]3810-a communist . [Lord Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois , shall [we]3803-we join [the ladies]701-the ladies ? ’[250-lord minchampstead] In [the drawing - room]1283-the drawing - room , [poor [Lancelot]172-lancelot]1354-poor lancelot , after rejecting overtures of fraternity from [several young ladies]1355-several young ladies , set [himself]172-lancelot steadily again against the wall to sulk and watch [Argemone]150-argemone . But this time [she]150-argemone spied in a few minutes [his]172-lancelot melancholy , moonstruck face , swam up to [him]172-lancelot , and said something kind and commonplace . [She]150-argemone spoke in the simplicity of [her]150-argemone heart , but [he]172-lancelot chose to think [she]150-argemone was patronising [him]172-lancelot — [she]150-argemone had not talked commonplaces to [the vicar]3366-the vicar . [He]172-lancelot tried to say something smart and cutting,—stuttered , broke down , blushed , and shrank back again to the wall , fancying that every eye in [the room]3190-the room was on [him]172-lancelot ; and for one moment a flash of sheer hatred to [Argemone]150-argemone swept through [him]172-lancelot . Was [Argemone]150-argemone patronising [him]172-lancelot ? Of course [she]150-argemone was . True , [she]150-argemone was but three - and - twenty , and [he]172-lancelot was of the same age ; but , spiritually and socially , [the girl]1358-the girl develops ten years earlier than [the boy]1359-the boy . [She]150-argemone was flattered and worshipped by [gray - headed men]1360-gray - headed men , and in [her]150-argemone simplicity [she]150-argemone thought it a noble self - sacrifice to stoop to notice [the poor awkward youth]1361-the poor awkward youth . And yet if [he]172-lancelot could have seen the pure moonlight of sisterly pity which filled all [her]150-argemone heart as [she]150-argemone retreated , with something of a blush and something of a sigh , and [her]150-argemone heart fluttered and fell , would [he]172-lancelot have been content ? Not [he]172-lancelot . It was [her]150-argemone love [he]172-lancelot wanted , and not [her]150-argemone pity ; it was to conquer [her]150-argemone and possess [her]150-argemone , and inform [himself]172-lancelot with [her]150-argemone image , and [her]150-argemone with [his]172-lancelot own ; though as yet [he]172-lancelot did not know it ; though the moment that [she]150-argemone turned away [he]172-lancelot cursed [himself]172-lancelot for selfish vanity , and moroseness and conceit . ‘ Who am [I]172-lancelot to demand [her]150-argemone all to [myself]172-lancelot ? [Her]150-argemone , [the glorious]3812-the glorious , the saintly , the unfallen ! Is not a look , a word , infinitely more than [I]172-lancelot deserve ? And yet [I]172-lancelot pretend to admire tales of chivalry ! [Old knightly hearts]3813-old knightly hearts would have fought and wandered for years to earn a tithe of the favours which have been bestowed on [me]172-lancelot unasked . ’[172-lancelot] — Peace ! poor [Lancelot]172-lancelot ! [Thy]1362-thy egg is by no means addle ; but the chick is breaking the shell in somewhat a cross - grained fashion . Now it was not extraordinary that [Squire Lavington]136-squire lavington had ‘ assimilated ’[268-carbonel] a couple of bottles of [Carbonel]268-carbonel ’s best port ; for however abstemious [the new lord]1273-the new lord [himself]136-squire lavington might be , [he]136-squire lavington felt for the habits , and for the vote of [an old - fashioned Whig squire]1364-an old - fashioned whig squire . Nor was it extraordinary that [he]136-squire lavington fell fast asleep the moment [he]136-squire lavington got into [the carriage]1365-the carriage ; nor , again , that [[his]136-squire lavington wife]934-his wife and [daughters]1367-daughters were not solicitous about waking [him]136-squire lavington ; nor , on the other hand , that [[the coachman]1368-the coachman and footman , who were like [all [the squire]3125-the squire ’s servants]1370-all the squire ’s servants , of [the good old sort]1372-the good old sort , [honest , faithful , boozing , extravagant]1373-honest , faithful , boozing , extravagant , happy - go - lucky souls , who had ‘ been about [the place]3814-the place these forty years , ’[1368-the coachman] were somewhat owlish and unsteady on the box]1369-the coachman and footman , who were like all the squire ’s servants , of the good old sort , honest , faithful , boozing , extravagant , happy - go - lucky souls , who had ‘ been about the place these forty years , ’ were somewhat owlish and unsteady on the box . Nor was it extraordinary that there was a heavy storm of lightning , for that happened three times a - week in [the chalk hills]1374-the chalk hills the summer through ; nor , again , that under these circumstances the horses , who were of [the squire]3125-the squire ’s own breeding , and never thoroughly broke ( nothing was done thoroughly at [Whitford]7-whitford ) , went rather wildly [home]452-home , and that [the carriage]1365-the carriage swung alarmingly down [the steep hills]1378-the steep hills , and the boughs brushed the windows rather too often . But it was extraordinary that [Mrs. Lavington]158-mrs. lavington had cast off [her]158-mrs. lavington usual primness , and seemed to - night , for the first time in [her]158-mrs. lavington life , in an exuberant good humour , which [she]158-mrs. lavington evinced by snubbing [her]158-mrs. lavington usual favourite [Honoria]162-honoria , and lavishing caresses on [Argemone]150-argemone , whose vagaries [she]158-mrs. lavington usually regarded with a sort of puzzled terror , like a hen who has hatched a duckling . ‘ [Honoria]162-honoria , take [your]162-honoria feet off [my]150-argemone dress . [Argemone]150-argemone , [[my]150-argemone child]3815-my child , [I]150-argemone hope [you]162-honoria spent a pleasant evening ? ’[150-argemone] [Argemone]150-argemone answered by some tossy commonplace . A pause — and then [Mrs. Lavington]158-mrs. lavington recommenced , — ‘ How very pleasing [that poor young Lord Vieuxbois]3816-that poor young lord vieuxbois is , after all ! ’[158-mrs. lavington] ‘ [I]158-mrs. lavington thought [you]158-mrs. lavington disliked [him]3816-that poor young lord vieuxbois so much . ’[158-mrs. lavington] ‘ [His]3816-that poor young lord vieuxbois opinions , [[my]150-argemone child]3815-my child ; but [we]3818-we must hope for the best . [He]3816-that poor young lord vieuxbois seems moral and well inclined , and really desirous of doing good in [his]3816-that poor young lord vieuxbois way ; and so successful in [the House]3485-the house , too , [I]150-argemone hear . ’[150-argemone] ‘ To [me]150-argemone , ’[150-argemone] said [Argemone]150-argemone , ‘ [he]3816-that poor young lord vieuxbois seems to want life , originality , depth , everything that makes [a great man]450-a great man . [He]3816-that poor young lord vieuxbois knows nothing but what [he]3816-that poor young lord vieuxbois has picked up ready - made from books . After all , [his]3816-that poor young lord vieuxbois opinions are the one redeeming point in [him]3816-that poor young lord vieuxbois . ’[150-argemone] ‘ Ah , [[my]158-mrs. lavington dear]1114-my dear , when it pleases [Heaven]215-heaven to open [your]1114-my dear eyes , [you]1114-my dear will see as [I]158-mrs. lavington do ! ’[158-mrs. lavington] [Poor Mrs. Lavington]158-mrs. lavington ! [Unconscious spokeswoman for the ninety - nine hundredths of the human race]1379-unconscious spokeswoman for the ninety - nine hundredths of the human race ! What are [we]1380-we all doing from morning to night , but setting up [our]1380-we own fancies as the measure of [all heaven]1381-all heaven and earth , and saying , each in [his]1382-his own dialect , [Whig]269-whig , [Radical]1383-radical , or [Tory]270-tory , [Papist or Protestant]1384-papist or protestant , ‘ When it pleases [Heaven]215-heaven to open [your]1114-my dear eyes [you]1114-my dear will see as [I]1382-his do ’[1382-his] ? ‘ It is a great pity , ’[158-mrs. lavington] went on [Mrs. Lavington]158-mrs. lavington , meditatively , ‘ to see [a young man so benighted and thrown away]3822-a young man so benighted and thrown away . With [his]3822-a young man so benighted and thrown away vast fortune , too — such a means of good ! Really [we]1380-we ought to have seen a little more of [him]3822-a young man so benighted and thrown away . [I]158-mrs. lavington think [Mr. O’Blareaway]271-mr. o’blareaway ’s conversation might be a blessing to [him]3822-a young man so benighted and thrown away . [I]158-mrs. lavington think of asking [him]3822-a young man so benighted and thrown away over to stay a week at [Whitford]7-whitford , to meet [that sainted young man]3823-that sainted young man . ’[158-mrs. lavington] Now [Argemone]150-argemone did not think [the Reverend Panurgus O’Blareaway]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway , [incumbent of [Lower Whitford]48-lower whitford]1385-incumbent of lower whitford , at all [a sainted young man]1386-a sainted young man , but , on the contrary , [a very vulgar , slippery Irishman]1387-a very vulgar , slippery irishman ; and [she]150-argemone had , somehow , tired of [[her]150-argemone late favourite]1388-her late favourite , [Lord Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois ; so [she]150-argemone answered tossily enough , — ‘ Really , [mamma]3824-mamma , a week of [Lord Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois will be too much . [We]3825-we shall be bored to death with [the Cambridge Camden Society]3826-the cambridge camden society , and ballads for [the people]1331-the people . ’[150-argemone] ‘ [I]158-mrs. lavington think , [[my]158-mrs. lavington dear]1114-my dear , ’[158-mrs. lavington] said [Mrs. Lavington]158-mrs. lavington ( who had , half unconsciously to [herself]158-mrs. lavington , more reasons than one for bringing [the young lord]1389-the young lord to [Whitford]7-whitford ) , ‘ [I]158-mrs. lavington think , [[my]158-mrs. lavington dear]1114-my dear , that [his]1389-the young lord conversation , with all its faults , will be a very improving change for [[your]1114-my dear father]3830-your father . [I]158-mrs. lavington hope [he]3830-your father ’s asleep . ’[158-mrs. lavington] [The squire]3125-the squire ’s nose answered for itself . ‘ Really , what between [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith , and [Colonel Bracebridge]139-bracebridge , and [[their]3831-their very ineligible friend]3832-their very ineligible friend , [Mr. Mellot]204-mr. mellot , whom [I]158-mrs. lavington should never have allowed to enter [[my]158-mrs. lavington house]3833-my house if [I]158-mrs. lavington had suspected [his]3830-your father religious views , [the place]3814-the place has become [a hotbed of false doctrine and heresy]3835-a hotbed of false doctrine and heresy . [I]158-mrs. lavington have been quite frightened when [I]158-mrs. lavington have heard [their]3831-their conversation at dinner , lest [the footmen]3836-the footmen should turn [infidels]3837-infidels ! ’[158-mrs. lavington] ‘ Perhaps , [mamma]3824-mamma , ’[162-honoria] said [Honoria]162-honoria , slyly , ‘ [Lord Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois might convert [them]3831-their to something quite as bad . How shocking if [old Giles]274-old giles , [the butler]3839-the butler , should turn [Papist]3840-papist ! ’[162-honoria] ‘ [Honoria]162-honoria , [you]162-honoria are very silly . [Lord Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois , at least can be trusted . [He]241-lord vieuxbois has no liking for [low companions]3841-low companions . [He]241-lord vieuxbois is above joking with [grooms]3842-grooms , and taking country walks with [gamekeepers]3843-gamekeepers . ’[158-mrs. lavington] It was lucky that it was dark , for [Honoria]162-honoria and [Argemone]150-argemone both blushed crimson . ‘ [[Your]3824-mamma poor father]3844-your poor father ’s mind has been quite unsettled by all [their]3845-their ribaldry . [They]3845-their have kept [him]241-lord vieuxbois so continually amused , that all [my]162-honoria efforts to bring [him]241-lord vieuxbois to a sense of [his]241-lord vieuxbois awful state have been more unavailing than ever . ’[162-honoria] [Poor Mrs. Lavington]158-mrs. lavington ! [She]158-mrs. lavington had married , at eighteen , [a man far [her]158-mrs. lavington inferior in intellect]1391-a man far her inferior in intellect ; and had become — as often happens in such cases — [a prude]1392-a prude and [a devotee]1393-a devotee . [The squire]3125-the squire , who really admired and respected [her]158-mrs. lavington , confined [his]3125-the squire disgust to sly curses at [the Methodists]1395-the methodists ( under which name [he]3125-the squire used to include [every species of religious earnestness]1396-every species of religious earnestness , from Quakerism to that of [Mr. Newman]196-newman ) . [Mrs. Lavington]158-mrs. lavington used at first to dignify these disagreeables by the name of persecution , and now [she]158-mrs. lavington was trying to convert [the old man]3135-the old man by coldness , severity , and long curtain - lectures , utterly unintelligible to [[their]1398-their victim]1399-their victim , because couched in the peculiar conventional phraseology of [a certain school]1400-a certain school . [She]158-mrs. lavington forgot , [poor earnest soul]1401-poor earnest soul , that the same form of religion which had captivated [a disappointed girl of twenty]1402-a disappointed girl of twenty , might not be the most attractive one for [a jovial old man of sixty]1403-a jovial old man of sixty . [Argemone]150-argemone , who a fortnight before would have chimed in with all [[her]150-argemone mother]1404-her mother ’s lamentations , now felt a little nettled and jealous . [She]150-argemone could not bear to hear [Lancelot]172-lancelot classed with [the colonel]504-the colonel . ‘ Indeed , ’[150-argemone] [she]150-argemone said , ‘ if amusement is bad for [[my]150-argemone father]3846-my father , [he]3846-my father is not likely to get much of it during [Lord Vieuxbois]241-lord vieuxbois ’s stay . But , of course , [mamma]3824-mamma , [you]3824-mamma will do as [you]3824-mamma please . ’[150-argemone] ‘ Of course [I]3239-the good lady shall , [[my]3239-the good lady dear]1114-my dear , ’[3239-the good lady] answered [the good lady]3239-the good lady , in a tragedy - queen tone . ‘ [I]3239-the good lady shall only take the liberty of adding , that it is very painful to [me]3239-the good lady to find [you]3824-mamma adding to the anxiety which [your]3824-mamma unfortunate opinions give [me]3239-the good lady , by throwing every possible obstacle in the way of [my]3239-the good lady plans for [your]3824-mamma good . ’[3239-the good lady] [Argemone]150-argemone burst into proud tears ( [she]150-argemone often did so after a conversation with [[her]150-argemone mother]1404-her mother ) . ‘ Plans for [my]150-argemone good!’—And an unworthy suspicion about [[her]150-argemone mother]1404-her mother crossed [her]150-argemone mind , and was peremptorily expelled again . What turn the conversation would have taken next , [I]150-argemone know not , but at that moment [Honoria]162-honoria and [[her]162-honoria mother]1404-her mother uttered a fearful shriek , as [their]3851-their side of [the carriage]1365-the carriage jolted half - way up [the bank]3419-the bank , and stuck still in that pleasant position . [The squire]3125-the squire awoke , and [the ladies]701-the ladies simultaneously clapped [their]701-the ladies hands to [their]701-the ladies ears , knowing what was coming . [He]1409-he thrust [his]1409-he head out of the window , and discharged a broadside of at least ten pounds ’[150-argemone] worth of oaths ( [Bow Street]275-bow street valuation ) at [the servants , who were examining the broken wheel]1408-the servants , who were examining the broken wheel , with a side volley or two at [Mrs. Lavington]158-mrs. lavington for being frightened . [He]1409-he often treated [her]158-mrs. lavington and [Honoria]162-honoria to that style of oratory . At [Argemone]150-argemone [he]1409-he had never sworn but once since [she]158-mrs. lavington left [the nursery]1410-the nursery , and was so frightened at the consequences , that [he]1409-he took care never to do it again . But there [they]1411-us were fast , with a broken wheel , plunging horses , and [a drunken coachman]1412-a drunken coachman . Luckily for [them]1411-us , [the colonel]504-the colonel and [Lancelot]172-lancelot were following close behind , and came to [their]1411-us assistance . [The colonel]504-the colonel , as usual , solved the problem . ‘ [Your]3125-the squire dog - cart will carry four , [Smith]172-lancelot ? ’[504-the colonel] ‘ [It]3856-it will . ’[504-the colonel] ‘ Then let [the ladies]701-the ladies get in , and [Mr. Lavington]276-mr. lavington drive [them]701-the ladies [home]452-home . ’[504-the colonel] ‘ What ? ’[3125-the squire] said [the squire]3125-the squire , ‘ with both [my]3125-the squire hands red - hot with the gout ? [You]3125-the squire must drive three of [us]1411-us , [colonel]530-colonel , and one of [us]1411-us must walk . ’[3125-the squire] ‘ [I]150-argemone will walk , ’[150-argemone] said [Argemone]150-argemone , in [her]150-argemone determined way . [Mrs. Lavington]158-mrs. lavington began something about propriety , but was stopped with another pound ’s worth of oaths by [the squire]3125-the squire , who , however , had tolerably recovered [his]3125-the squire good humour , and hurried [Mrs. Lavington]158-mrs. lavington and [Honoria]162-honoria , laughingly , into [the dog - cart]1417-the dog - cart , saying — ‘ [Argemone]150-argemone ’s safe enough with [Smith]172-lancelot ; [the servants]3860-the servants will lead the horses behind [them]1417-the dog - cart . It ’s only three miles [home]452-home , and [I]162-honoria should like to see [any one]936-any one speak to [her]150-argemone twice while [Smith]172-lancelot ’s fists are in the way . ’[162-honoria] [Lancelot]172-lancelot thought so too . ‘ [You]158-mrs. lavington can trust [yourself]158-mrs. lavington to [me]162-honoria , [Miss Lavington]189-miss lavington ? ’[162-honoria] ‘ By all means . [I]158-mrs. lavington shall enjoy the walk after — : ’[158-mrs. lavington] and [she]158-mrs. lavington stopped . In a moment [the dog - cart]1417-the dog - cart had rattled off , with a parting curse from [the squire]3125-the squire to [the servants]3860-the servants , who were unharnessing the horses . [Argemone]150-argemone took [Lancelot]172-lancelot ’s arm ; the soft touch thrilled through and through [him]172-lancelot ; and [Argemone]150-argemone felt , [she]150-argemone knew not why , a new sensation run through [her]150-argemone frame . [She]150-argemone shuddered — not with pain . ‘ [You]172-lancelot are cold , [Miss Lavington]189-miss lavington ? ’[150-argemone] ‘ Oh , not in the least . ’[150-argemone] Cold ! when every vein was boiling so strangely ! A soft luscious melancholy crept over [her]150-argemone . [She]150-argemone had always had a terror of darkness ; but now [she]150-argemone felt quite safe in [his]172-lancelot strength . The thought of [her]150-argemone own unprotected girlhood drew [her]150-argemone heart closer to [him]172-lancelot . [She]150-argemone remembered with pleasure the stories of [his]172-lancelot personal prowess , which had once made [her]150-argemone think [him]172-lancelot coarse and brutal . For the first time in [her]150-argemone life [she]150-argemone knew the delight of dependence — the holy charm of weakness . And as [they]1421-they paced on silently together , through the black awful night , while [the servants]3860-the servants lingered , far out of sight , about the horses , [she]150-argemone found out how utterly [she]150-argemone trusted to [him]172-lancelot . ‘ Listen ! ’[150-argemone] [she]150-argemone said . [A nightingale]1423-a nightingale was close to [them]1421-they , pouring out [his]172-lancelot whole soul in song . ‘ Is it not very late in the year for [a nightingale]1423-a nightingale ? ’[1423-a nightingale] ‘ [He]172-lancelot is waiting for [[his]172-lancelot mate]3864-his mate . [She]3864-his mate is rearing a late brood , [I]1423-a nightingale suppose . ’[1423-a nightingale] ‘ What do [you]1423-a nightingale think it is which can stir [him]172-lancelot up to such an ecstasy of joy , and transfigure [his]172-lancelot whole heart into melody ? ’[1423-a nightingale] ‘ What but love , the fulness of all joy , the evoker of all song ? ’[1423-a nightingale] ‘ [All song?—The angels]3865-all song?—the angels sing in [heaven]1101-heaven . ’[1423-a nightingale] ‘ So [they]3865-all song?—the angels say : but [the angels]3665-the angels must love if [they]3665-the angels sing . ’[1423-a nightingale] ‘ [They]3665-the angels love [God]281-god ! ’[1423-a nightingale] ‘ And [no one else]3868-no one else ? ’[1423-a nightingale] ‘ Oh yes : but that is universal , spiritual love ; not earthly love — a narrow passion for [an individual]3666-an individual . ’[1423-a nightingale] ‘ How do [we]3870-we know that [they]3665-the angels do not learn to love all by first loving [one]3305-one ? ’[1423-a nightingale] ‘ Oh , the angelic life is single ! ’[1423-a nightingale] ‘ Who told [you]1424-you so , [Miss Lavington]189-miss lavington ? ’[1424-you] [She]1424-you quoted the stock text , of course:—‘“In heaven [they]1425-they neither marry nor are given in marriage , but are as [the angels]3665-the angels . ” ’ ‘[3665-the angels] “ As the tree falls , so it lies . ” And God forbid that those who have been [true lovers on earth]1427-true lovers on earth should contract new marriages in [the next world]1428-the next world . Love is eternal . [Death]277-death may part [lovers]1429-lovers , but not love . And how do [we]1430-we know that [these angels]1431-these angels , as [they]1431-these angels call [them]1431-these angels , if [they]1431-these angels be really [persons]1432-persons , may not be united in pairs by some marriage bond , infinitely more perfect than any [we]1430-we can dream of on [earth]724-earth ? ’ ‘[1431-these angels] That is a very wild view , [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith , and not sanctioned by [the Church]24-the church , ’ said [Argemone]150-argemone , severely . ( Curious and significant it is , how [severe ladies]3872-severe ladies are apt to be whenever [they]3872-severe ladies talk of [the Church]863-the church . ) ‘[137-mr. smith] In plain historic fact , [the early fathers]1434-the early fathers and [the middle - age monks]1435-the middle - age monks did not sanction it : and are not [they]1431-these angels the very last persons to whom [one would go to be taught about marriage]1436-one would go to be taught about marriage ? Strange ! that [people]3181-people should take [their]3181-people notions of love from [the very men who prided [themselves]1438-the very men who prided themselves on being bound , by their own vows on being bound , by [their]1438-the very men who prided themselves on being bound , by their own vows own vows]1438-the very men who prided themselves on being bound , by their own vows , to know nothing about it ! ’ ‘[1438-the very men who prided themselves on being bound , by their own vows] [They]1438-the very men who prided themselves on being bound , by their own vows were [very holy men]1439-very holy men . ’ ‘[1439-very holy men] But still [men]612-men , as [I]0-i take it . And do [you]1441-you not see that Love is , like all spiritual things , only to be understood by experience — by loving ? ’ ‘[1441-you] But is love spiritual ? ’ ‘[1441-you] Pardon [me]0-i , but what a question for one who believes that “ [God]281-god is love ! ” ’ ‘[1441-you] But [the divines]1442-the divines tell [us]1443-us that the love of [human beings]3674-human beings is earthly . ’ ‘[1442-the divines] How did [they]1442-the divines know ? [They]1442-the divines had never tried . Oh , [Miss Lavington]189-miss lavington ! can not [you]189-miss lavington see that in those barbarous and profligate ages of [the later empire]1445-the later empire , it was impossible for [men]612-men to discern the spiritual beauty of marriage , degraded as it had been by heathen brutality ? Do [you]189-miss lavington not see that there must have been a continual tendency in the minds of [a celibate clergy]1447-a celibate clergy to look with contempt , almost with spite , on pleasures which were forbidden to [them]1447-a celibate clergy ? ’ Another pause . ‘[189-miss lavington] It must be very delicious , ’ said [Argemone]150-argemone , thoughtfully , ‘[189-miss lavington] for [any one who believes it , to think that marriage can last through eternity]1448-any one who believes it , to think that marriage can last through eternity . But , then , what becomes of entire love to [God]281-god ? How can [we]1443-us part [our]1443-us hearts between [him]281-god and [[his]281-god creatures]1449-his creatures ? ’ ‘[1443-us] It is a sin , then , to love [[your]189-miss lavington sister]1450-your sister ? or [[your]189-miss lavington friend]834-your friend ? What a low , material view of love , to fancy that [you]189-miss lavington can cut it up into so many pieces , like a cake , and give to [one person]1452-one person one tit - bit , and another to another , as the Popish books would have [you]189-miss lavington believe ! Love is like flame — light as many fresh flames at it as [you]189-miss lavington will , it grows , instead of diminishing , by the dispersion . ’ ‘[189-miss lavington] It is a beautiful imagination . ’ ‘[189-miss lavington] But , oh , how miserable and tantalising a thought , [Miss Lavington]189-miss lavington , to [those who know that a priceless spirit]1453-those who know that a priceless spirit is near [them]1453-those who know that a priceless spirit , which might be [one with theirs through all eternity , like twin stars in one common atmosphere , for ever giving and receiving wisdom and might , beauty and bliss]1454-one with theirs through all eternity , like twin stars in one common atmosphere , for ever giving and receiving wisdom and might , beauty and bliss , and yet are barred from [their]1453-those who know that a priceless spirit bliss by some invisible adamantine wall , against which [they]1453-those who know that a priceless spirit must beat [themselves]1453-those who know that a priceless spirit to death , like butterflies against the window - pane , gazing , and longing , and unable to guess why [they]1453-those who know that a priceless spirit are forbidden to enjoy ! ’ Why did [Argemone]150-argemone withdraw [her]150-argemone arm from [his]0-i ? [He]0-i knew , and [he]0-i felt that [she]150-argemone was entrusted to [him]0-i . [He]0-i turned away from the subject . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i wonder whether [they]1453-those who know that a priceless spirit are safe [home]452-home by this time ? ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i hope [[my]0-i father]3846-my father will not catch cold . How sad , [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith , that [he]3846-my father will swear so . [I]0-i do not like to say it ; and yet [you]137-mr. smith must have heard [him]3846-my father too often [yourself]137-mr. smith . ’ ‘[3846-my father] It is hardly a sin with [him]3846-my father now , [I]0-i think . [He]3846-my father has become so habituated to it , that [he]3846-my father attaches no meaning or notion whatsoever to [his]3846-my father own oaths . [I]0-i have heard [him]3846-my father do it with a smiling face to [the very beggar to whom [he]3846-my father was giving half - a - crown]1457-the very beggar to whom he was giving half - a - crown . [We]1458-we must not judge [a man of [his]3846-my father school]1459-a man of his school by the standard of [our]1458-we own day . ’ ‘[3846-my father] Let [us]1458-we hope so , ’ said [Argemone]150-argemone , sadly . There was another pause . At a turn of [the hill road]3874-the hill road the black masses of beech - wood opened , and showed the Priory lights twinkling right below . Strange that [Argemone]150-argemone felt sorry to find [herself]150-argemone so near [home]452-home . ‘[3846-my father] [We]1458-we shall go to [town]485-town next week , ’ said [she]150-argemone ; “ and then — [You]150-argemone are going to [Norway]29-norway this summer , are [you]150-argemone not ? ’[3846-my father] ‘ No . [I]3846-my father have learnt that [my]3846-my father duty lies nearer [home]452-home . ’[3846-my father] ‘ What are [you]150-argemone going to do ? ’[3846-my father] ‘ [I]3846-my father wish this summer , for the first time in [my]3846-my father life , to try and do some good — to examine a little into the real condition of [English working men]3877-english working men . ’[3846-my father] ‘ [I]3846-my father am afraid , [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith , that [I]3846-my father did not teach [you]137-mr. smith that duty . ’[3846-my father] ‘ Oh , [you]137-mr. smith have taught [me]3846-my father priceless things ! [You]137-mr. smith have taught [me]3846-my father beauty is the sacrament of heaven , and love its gate ; that that which is the most luscious is also the most pure . ’[3846-my father] ‘ But [I]3846-my father never spoke a word to [you]137-mr. smith on such subjects . ’[3846-my father] ‘ There are those , [Miss Lavington]189-miss lavington , to whom a human face can speak truths too deep for books . ’[3846-my father] [Argemone]150-argemone was silent ; but [she]150-argemone understood [him]1461-him . Why did [she]150-argemone not withdraw [her]150-argemone arm a second time ? In a moment more [the colonel]504-the colonel hailed [them]1463-them from [the dog - cart]1417-the dog - cart and behind [him]1461-him came [the britschka]1465-the britschka with [a relay of [servants]1467-servants]1466-a relay of servants . [They]1463-them parted with a long , lingering pressure of the hand , which haunted [her]150-argemone young palm all night in dreams . [Argemone]150-argemone got into [the carriage]1365-the carriage , [Lancelot]172-lancelot jumped into [the dog - cart]1417-the dog - cart , took the reins , and relieved [his]172-lancelot heart by galloping [Sandy]278-sandy up [the hill]570-the hill , and frightening [the returning coachman]1471-the returning coachman down [one bank]1472-one bank and [his]1461-him led horses up the other . ‘ [Vogue la Galère]279-vogue la galère , [Lancelot]172-lancelot ? [I]1471-the returning coachman hope [you]172-lancelot have made good use of [your]172-lancelot time ? ’[1471-the returning coachman] But [Lancelot]172-lancelot spoke no word all the way [home]452-home , and wandered till dawn in the woods around [[his]172-lancelot cottage]1474-his cottage , kissing the hand which [Argemone]150-argemone ’s palm had pressed . Some three months slipped away — right dreary months for [Lancelot]172-lancelot , for [the Lavingtons]248-the lavingtons went to [Baden - Baden]56-baden - baden for the summer . ‘ The waters were necessary for [their]1475-those german brunnen health . ’[248-the lavingtons] ... How wonderful it is , by the bye , that [those German Brunnen]1475-those german brunnen are never necessary for [poor people]1476-poor people ’s health ! ... and [they]1475-those german brunnen did not return till the end of August . So [Lancelot]172-lancelot buried [himself]172-lancelot up to the eyes in the Condition - of - the - Poor question — that is , in blue books , red books , sanitary reports , mine reports , factory reports ; and came to the conclusion , which is now pretty generally entertained , that something was the matter — but what , [no man]1477-no man knew , or , if [they]1478-they knew , thought proper to declare . Hopeless and bewildered , [he]172-lancelot left the books , and wandered day after day from [farm]1479-farm to [hamlet]1480-hamlet , and from [field]1248-field to [[tramper]1482-tramper ’s tent]1483-tramper ’s tent , in hopes of finding out the secret for [himself]172-lancelot . What [he]172-lancelot saw , of course [I]0-i must not say ; for if [I]0-i did [the reviewers]1484-the reviewers would declare , as usual , one and all , that [I]0-i copied out of the Morning Chronicle ; and the fact that these pages , ninety - nine hundredths of them at least , were written two years before the Morning Chronicle began its invaluable investigations , would be contemptuously put aside as at once impossible and arrogant . [I]0-i shall therefore only say , that [he]172-lancelot saw what [every one else]3329-every one else has seen , at least heard of , and got tired of hearing — though alas ! [they]3329-every one else have not got tired of seeing it ; and so proceed with [my]0-i story , only mentioning therein certain particulars which [folks]1214-folks seem , to [me]0-i , somewhat strangely , to have generally overlooked . But whatever [Lancelot]172-lancelot saw , or thought [he]172-lancelot saw , [I]0-i can not say that it brought [him]172-lancelot any nearer to a solution of the question ; and [he]172-lancelot at last ended by a sulky acquiescence in [Sam Weller]280-sam weller ’s memorable dictum : ‘ Who it is [I]172-lancelot ca n’t say ; but all [I]172-lancelot can say is that [somebody]3878-somebody ought to be wopped for this ! ’[172-lancelot] But one day , turning over , as hopelessly as [he]172-lancelot was beginning to turn over everything else , a new work of [Mr. Carlyle]126-mr. carlyle ’s , [he]172-lancelot fell on some such words as these : — ‘ The beginning and the end of what is the matter with [us]3879-us in these days is — that [we]3879-us have forgotten [God]281-god . ’[172-lancelot] [Forgotten God]281-god ? That was at least a defect of which blue books had taken no note . And it was one which , on the whole — granting , for the sake of argument , any real , living , or practical existence to That Being , might be a radical one — it brought [him]172-lancelot many hours of thought , that saying ; and when they were over , [he]172-lancelot rose up and went to find — [Tregarva]173-tregarva . ‘ Yes , [he]173-tregarva is [the man]738-the man . [He]173-tregarva is [the only man with whom [I]172-lancelot have ever met , of whom [I]172-lancelot could be sure , that independent of [his]173-tregarva own interest , without the allurements of respectability and decency , of habit and custom]3881-the only man with whom i have ever met , of whom i could be sure , that independent of his own interest , without the allurements of respectability and decency , of habit and custom , [he]173-tregarva believes in [God]281-god . And [he]173-tregarva too is [a poor man]3882-a poor man ; [he]173-tregarva has known the struggles , temptations , sorrows of [the poor]698-the poor . [I]172-lancelot will go to [him]173-tregarva . ’[172-lancelot] But as [Lancelot]172-lancelot rose to find [him]173-tregarva , there was put into [his]172-lancelot hand a letter , which kept [him]172-lancelot at [home]452-home a while longer — none other , in fact , than the long - expected answer from [Luke]137-mr. smith . ‘ WELL , [[MY]137-mr. smith DEAR COUSIN]3884-my dear cousin — [You]3884-my dear cousin may possibly have some logical ground from which to deny Popery , if [you]3884-my dear cousin deny all other religions with it ; but how [those who hold any received form of Christianity]3885-those who hold any received form of christianity whatsoever can fairly side with [you]3884-my dear cousin against [Rome]21-rome , [I]137-mr. smith can not see . [I]137-mr. smith am sure [I]137-mr. smith have been sent to [Rome]21-rome by [them]3885-those who hold any received form of christianity , not drawn thither by [Jesuits]282-jesuits . Not merely by [their]3885-those who hold any received form of christianity defects and inconsistencies ; not merely because [they]3885-those who hold any received form of christianity go on taunting [us]3886-we , and shrieking at [us]3886-we with the cry that [we]3886-we ought to go to [Rome]21-rome , till [we]3886-we at last , wearied out , take [them]3885-those who hold any received form of christianity at [their]3885-those who hold any received form of christianity word , and do at [their]3885-those who hold any received form of christianity bidding the thing [we]3886-we used to shrink from with terror — not this merely but the very doctrines [we]3886-we hold in common with [them]3885-those who hold any received form of christianity , have sent [me]137-mr. smith to [Rome]21-rome . For would [these men]3704-these men have known of [them]3885-those who hold any received form of christianity if [Rome]21-rome had not been ? The Trinity — the Atonement — the Inspiration of Scripture.—A future state — that point on which [the present generation , without a smattering of psychological science]3888-the present generation , without a smattering of psychological science , without even the old belief in apparitions , dogmatises so narrowly and arrogantly — what would [they]3704-these men have known of [them]3885-those who hold any received form of christianity but for [Rome]21-rome ? And [she]3889-she says there are [three realms in the future state]3890-three realms in the future state ... [heaven , hell]3891-heaven , hell , and purgatory ... What right have [they]3890-three realms in the future state to throw away the latter , and arbitrarily retain the two former ? [I]137-mr. smith am told that Scripture gives no warrant for a third state . [She]3889-she says that it does — that it teaches that implicitly , as it teaches other , the very highest doctrines ; some hold , the Trinity itself ... It may be proved from Scripture ; for it may be proved from the love and justice of [God]281-god revealed in Scripture . [The Protestants]220-protestants divide — in theory , that is — [mankind]1077-mankind into [two classes]3893-two classes , the righteous , who are destined to infinite bliss ; [the wicked , who are doomed to infinite torment]3894-the wicked , who are doomed to infinite torment ; in which [latter class]3895-latter class , to make [their]220-protestants arbitrary division exhaustive , [they]220-protestants put of course nine hundred and ninety - nine out of the thousand , and doom to everlasting companionship with [Borgias]283-borgias and [Cagliostros]57-cagliostros , [the gentle , frivolous girl]3896-the gentle , frivolous girl , or [the peevish boy , who would have shrunk , in life , with horror from the contact ... Well , at least , [their]3890-three realms in the future state hell]3897-the peevish boy , who would have shrunk , in life , with horror from the contact ... well , at least , their hell is hellish enough ... if it were but just ... But [I]137-mr. smith , [Lancelot]172-lancelot , [I]137-mr. smith can not believe it ! [I]137-mr. smith will not believe it ! [I]137-mr. smith had [a brother]3632-a brother once — affectionate , simple , generous , full of noble aspirations — but without , alas ! a thought of [God]281-god ; yielding in a hundred little points , and some great ones , to the infernal temptations of [a public school]3899-a public school ... [He]281-god died at seventeen . Where is [he]281-god now ? [Lancelot]172-lancelot ! where is [he]281-god now ? Never for a day has that thought left [my]137-mr. smith mind for years . Not in [heaven]1101-heaven — for [he]281-god has no right there ; [Protestants]1112-protestants would say that as well as [I]137-mr. smith ... Where , then?—Lancelot ! not in [that other place]3902-that other place . [I]137-mr. smith can not , [I]137-mr. smith will not believe it . For the sake of [God]281-god ’s honour , as well as of [my]137-mr. smith own sanity , [I]137-mr. smith will not believe it ! There must be some third place — some intermediate chance , some door of hope — some purifying and redeeming process beyond the grave ... Why not a purifying fire ? Ages of that are surely punishment enough — and if there be a fire of hell , why not a fire of purgatory ? ... After all , the idea of purgatory as a fire is only an opinion , not a dogma of [the Church]863-the church ... But if the gross flesh which has sinned is to be punished by the matter which it has abused , why may it not be purified by it ? ’[137-mr. smith] ‘ [You]137-mr. smith may laugh , if [you]137-mr. smith will , at both , and say again , as [I]0-i have heard [you]137-mr. smith say ere now , that [the popular Christian paradise and [hell]3905-hell]3904-the popular christian paradise and hell are but a Pagan Olympus and [Tartarus]58-tartarus , as grossly material as [Mahomet]284-mahomet ’s , without the honest thorough - going sexuality , which [you]137-mr. smith thought made [his]281-god notion logical and consistent ... Well , [you]137-mr. smith may say that , but [Protestants]220-protestants can not ; for [their]220-protestants idea of [heaven]1101-heaven and [ours]3907-ours is the same — with this exception , that [theirs]220-protestants will contain but a thin band of saved ones , while [ours]3907-ours will fill and grow to all eternity ... [I]0-i tell [you]137-mr. smith , [Lancelot]172-lancelot , it is just the very doctrines for which [England]242-young england most curses [Rome]21-rome , and this very purgatory at the head of [them]220-protestants , which constitute [her]242-young england strength and [her]242-young england allurement ; which appeal to the reason , the conscience , the heart of [men]612-men , like [me]0-i , who have revolted from the novel superstition which looks pitilessly on at the fond memories of [the brother]3909-the brother , the prayers of [the orphan]3910-the orphan , the doubled desolation of [the widow]3911-the widow , with its cold terrible assurance , “ There is no hope for [thy]3912-thy loved and lost ones — no hope , but hell for evermore ! ” ‘[0-i] [I]0-i do not expect to convert [you]1488-you . [You]1488-you have [your]1488-you metempsychosis , and [your]1488-you theories of progressive incarnation , and [your]1488-you monads , and [your]1488-you spirits of the stars and flowers . [I]0-i have not forgotten a certain talk of [ours]1489-ours over [Falk Von Müller]285-falk von müller ’s Recollections of [Goethe]187-goethe , and how [[you]1488-you [materialists]1491-materialists]1490-you materialists are often the most fantastic of [theorists]1492-theorists ... [I]0-i do not expect , [I]0-i say , to convert [you]1488-you . [I]0-i only want to show [you]1488-you there is no use trying to show [the self - satisfied Pharisees of the popular sect]1493-the self - satisfied pharisees of the popular sect — why , in spite of all [their]1493-the self - satisfied pharisees of the popular sect curses , [men]612-men still go back to [Rome]21-rome . ’ [Lancelot]172-lancelot read this , and re - read it ; and smiled , but sadly — and the more [he]172-lancelot read , the stronger its arguments seemed to [him]172-lancelot , and [he]172-lancelot rejoiced thereat . For there is a bad pleasure — happy [he]172-lancelot who has not felt it — in a pitiless reductio ad absurdum , which asks tauntingly , ‘[1488-you] Why do [you]1488-you not follow out [your]1488-you own conclusions?’—instead of thanking [God]281-god that [people]3181-people do not follow [them]3181-people out , and that [their]3181-people hearts are sounder than [their]3181-people heads . Was it with this feeling that [the fancy]1496-the fancy took possession of [him]1488-you , to show the letter to [Tregarva]173-tregarva ? [I]0-i hope not — perhaps [he]1488-you did not altogether wish to lead [him]1488-you into temptation , any more than [I]0-i wish to lead [[my]0-i readers]1497-my readers , but only to make [him]1488-you , just as [I]0-i wish to make [them]1497-my readers , face manfully a real awful question now racking the hearts of [hundreds]1498-hundreds , and see how [they]1497-my readers will be able to answer [the sophist fiend]1499-the sophist fiend — for honestly , such [he]1488-you is — when [their]1497-my readers time comes , as come it will . At least [he]1488-you wanted to test at once [Tregarva]173-tregarva ’s knowledge and [his]1488-you logic . As for [his]1488-you ‘ faith , ’[1488-you] alas ! [he]1488-you had not so much reverence for it as to care what effect [Luke]137-mr. smith ’s arguments might have there . ‘ [The whole man]3913-the whole man , ’[172-lancelot] quoth [Lancelot]172-lancelot to [himself]172-lancelot , ‘ is a novel phenomenon ; and all phenomena , however magnificent , are surely fair subjects for experiment . [Magendie]286-magendie may have gone too far , certainly , in dissecting a live dog — but what harm in [my]172-lancelot pulling the mane of a dead lion ? ’[172-lancelot] So [he]172-lancelot showed the letter to [Tregarva]173-tregarva as [they]1500-they were fishing together one day — for [Lancelot]172-lancelot had been installed duly in the Whitford trout preserves’—Tregarva read it slowly ; asked , shrewdly enough , the meaning of a word or two as [he]172-lancelot went on ; at last folded it up deliberately , and returned it to [its owner]1501-its owner with a deep sigh . [Lancelot]172-lancelot said nothing for a few minutes ; but [the giant]3364-the giant seemed so little inclined to open the conversation , that [he]172-lancelot was forced at last to ask [him]3364-the giant what [he]3364-the giant thought of it . ‘ It is n’t a matter for thinking , [sir]753-sir , to [my]172-lancelot mind — There ’s a nice fish on the feed there , just over - right that alder . ’[172-lancelot] ‘ Hang the fish ! Why not a matter for thinking ? ’[3358-the cornishman] ‘ To [my]3358-the cornishman mind , [sir]753-sir , [a man]445-a man may think a deal too much about many matters that come in [his]445-a man way . ’[3358-the cornishman] ‘ What should [he]445-a man do with [them]3917-them , then ? ’[172-lancelot] ‘ Mind [his]445-a man own business . ’[3358-the cornishman] ‘ Pleasant for those whom [they]3917-them concern!—That ’s rather a cold - blooded speech for [you]753-sir , [Tregarva]173-tregarva ! ’[3358-the cornishman] [The Cornishman]3358-the cornishman looked up at [him]172-lancelot earnestly . [His]3358-the cornishman eyes were glittering — was it with tears ? ‘ Do n’t fancy [I]3358-the cornishman do n’t feel for [the poor young gentleman]3918-the poor young gentleman — [God]281-god help him!—I’ve been through it all — or not through it , that ’s to say . [I]3358-the cornishman had [a brother]3632-a brother once , as fine [a young fellow as ever handled pick]3920-a young fellow as ever handled pick , as kind - hearted as [a woman]3251-a woman , and as honest as the sun in Heaven.—But [he]3632-a brother would drink , sir;—that one temptation , [he]3632-a brother never could stand it . And one day at the shaft ’s mouth , reaching after the kibble - chain — maybe [he]3632-a brother was in liquor , maybe not — [the Lord]817-the lord knows ; but — ’[3358-the cornishman] ‘ [I]1504-the strong man did n’t know [him]3632-a brother again , [sir]753-sir , when [we]3924-we picked [him]3632-a brother up , any more than — ’[1504-the strong man] and [the strong man]1504-the strong man shuddered from head to foot , and beat impatiently on the ground with [his]1504-the strong man heavy heel , as if to crush down the rising horror . ‘ Where is [he]3632-a brother , [sir]753-sir ? ’[1504-the strong man] A long pause . ‘ Do [you]753-sir think [I]1504-the strong man did n’t ask that , [sir]753-sir , for years and years after , of [God]281-god , and [my]1504-the strong man own soul , and [heaven]1101-heaven and [earth]724-earth , and the things under [the earth]866-the earth , too ? For many a night did [I]1504-the strong man go down that mine out of [my]1504-the strong man turn , and sat for hours in [that level]3930-that level , watching and watching , if perhaps the spirit of [him]3632-a brother might haunt about , and tell [[his]3632-a brother poor brother]3931-his poor brother one word of news — one way or the other — anything would have been a comfort — but the doubt [I]1504-the strong man could n’t bear . And yet at last [I]1504-the strong man learnt to bear it — and what ’s more , [I]1504-the strong man learnt not to care for it . It ’s a bold word — there ’s [one who knows whether or not it is a true one]3932-one who knows whether or not it is a true one . ’[1504-the strong man] ‘ [Good Heavens!—and]287-good heavens!—and what then did [you]753-sir say to [yourself]753-sir ? ’[1504-the strong man] ‘ [I]1504-the strong man said this , [sir]753-sir — or rather , one came as [I]1504-the strong man was on [my]1504-the strong man knees , and said it to [me]1504-the strong man — What ’s done [you]753-sir ca n’t mend . What ’s left , [you]753-sir can . Whatever has happened is [God]281-god ’s concern now , and none but [His]281-god . Do [you]753-sir see that as far as [you]753-sir can no such thing ever happen again , on the face of [[His]281-god earth]3934-his earth . And from that day , [sir]753-sir , [I]1504-the strong man gave [myself]1504-the strong man up to that one thing , and will until [I]1504-the strong man die , to save [the poor young fellows like [myself]1504-the strong man , who are left now - a - days to [the Devil]237-devil , body and soul , just when [they]3936-the poor young fellows like myself , who are left now - a - days to the devil , body and soul , just when they are in the prime of their power to work for god are in the prime of [their]3936-the poor young fellows like myself , who are left now - a - days to the devil , body and soul , just when they are in the prime of their power to work for god power to work for [God]281-god]3936-the poor young fellows like myself , who are left now - a - days to the devil , body and soul , just when they are in the prime of their power to work for god . ’[1504-the strong man] ‘ Ah ! ’[288-lancelot—‘if] said [Lancelot—‘if]288-lancelot—‘if poor [Luke]137-mr. smith ’s spirit were but as strong as [yours]1505-you ! ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i strong ? ’ answered [he]0-i , with a sad smile ; ‘[1505-you] and so [you]1505-you think , [sir]753-sir . But it ’s written , and it ’s [true—“The]1507-true—“the heart knoweth its own bitterness . ” ’ ‘[1507-true—“the] Then [you]1505-you absolutely refuse to try to fancy [your]1505-you — [his]137-mr. smith present state ? ’ ‘[1505-you] Yes , [sir]753-sir , because if [I]0-i did fancy it , that would be a certain sign [I]0-i did n’t know it . If [we]1509-we ca n’t conceive what [God]281-god has prepared for those that [we]1509-we know loved [Him]137-mr. smith , how much less can [we]1509-we for [them]1510-them of whom [we]1509-we do n’t know whether [they]1510-them loved [Him]137-mr. smith or not ? ’ ‘[1509-we] Well , ’ thought [Lancelot]172-lancelot to [himself]172-lancelot , ‘[1509-we] [I]0-i did not do so very wrong in trusting [your]753-sir intellect to cut through a sophism . ’ ‘[0-i] But what do [you]1505-you believe , [Tregarva]173-tregarva ? ’ ‘[1505-you] [I]0-i believe this , [sir]753-sir — and [[your]753-sir cousin]1512-your cousin will believe the same , if [he]1512-your cousin will only give up , as [I]0-i am sore afraid [he]1512-your cousin will need to some day , sticking to arguments and doctrines about [the Lord]817-the lord , and love and trust [the Lord]817-the lord [himself]1512-your cousin . [I]0-i believe , [sir]753-sir , that [the judge of all [the earth]866-the earth]1516-the judge of all the earth will do right — and what ’s right ca n’t be wrong , nor cruel either , else it would not be like [Him]817-the lord who loved [us]1518-us to the death , that ’s all [I]0-i know ; and that ’s enough for [me]0-i . To whom little is given , of [him]817-the lord is little required . [He]817-the lord that did n’t know [[his]817-the lord Master]567-his master ’s will , will be beaten with few stripes , and [he]817-the lord that did know it , as [I]0-i do , will be beaten with many , if [he]817-the lord neglects it — and that latter , not the former , is [my]0-i concern . ’ ‘[281-god] Well , ’ thought [Lancelot]172-lancelot to [himself]172-lancelot , ‘[281-god] this great heart has gone down to the root of the matter — the right and wrong of it . [He]817-the lord , at least , has not forgotten [God]281-god . Well , [I]0-i would give up all the Teleologies and cosmogonies that [I]0-i ever dreamt or read , just to believe what [he]817-the lord believes — Heigho and well - a - day!—Paul ! [hist]1520-hist ? [I]0-i ’ll swear that was an otter ! ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i hope not , [sir]753-sir , [I]0-i ’m sure . [I]1520-hist have n’t seen the spraint of one here this two years . ’[1520-hist] ‘ There again — don’t [you]753-sir see something move under [that marl bank]3937-that marl bank ? ’[173-tregarva] [Tregarva]173-tregarva watched a moment , and then ran up to the spot , and throwing [himself]173-tregarva on [his]173-tregarva face on the edge , leant over , grappled something — and was instantly , to [Lancelot]172-lancelot ’s astonishment , grappled in [his]172-lancelot turn by a rough , lank , white dog , whose teeth , however , could not get through the velveteen sleeve . ‘ [I]172-lancelot ’ll give in , [keeper]3938-keeper ! [he]3939-him ’s deaf as a post , [you]3938-keeper knows . ’[172-lancelot] ‘ [I]172-lancelot wo n’t harm [him]3939-him if [you]3938-keeper take [him]3939-him off , and come up quietly . ’[172-lancelot] This mysterious conversation was carried on with a human head , which peeped above the water , its arms supporting from beneath the growling cur — such a visage as only worn - out poachers , or [trampling drovers]1522-trampling drovers , or [London chiffonniers]46-london carry ; pear - shaped and retreating to a narrow peak above , while below , the bleared cheeks , and drooping lips , and peering purblind eyes , perplexed , hopeless , defiant , and yet sneaking , bespeak [their]1523-their share in the ‘ inheritance of [the kingdom of heaven]1146-the kingdom of heaven . ’—Savages[1522-trampling drovers] without the resources of [a savage]1524-a savage — [slaves]1525-slaves without the protection of [a master]3799-a master — to whom the cart - whip and [the rice - swamp]1527-the rice - swamp would be a change for the better — for there , at least , is food and shelter . Slowly and distrustfully [a dripping scarecrow of rags and bones]1528-a dripping scarecrow of rags and bones rose from [his]172-lancelot hiding - place in [the water]688-the water , and then stopped suddenly , and seemed inclined to dash through [the river]505-the river ; but [Tregarva]173-tregarva held [him]172-lancelot fast . ‘ There ’s two on [ye]172-lancelot ! [He]3733-a gentleman wo n’t tell — will [you]172-lancelot , [sir]753-sir ? ’[173-tregarva] And [he]173-tregarva turned to [Lancelot]172-lancelot . ‘ Have pity on [the poor creature]3944-the poor creature , [sir]753-sir , for God ’s sake — it is n’t often [he]3733-a gentleman gets it . ’[173-tregarva] ‘ [I]1531-the creature wo n’t tell , [[my]1531-the creature man]3527-my man . [I]1531-the creature ’ve not seen [you]172-lancelot doing any harm . Have n’t [I]173-tregarva warned [you]172-lancelot ? Of course [you]172-lancelot wo n’t prosper : as [you]172-lancelot make [your]172-lancelot bed , so [you]172-lancelot must lie in [it]3958-it .
