[I]0-i do hope [you]177-crawy wo n’t have [me]0-i up to bench . ’ Tain’t a month now as [I]177-crawy ’m[177-crawy] out o ’ prizzum along o ’[177-crawy] they fir - toppings , and [I]0-i should , [you]177-crawy see — ’ with a look up and down and round at [the gay hay - meadows]3962-the gay hay - meadows , and [the fleet water]3963-the fleet water , and the soft gleaming clouds , which to [Lancelot]172-lancelot seemed most pathetic,—‘I should like to ha ’[0-i] a spell o ’ fresh air , like , afore [I]173-tregarva goes in again . ’[173-tregarva] [Tregarva]173-tregarva stood over [him]0-i and looked down at [him]0-i , like some huge stately bloodhound on a trembling mangy cur . ‘ Good heavens ! ’[172-lancelot] thought [Lancelot]172-lancelot , as [his]172-lancelot eye wandered from the sad steadfast dignity of [the one]1534-the one , to the dogged helpless misery of the other—‘can those two be really [fellow - citizens]1535-fellow - citizens ? [fellow - Christians?—even animals of the same species]1536-fellow - christians?—even animals of the same species ? Hard to believe ! ’ True , [Lancelot]172-lancelot ; but to quote [you]172-lancelot against [yourself]172-lancelot , [Bacon]235-bacon , or rather the instinct which taught [Bacon]235-bacon , teaches [you]172-lancelot to discern the invisible common law under the deceitful phenomena of sense . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i must have those night - lines , [Crawy]177-crawy , ’ quoth [Tregarva]173-tregarva , at length . ‘[177-crawy] Then [I]0-i must starve . [You]172-lancelot might ever so well take away the dog . [They]1537-they ’re the life of [me]177-crawy . ’[177-crawy] ‘ [They]1537-they ’re[177-crawy] the death of [you]172-lancelot . Why do n’t [you]172-lancelot go and work , instead of idling about , stealing trout ? ’ ‘[172-lancelot] Be [you]172-lancelot a laughing at [a poor fellow in [his]1538-a poor fellow in his trouble trouble]1538-a poor fellow in his trouble ? Who ’d gie [me]0-i a day ’s work , [I]0-i ’d like to know ? It ’s twenty year too late for that ! ’ [Lancelot]172-lancelot stood listening . Yes , [that wretch]3964-that wretch , too , was [a man]445-a man and [a brother]3632-a brother — at least so [books]3967-books used to say . Time was , when [he]172-lancelot had looked on [a poacher]3968-a poacher as [a Pariah ‘[1539-them] hostem humani generis’—and]3969-a pariah ‘ hostem humani generis’—and only deplored that the law forbade [him]172-lancelot to shoot [them]1539-them down , like cats and otters ; but [he]172-lancelot had begun to change [his]172-lancelot mind . [He]172-lancelot had learnt , and learnt rightly , the self - indulgence , the danger , the cruelty , of indiscriminate alms . It looked well enough in theory , on paper . ‘ But — but — but , ’[172-lancelot] thought [Lancelot]172-lancelot , ‘ in practice , one ca n’t help feeling a little of that un - economic feeling called pity . No doubt [the fellow]3970-the fellow has committed an unpardonable sin in daring to come into [the world]475-the world when there was no call for [him]3970-the fellow ; [one]3305-one used to think , certainly , that [children]935-children ’s opinions were not consulted on such points before [they]935-children were born , and that therefore it might be hard to visit the sins of [the fathers]3974-the fathers on [the children]930-the children , even though the labour - market were a little overstocked—“mais nous avons changé tout cela , ” like [[M. Jourdain]291-m. jourdain ’s doctors]3976-m. jourdain ’s doctors . No doubt , too , [the fellow]3970-the fellow might have got work if [he]3970-the fellow had chosen — in [Kamschatka]60-kamschatka or [the Cannibal Islands]89-the cannibal islands ; for [the political economists]3978-the political economists have proved , beyond a doubt , that there is work somewhere or other for [every one who chooses to work]3979-every one who chooses to work . But as , unfortunately , [society]3980-society has neglected to inform [him]1541-he of the state of the Cannibal Island labour - market , or to pay [his]1541-he passage thither when informed thereof , [he]1541-he has had to choose in [the somewhat limited labour - field of [the Whitford Priors]144-whitford priors ’[172-lancelot] union]3981-the somewhat limited labour - field of the whitford priors ’ union , whose workhouse is already every winter filled with [abler - bodied men than [he]1541-he , between starvation]1540-abler - bodied men than he , between starvation — and this—. Well , as for employing [him]1541-he , one would have thought that there was a little work waiting to be done in those five miles of [heather and snipe - bog]1542-heather and snipe - bog , which [I]0-i used to tramp over last winter — but those , it seems , are still on the “ margin of cultivation , ” and not a remunerative investment — that is , to [capitalists]1543-capitalists . [I]0-i wonder if [any one]936-any one had made [Crawy]177-crawy a present of [ten acres of them]1545-ten acres of them when [he]177-crawy came of age , and commanded [him]177-crawy to till that or be hanged , whether [he]177-crawy would not have found it a profitable investment ? But bygones are bygones , and there [he]177-crawy is , and the moors , thanks to the rights of property — in this case the rights of the dog in the manger — belong to [poor old Lavington]1546-poor old lavington — that is , the game and timber on them ; and neither [Crawy]177-crawy nor [any one else]1547-any one else can touch them . What can [I]0-i do for [him]177-crawy ? Convert [him]177-crawy ? to what ? For the next life , even [Tregarva]173-tregarva ’s talisman seems to fail . And for this life — perhaps if [he]1541-he had had a few more practical proofs of a divine justice and government — [that “ kingdom of heaven]1548-that “ kingdom of heaven ” of which [Luke]137-mr. smith talks , in the sensible bodily matters which [he]1541-he does appreciate , [he]1541-he might not be so unwilling to trust to it for the invisible spiritual matters which [he]1541-he does not appreciate . At all events , [one]3305-one has but one chance of winning [him]177-crawy , and that is , through those five senses which [he]177-crawy has left . What if [he]177-crawy does spend the money in gross animal enjoyment ? What will the amount of it be , compared with the animal enjoyments which [[my]0-i station]1550-my station allows [me]0-i daily without reproach ! A little more bacon — a little more beer — a little more tobacco ; at all events they will be more important to [him]177-crawy than a pair of new boots or an extra box of cigars to [me]0-i . ’—And [Lancelot]172-lancelot put [his]172-lancelot hand in [his]172-lancelot pocket , and pulled out a sovereign . No doubt [he]177-crawy was a great goose ; but if [you]177-crawy can answer [his]172-lancelot arguments , [reader]3174-reader , [I]177-crawy can not . ‘[177-crawy] Look here — what are [your]177-crawy night - lines worth ? ’ ‘[177-crawy] A matter of seven shilling ; ai n’t they now , [Paul Tregarva]173-tregarva ? ’ ‘[1551-they] [I]0-i should suppose [they]1551-they are . ’ ‘[1551-they] Then do [you]177-crawy give [me]0-i the lines , one and all , and there ’s a sovereign for you.—No , [I]0-i ca n’t trust [you]177-crawy with it all at once . [I]0-i ’ll give it to [Tregarva]173-tregarva , and [he]173-tregarva shall allow [you]177-crawy four shillings a week as long as it lasts , if [you]177-crawy ’ll promise to keep off [[Squire Lavington]136-squire lavington ’s river]1552-squire lavington ’s river . ’ It was pathetic , and yet disgusting , to see the abject joy of [the poor creature]3944-the poor creature . ‘[136-squire lavington] Well , ’ thought [Lancelot]172-lancelot , ‘[136-squire lavington] if [he]173-tregarva deserves to be wretched , so do [I]0-i — why , therefore , if [we]1553-we are one as bad as the other , should [I]0-i not make [his]173-tregarva wretchedness a little less for the time being ? ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i waint come a - near [the water]688-the water . [You]177-crawy trust [me]0-i — [I]0-i minds [them]1555-them as is kind to [me’—and]1556-i a thought seemed suddenly to lighten up [his]0-i dull intelligence . ‘ [I]1556-i say , [Paul]173-tregarva , hark [you]173-tregarva here . [I]1556-i see that Bantam into D * * * t’other day . ’[1556-i] ‘ What ! is [he]173-tregarva down already ? ’[0-i] ‘ With [a dog - cart]3984-a dog - cart ; [he]173-tregarva and [another of [[his]173-tregarva pals]3986-his pals]3985-another of his pals ; and [I]1556-i see [’em]3987-’em[1556-i] take out a silk flue , [I]0-i did . Lying again ! ’ ‘[177-crawy] No , but [I]0-i sayed it in course . [I]0-i did n’t want [they]1557-they a - robbing [here]775-here ; so [I]0-i think [they]1557-they worked mainly up [Squire Vaurien]293-squire vaurien ’s water . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i wish [I]0-i ’d caught [them]1557-they here , ’ quoth [Tregarva]173-tregarva , grimly enough ; ‘[0-i] though [I]0-i do n’t think [they]1557-they came , or [I]0-i should have seen the track on [the banks]1559-the banks . ’ ‘[1560-he] But [he]1560-he sayed like , as how [he]1560-he should be down here again about pheasant shooting . ’ ‘[1560-he] Trust [him]1560-he for it . Let [us]1561-us know , now , if [you]177-crawy see [him]1560-he . ’ ‘[177-crawy] And that [I]0-i will , too . [I]0-i would n’t save a feather for [that ’ ere old rascal]3988-that ’ ere old rascal , [Harry]174-old harry . If [the devil]600-the devil do n’t have [he]1560-he , [I]0-i do n’t see no use in keeping [no devil]3990-no devil . But [I]0-i minds [them]600-the devil as has mercy on [me]0-i , though [my]0-i name is [Crawy]177-crawy . Ay , ’[0-i] [he]0-i added , bitterly , ‘ ’[0-i] tain’t so many kind turns as [I]0-i gets in this life , that [I]0-i can afford to forget e’er a one . ’ And [he]0-i sneaked off , with the deaf dog at [his]0-i heels . ‘[0-i] How did [that fellow]1562-that fellow get [his]1562-that fellow name , [Tregarva]173-tregarva ? ’ ‘[1562-that fellow] Oh , [most of [them]1564-them]1563-most of them have nicknames round here . Some of [them]1564-them hardly know [their]1564-them own real names , [sir]753-sir . ’ ( ‘[1562-that fellow] A sure sign of low civilisation , ’ thought [Lancelot]172-lancelot . ) ‘[1562-that fellow] But [he]1562-that fellow got [his]1562-that fellow a foolish way ; and yet it was the ruin of [him]1562-that fellow . When [he]1562-that fellow was [a boy of fifteen]1566-a boy of fifteen , [he]1562-that fellow got miching away in [church]3599-church - time , as [boys]468-boys will , and took off [his]1562-that fellow clothes to get in somewhere here in [this very river]1569-this very river , groping in the banks after craw - fish ; and as [the devil]600-the devil — for [I]0-i can think no less — would have it , [a big one]1571-a big one catches hold of [him]1562-that fellow by the fingers with one claw , and a root with the other , and holds [him]1562-that fellow there till [Squire Lavington]136-squire lavington comes out to take [his]136-squire lavington walk after [church]3599-church , and there [he]136-squire lavington caught [the boy]1359-the boy , and gave [him]1359-the boy a thrashing there and then , naked as [he]1359-the boy stood . And the story got wind , and [all the chaps]1574-all the chaps round called [him]1562-that fellow [Crawy]177-crawy ever afterwards , and [the poor fellow]1575-the poor fellow got quite reckless from that day , and never looked [any one]936-any one in the face again ; and being ashamed of [himself]1575-the poor fellow , [you]1577-you see , [sir]753-sir , was never ashamed of anything else — and there [he]1575-the poor fellow is . That dog ’s [[his]1562-that fellow only friend]1579-his only friend , and gets a livelihood for [them]1580-them both . It ’s growing old now ; and when it dies , [he]1575-the poor fellow ’ll starve . ’ ‘[1575-the poor fellow] Well — [the world]475-the world has no right to blame [him]1575-the poor fellow for not doing [his]1575-the poor fellow duty , till it has done its own by [him]1575-the poor fellow a little better . ’ ‘[294-cain] But [the world]475-the world will , [sir]753-sir , because [it]475-the world hates [its]475-the world duty , and cries all day long , like [Cain]294-cain , “ Am [I]0-i [[[my]0-i brother]1584-my brother ’s keeper]1585-my brother ’s keeper ? ” ’ ‘[294-cain] Do [you]753-sir think it knows its duty ? [I]0-i have found it easy enough to see that something is diseased , [Tregarva]173-tregarva ; but to find the medicine first , and to administer it afterwards , is a very different matter . ’ ‘[294-cain] Well — [I]0-i suppose [the world]475-the world will never be mended till the day of judgment . ’ ‘[294-cain] In plain English , not mended till it is destroyed . Hopeful for [the poor world]1587-the poor world ! [I]0-i should fancy , if [I]0-i believed that , that the devil in the old history — which [you]753-sir believe — had had the best of it with a vengeance , when [he]1575-the poor fellow brought sin into [the world]475-the world , and ruined it . [I]0-i dare not believe that . How dare [you]753-sir , who say that [God]281-god sent [[His]281-god Son]1227-his son into [the world]475-the world to defeat [the devil]600-the devil ? ’ [Tregarva]173-tregarva was silent a while . ‘[753-sir] Learning and the Gospel together ought to do something , [sir]753-sir , towards mending it . [One]3305-one would think so . But the prophecies are against that . ’ ‘[1214-folks] As [folks]1214-folks happen to read [them]1214-folks just now . A hundred years hence [they]1214-folks may be finding the very opposite meaning in [them]1214-folks . Come , [Tregarva,—Suppose]1595-tregarva,—suppose [I]0-i teach [you]753-sir a little of the learning , and [you]753-sir teach [me]0-i a little of the Gospel — do [you]753-sir think [we]1596-we two could mend [the world]475-the world between [us]1596-we , or even mend [Whitford Priors]144-whitford priors ? ’ ‘[753-sir] [God]281-god knows , [sir]753-sir , ’ said [Tregarva]173-tregarva . * * * * * ‘[753-sir] [Tregarva]173-tregarva , ’ said [Lancelot]172-lancelot , as [they]1596-we were landing the next trout , ‘[173-tregarva] where will [that Crawy]1599-that crawy go , when [he]1599-that crawy dies ? ’ ‘[281-god] [God]281-god knows , [sir]753-sir , ’ said [Tregarva]173-tregarva . * * * * * [Lancelot]172-lancelot went thoughtful [home]452-home , and sat down — not to answer [Luke]137-mr. smith ’s letter — for [he]172-lancelot knew no answer but [Tregarva]173-tregarva ’s , and that , alas ! [he]172-lancelot could not give , for [he]172-lancelot did not believe it , but only longed to believe it . So [he]172-lancelot turned off the subject by a question — ‘[281-god] [You]753-sir speak of [yourself]753-sir as being already [a member of [the Romish communion]1602-the romish communion]1601-a member of the romish communion . How is this ? Have [you]753-sir given up [your]753-sir curacy ? Have [you]753-sir told [[your]753-sir father]3830-your father ? [I]0-i fancy that if [you]753-sir had done so [I]0-i must have heard of it ere now . [I]0-i entreat [you]753-sir to tell [me]0-i the state of the case , for , heathen as [I]0-i am , [I]0-i am still [an Englishman]1153-an englishman ; and there are certain old superstitions still lingering among [us]1605-us — whencesoever [we]1605-us may have got them first — about truth and common honesty — [you]753-sir understand [me]0-i . — ‘ Do not be angry . But there is a prejudice against the truthfulness of [Romish priests]3992-romish priests and [Romish converts.—It]3993-romish converts.—it ’s no affair of [mine]0-i . [I]753-sir see quite enough [Protestant rogues]3994-protestant rogues and [liars]3951-liars , to prevent [my]753-sir having any pleasure in proving [Romanists]3996-romanists , or [any other persons]3997-any other persons , [rogues]3998-rogues and [liars]3951-liars also . But [I]753-sir am — if not fond of [you]753-sir — at least sufficiently fond to be anxious for [your]753-sir good name . [You]753-sir used to be [an open - hearted fellow]4000-an open - hearted fellow enough . Do prove to [the world]475-the world that cœlum , non animum mutant , qui trans mare currunt . ’[753-sir] The day after [the Lavingtons]248-the lavingtons ’ return , when [Lancelot]172-lancelot walked up to [the Priory]534-the priory with a fluttering heart to inquire after [all parties]4003-all parties , and see one , [he]172-lancelot found [the squire]3125-the squire in a great state of excitement . [A large gang of poachers]4005-a large gang of poachers , who had come down from [London]46-london by rail , had been devastating all the covers round , to stock [the [London]46-london markets]4006-the london markets by the first of October , and intended , as [Tregarva]173-tregarva had discovered , to pay [Mr. Lavington]276-mr. lavington ’s preserves a visit that night . [They]4005-a large gang of poachers did n’t care for [country justices]4007-country justices , not [they]4005-a large gang of poachers . Were n’t all [their]4005-a large gang of poachers fines paid by [highly respectable game - dealers at [the West end]4009-the west end]4008-highly respectable game - dealers at the west end ? [They]4005-a large gang of poachers owned three dog - carts among [them]4005-a large gang of poachers ; a parcel by [railway]4010-railway would bring [them]4005-a large gang of poachers down bail to any amount ; [they]4005-a large gang of poachers tossed [their]4005-a large gang of poachers money away at [the public - houses]4011-the public - houses , like [gentlemen]780-gentlemen ; thanks to the Game Laws , [their]4005-a large gang of poachers profits ran high , and when [they]4005-a large gang of poachers had swept [the country]976-the country pretty clean of game , why , [they]4005-a large gang of poachers would just finish off the season by a stray highway robbery or two , and vanish into [Babylon]62-babylon and [their]4005-a large gang of poachers native night . Such was [Harry Verney]174-old harry ’s information as [he]174-old harry strutted about [the courtyard]4014-the courtyard waiting for [the squire]3125-the squire ’s orders . ‘[1606-they] But [they]1606-they ’ve put [their]1606-they nose into a furze - bush , [Muster Smith]295-muster smith , [they]1606-they have . [We]1607-we ’ve got [[our]1607-we posse - commontaturs]1608-our posse - commontaturs , [fourteen men]1609-fourteen men , [sir]753-sir , as’ll play the whole vale to cricket , and whap [them]1606-they ; and every one’ll fight , for [they]1606-they ’re half [poachers]4016-poachers [themselves]1606-they , [you]753-sir see ’[174-old harry] ( and [Harry]174-old harry winked and chuckled ) ; ‘ and [they]1606-they ca n’t abide [no interlopers]4017-no interlopers to come down and take the sport out of [their]1606-they mouths . ’[1606-they] ‘ But are [you]174-old harry sure [they]1606-they ’ll come to - night ? ’[174-old harry] ‘ That ’[1606-they] ere [Paul]173-tregarva says so . [They]4024-these keepers always fight better with [a gentleman among [them]4024-these keepers]4025-a gentleman among them . Breeding tells , [you]295-muster smith know — breeding tells . ’[3125-the squire] [Lancelot]172-lancelot felt a strong disgust at the occupation , but [he]172-lancelot was under too many obligations to [the squire]3125-the squire to refuse . ‘ Ay , [I]3135-the old man knew [you]295-muster smith were game , ’[3135-the old man] said [the old man]3135-the old man . ‘ And [you]295-muster smith ’ll find it capital fun . [I]3135-the old man used to think it so , [I]3135-the old man know , when [I]3135-the old man was young . [Many a shindy]4026-many a shindy have [I]3135-the old man had here in [[my]3135-the old man uncle]653-my uncle ’s time , under the very windows , before the chase was disparked , when [the fellows]4028-the fellows used to come down after the deer . ’[3135-the old man] Just then [Lancelot]172-lancelot turned and saw [Argemone]150-argemone standing close to [him]172-lancelot . [He]172-lancelot almost sprang towards [her]150-argemone — and retreated , for [he]172-lancelot saw that [she]150-argemone had overheard the conversation between [him]172-lancelot and [[her]150-argemone father]3219-her father . ‘ What ! [Women]3246-women will be tender - hearted , [you]172-lancelot know . Quite right — but [they]3246-women do n’t understand these things . [They]3246-women fight with [their]3246-women tongues , and [we]4031-we with [our]4031-we fists ; and then [they]3246-women fancy [their]3246-women weapons do n’t hurt — Ha ! ha ! ha ! ’[3125-the squire] ‘ [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith , ’[150-argemone] said [Argemone]150-argemone , in a low , determined voice , ‘ if [you]137-mr. smith have promised [[my]150-argemone father]3846-my father to go on this horrid business — go . But promise [me]150-argemone , too , that [you]137-mr. smith will only look on , or [I]150-argemone will never — ’[150-argemone] [Argemone]150-argemone had not time to finish [her]150-argemone sentence before [Lancelot]172-lancelot had promised seven times over , and meant to keep [his]172-lancelot promise , as [we]1616-we all do . About ten o’clock that evening [Lancelot]172-lancelot and [Tregarva]173-tregarva were walking stealthily up a ride in [one of [the home - covers]1618-the home - covers]1617-one of the home - covers , at the head of [some fifteen fine young fellows]1619-some fifteen fine young fellows , [keepers]3523-keepers , [grooms]3842-grooms , and [not extempore ‘ watchers]4033-not extempore ‘ watchers , ’[1619-some fifteen fine young fellows] whom [old Harry]174-old harry was marshalling and tutoring , with exhortations as many and as animated as if [their]1619-some fifteen fine young fellows ambition was ‘ Mourir pour la patrie . ’[173-tregarva] ‘ How does this sort of work suit [you]137-mr. smith , [Tregarva]173-tregarva , for [I]173-tregarva do n’t like it at all ! The fighting ’s all very well , but it ’s a poor cause . ’[173-tregarva] ‘ Oh , [sir]753-sir , [I]173-tregarva have no mercy on [these Londoners]4035-these londoners . If it was [these poor half - starved labourers]4036-these poor half - starved labourers , that snare the same hares that have been eating up [their]4036-these poor half - starved labourers garden - stuff all the week , [I]173-tregarva ca n’t touch [them]4036-these poor half - starved labourers , [sir]753-sir , and that ’s truth ; but [these ruffians]4038-these ruffians — And yet , [sir]753-sir , would n’t it be better for [the parsons]3377-the parsons to preach to [them]4038-these ruffians , than for [the keepers]726-the keepers to break [their]4038-these ruffians heads ? ’[173-tregarva] ‘ Oh ? ’[172-lancelot] said [Lancelot]172-lancelot , ‘ [the parsons]3377-the parsons say all to [them]4038-these ruffians that [they]4038-these ruffians can . ’[172-lancelot] [Tregarva]173-tregarva shook [his]173-tregarva head . ‘ [I]173-tregarva doubt that , [sir]753-sir . But , no doubt , there ’s a great change for the better in [the parsons]3377-the parsons . [I]173-tregarva remember the time , [sir]753-sir , that there was n’t [an earnest clergyman]4046-an earnest clergyman in [the vale]518-the vale ; and now [every other man [you]753-sir meet]4048-every other man you meet is trying to do [his]4048-every other man you meet best . But [those London parsons]4049-those london parsons , [sir]753-sir , what ’s the matter with [them]4049-those london parsons ? For all [their]4049-those london parsons societies and [[their]4049-those london parsons schools]4051-their schools , [the devil]600-the devil seems to keep ahead of [them]4049-those london parsons sadly . [I]173-tregarva doubt [they]4049-those london parsons have n’t found the right fly yet for [publicans]4053-publicans and [sinners]4054-sinners to rise at . ’[173-tregarva] A distant shot in the cover . ‘ There [they]4049-those london parsons are , [sir]753-sir . [I]173-tregarva thought that [Crawy]177-crawy would n’t lead [me]173-tregarva false when [I]173-tregarva let [him]177-crawy off . ’[173-tregarva] ‘ Well , fight away , then , and win . [I]3125-the squire have promised [Miss Lavington]189-miss lavington not to lift a hand in the business . ’[3125-the squire] ‘ Then [you]753-sir ’re[173-tregarva] [a lucky man]1622-a lucky man , [sir]753-sir . But [the squire]3125-the squire ’s game is [his]3125-the squire own , and [we]1625-our must do [our]1625-our duty by [[our]1625-our master]1626-our master . ’ There was a rustle in the bushes , and a tramp of feet on the turf . ‘[1626-our master] There [they]1627-they are , [sir]753-sir , sure enough . [The Lord]817-the lord keep [us]1625-our from murder this night ! ’ And [Tregarva]173-tregarva pulled off [his]173-tregarva neckcloth , and shook [his]173-tregarva huge limbs , as if to feel that [they]1627-they were all in [their]1627-they places , in a way that augured ill for [the man who came across [him]173-tregarva]4056-the man who came across him . [They]1627-they turned the corner of [a ride]4057-a ride , and , in an instant , found [themselves]1627-they face to face with [five or six armed men]4058-five or six armed men , with blackened faces , who , without speaking a word , dashed at [them]1627-they , and the fight began ; [reinforcements]4059-reinforcements came up on each side , and the engagement became general . ‘[817-the lord] [The forest - laws]1630-the forest - laws were sharp and stern , The forest blood was keen , [They]1627-they lashed together for life and death Beneath the hollies green . ‘ The metal good and the walnut - wood Did soon in splinters flee ; [They]1627-they tossed the orts to south and north , And grappled knee to knee . ‘[1627-they] [They]1627-they wrestled up , [they]1627-they wrestled down , [They]1627-they wrestled still and sore ; The herbage sweet beneath [their]1627-they feet Was stamped to mud and gore . ’ And all the while the broad still moon stared down on [them]1627-they grim and cold , as if with a saturnine sneer at the whole humbug ; and the silly birds about whom all this butchery went on , slept quietly over [their]1627-they heads , every one with [his]173-tregarva head under [his]173-tregarva wing . Oh ! if pheasants had but understanding , how [they]1627-they would split [their]1627-they sides with chuckling and crowing at the follies which civilised [Christian men]4060-christian men perpetrate for [their]4060-christian men precious sake ! Had [I]1633-i the pen of [Homer]213-homer ( though [they]1627-they say [he]213-homer never used one ) , or even that of [the worthy who wasted precious years in writing a Homer Burlesqued]4061-the worthy who wasted precious years in writing a homer burlesqued , what heroic exploits might not [I]1633-i immortalise ! In [every stupid serf and cunning ruffian there]4062-every stupid serf and cunning ruffian there , there was a heart as brave as [Ajax]296-ajax ’s own ; but then [they]1627-they fought with sticks instead of lances , and hammered away on fustian jackets instead of brazen shields ; and , therefore , [poor fellows]4063-poor fellows , [they]1627-they were beneath ‘[1633-i] the dignity of poetry , ’ whatever that may mean . If one of [your]4064-your squeamish ‘[1633-i] dignity - of - poetry ’ critics had just had [his]173-tregarva head among the gun - stocks for five minutes that night , [he]173-tregarva would have found it grim tragic earnest enough ; not without a touch of fun though , here and there . [Lancelot]172-lancelot leant against a tree and watched [the riot with folded arms]4065-the riot with folded arms , mindful of [his]172-lancelot promise to [Argemone]150-argemone , and envied [Tregarva]173-tregarva as [he]172-lancelot hurled [[his]172-lancelot assailants]4066-his assailants right and left with immense strength , and led the van of battle royally . Little would [Argemone]150-argemone have valued the real proof of love which [he]172-lancelot was giving [her]150-argemone as [he]172-lancelot looked on sulkily , while [his]172-lancelot fingers tingled with longing to be up and doing . Strange — that mere lust of fighting , common to [man]564-man and animals , whose traces [even the lamb]4068-even the lamb and [the civilised child]4069-the civilised child evince in [their]1627-they mock - fights , the earliest and most natural form of play . Is it , after all , the one human propensity which is utterly evil , incapable of being turned to any righteous use ? Gross and animal , no doubt it is , but not the less really pleasant , as [every Irishman]4070-every irishman and [many an Englishman]4071-many an englishman knows well enough . A curious instance of this , by the bye , occurred in [Paris]63-paris during the February Revolution . [A fat English coachman]4072-a fat english coachman went out , from mere curiosity , to see the fighting . As [he]4072-a fat english coachman stood and watched , a new passion crept over [him]4072-a fat english coachman ; [he]4072-a fat english coachman grew madder and madder as the bullets whistled past [him]4072-a fat english coachman ; at last , when [men]612-men began to drop by [his]4072-a fat english coachman side , [he]4072-a fat english coachman could stand it no longer , seized a musket , and rushed in , careless which side [he]4072-a fat english coachman took , — ‘[1633-i] To drink delight of battle with [[his]1631-his peers]1632-his peers . ’ [He]4072-a fat english coachman was not heard of for a day or two , and then [they]612-men found [him]4072-a fat english coachman stiff and cold , lying on [his]4072-a fat english coachman face across a barricade , with a bullet through [his]4072-a fat english coachman heart . [Sedentary persons]4074-sedentary persons may call [him]4072-a fat english coachman [a sinful fool]4075-a sinful fool . Be it so . Homo sum : humani nihil à [me]1633-i alienum puto . [Lancelot]172-lancelot , [I]1633-i verily believe , would have kept [his]172-lancelot promise , though [he]172-lancelot saw that [the keepers]726-the keepers gave ground , finding [Cockney]297-cockney skill too much for [their]726-the keepers clumsy strength ; but at last [Harry Verney]174-old harry , who had been fighting as venomously as a wild cat , and had been once before saved from a broken skull by [Tregarva]173-tregarva , rolled over at [his]4072-a fat english coachman very feet with a couple of poachers on [him]4072-a fat english coachman . ‘[1633-i] [You]1633-i wo n’t see [an old man]1634-an old man murdered , [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith ? ’ cried [he]4072-a fat english coachman , imploringly . [Lancelot]172-lancelot tore the ruffians off [the old man]3135-the old man right and left . [One of [them]4079-them]4078-one of them struck [him]172-lancelot ; [he]172-lancelot returned the blow ; and , in an instant , promises and [Argemone]150-argemone , philosophy and anti - game - law prejudices , were swept out of [his]172-lancelot head , and ‘[1634-an old man] [he]1634-an old man went , ’ as [the old romances]4080-the old romances say , ‘[1634-an old man] hurling into the midst of the press , ’ as mere a wild animal for the moment as angry bull or boar . An instant afterwards , though , [he]172-lancelot burst out laughing , in spite of [himself]172-lancelot , as ‘[1634-an old man] [The Battersea Bantam]298-the battersea bantam , ’ who had been ineffectually dancing round [Tregarva]173-tregarva like a gamecock spurring at a bull , turned off with a voice of ineffable disgust , — ‘[298-the battersea bantam] That big cove ’s a yokel ; ta’nt creditable to waste science on [him]1634-an old man . [You]1633-i ’re [[my]298-the battersea bantam man]3527-my man , if [you]753-sir please , [sir,’—and the little wiry lump of courage and conceit , rascality and good humour]4082-sir,’—and the little wiry lump of courage and conceit , rascality and good humour , flew at [Lancelot]172-lancelot , who was twice [his]172-lancelot size , ‘[298-the battersea bantam] with a heroism worthy of a better cause , ’ as respectable papers , when [they]4083-they are not too frightened , say of [the French]267-french revolutions . * * * * * ‘[1633-i] Do [you]1633-i want any more ? ’ asked [Lancelot]172-lancelot . ‘[753-sir] Quite a pleasure , [sir]753-sir , to meet [a scientific gen’lman]1636-a scientific gen’lman . Beg [your]753-sir pardon , [sir]753-sir ; stay a moment while [I]0-i wipes [my]0-i face . Now , [sir]753-sir , time , if [you]753-sir please . ’ Alas for [the little man]4084-the little man ! in another moment [he]4084-the little man tumbled over and lay senseless — [Lancelot]172-lancelot thought [he]172-lancelot had killed [him]4084-the little man . [The gang]4085-the gang saw [[their]4085-the gang champion]4086-their champion fall , gave ground , and limped off , leaving [three of [[their]4085-the gang party]4088-their party groaning on the ground , beside as many [Whitford men]4089-whitford men]4087-three of their party groaning on the ground , beside as many whitford men . As it was in the beginning , so is it to be to the end , [[my]753-sir foolish brothers]4090-my foolish brothers ! From [the poacher]4091-the poacher to [the prime minister]4092-the prime minister — wearying [yourselves]4090-my foolish brothers for very vanity ! [The soldier]3436-the soldier is not [the only man in [England]3-england who is fool enough to be shot at for a shilling a day]4094-the only man in england who is fool enough to be shot at for a shilling a day . But while [all the rest]4095-all the rest were busy picking up [the wounded men]4096-the wounded men and securing [the prisoners]4097-the prisoners , [Harry Verney]174-old harry alone held on , and as [the poachers]4098-the poachers retreated slowly up [the ride]4099-the ride , [he]174-old harry followed [them]4098-the poachers , peering into the gloom , as if in hopes of recognising [some old enemy]4100-some old enemy . ‘[753-sir] Stand back , [Harry Verney]174-old harry ; [we]1639-we know [you]174-old harry , and [we]1639-we ’d be loth to harm [an old man]1634-an old man , ’ cried a voice out of the darkness . ‘[1639-we] Eh ? Do [you]174-old harry think [old Harry’d]299-old harry’d turn back when [he]1634-an old man was once on the track of [ye]174-old harry ? [[You]174-old harry soft - fisted , gin - drinking , counter - skipping [Cockney rascals]1642-cockney rascals]1641-you soft - fisted , gin - drinking , counter - skipping cockney rascals , that fancy [you]174-old harry ’re to carry [the county]4101-the county before [you]174-old harry , because [you]174-old harry get [your]174-old harry fines paid by [[London]46-london - tradesmen]4102-london - tradesmen ! What do [you]174-old harry take [old Harry]174-old harry for ? ’[174-old harry] ‘ Go back , [[you]174-old harry old fool]4103-you old fool ! ’[3135-the old man] and a volley of oaths followed . ‘ If [you]174-old harry follow [us]1644-us , [we]1644-us ’ll fire at [you]174-old harry , as sure as the moon ’s in [heaven]1101-heaven ! ’[3135-the old man] ‘ Fire away , then ! [Tregarva]173-tregarva saw [his]173-tregarva danger and sprang forward , but it was too late . ‘ What , [you]174-old harry will have it , then ? ’[173-tregarva] A sharp crack followed,—a bright flash in the darkness — every white birch - stem and jagged oak - leaf shone out for a moment as bright as day — and in front of the glare [Lancelot]172-lancelot saw [the old man]3135-the old man throw [his]3135-the old man arms wildly upward , fall forward , and disappear on the dark ground . ‘ [You]174-old harry ’ve done it ! off with [you]174-old harry ! ’[1646-the rascals] And [the rascals]1646-the rascals rushed off up [the ride]4099-the ride . [Old Harry]174-old harry ’s got [his]3135-the old man gruel . [He]174-old harry ’s heard [his]3135-the old man last shot fired . [I]173-tregarva knowed it ’[173-tregarva] ud come to this , and [I]0-i said it . Eh ? Did n’t [I]0-i , now , [Paul]173-tregarva ? ’ And as [the old man]3135-the old man spoke , the workings of [his]3135-the old man lungs pumped great jets of blood out over the still heather - flowers as [they]612-men slept in the moonshine , and dabbled [them]612-men with smoking gore . ‘[173-tregarva] Here , [men]612-men , ’ shouted [the colonel]504-the colonel , ‘[173-tregarva] up with [him]3135-the old man at once , and [home]452-home ! Here , put a brace of [your]612-men guns together , muzzle and lock . Help [him]3135-the old man to sit on them , [Lancelot]172-lancelot . Now then , [men]612-men , left legs foremost — keep step — march ! ’ And [they]612-men moved off towards [the Priory]64-the priory . ‘[1652-you] [You]1652-you seem to know everything , [colonel]530-colonel , ’ said [Lancelot]172-lancelot . [The colonel]504-the colonel did not answer for a moment . ‘[1652-you] [Lancelot]172-lancelot , [I]0-i learnt this dodge from [the only friend [I]0-i ever had in [the world]475-the world]1654-the only friend i ever had in the world , or ever shall have ; and a week after [I]0-i marched [him]3135-the old man [home]452-home to [his]3135-the old man deathbed in this very way . ’ ‘[173-tregarva] [Paul]173-tregarva — [Paul Tregarva]173-tregarva , ’ whispered [old Harry]174-old harry , ‘[173-tregarva] put [your]173-tregarva head down here : wipe [my]0-i mouth , there ’s [a man]445-a man ; it ’s wet , uncommon wet . ’ It was [his]0-i own life - blood . ‘[445-a man] [I]0-i ’ve been a beast to [you]173-tregarva , [Paul]173-tregarva . [I]0-i ’ve hated [you]173-tregarva , and envied [you]173-tregarva , and tried to ruin [you]173-tregarva . But [you]173-tregarva dropped a song , [Paul]173-tregarva , a bit of writing . ’ [Paul]173-tregarva turned pale . ‘[173-tregarva] And — [the Lord]817-the lord forgive me!—I put it in [the squire]3125-the squire ’s fly - book . ’ ‘[817-the lord] [The Lord]817-the lord forgive [you]173-tregarva ! Amen ! ’ said [Paul]173-tregarva , solemnly . Wearily and slowly [they]4108-they stepped on towards [[the old man]3135-the old man ’s cottage]4110-the old man ’s cottage . [A messenger]4111-a messenger had gone on before , and in a few minutes [the squire]3125-the squire , [Mrs. Lavington]158-mrs. lavington , and [the girls]4113-the girls , were round the bed of [[their]4108-they old retainer]4114-their old retainer . [They]4108-they sent off right and left for [the doctor]4115-the doctor and [the vicar]3366-the vicar ; [the squire]3125-the squire was in a frenzy of rage and grief . ‘[817-the lord] Do n’t take on , [master]1667-master , do n’t take on , ’ said [old Harry]174-old harry , as [he]174-old harry lay ; while [the colonel]504-the colonel and [Honoria]162-honoria in vain endeavoured to stanch the wound . ‘[1667-master] [I]0-i knowed it would be so , sooner or later ; ’ tis all in the way of business . [They]4108-they have n’t carried off a bird , [squire]588-squire , not a bird ; [we]4108-they was too many for ’em[173-tregarva] — eh , [Paul]173-tregarva , eh ? ’ ‘[173-tregarva] Where is [that cursed doctor]1668-that cursed doctor ? ’ said [the squire]3125-the squire . ‘[530-colonel] Save [him]1668-that cursed doctor , [colonel]530-colonel , save [him]1668-that cursed doctor ; and [I]0-i ’ll give [you]530-colonel — ’ Alas ! the charge of shot at a few feet distance had entered like a bullet , tearing a great ragged hole.—There was no hope , and [the colonel]504-the colonel knew it ; but [he]504-the colonel said nothing . ‘[1670-the second keeper] [The second keeper]1670-the second keeper , ’ sighed [Argemone]150-argemone , ‘[1670-the second keeper] who has been killed [here]775-here ! Oh , [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith , must this be ? Is [God]281-god ’s blessing on all this ? ’ [Lancelot]172-lancelot said nothing . [The old man]3135-the old man lighted up at [Argemone]150-argemone ’s voice . ‘[281-god] There ’s the beauty , there ’s the pride of [Whitford]7-whitford . And [sweet Miss Honor]162-honoria , too,—so kind to nurse [a poor old man]1672-a poor old man ! But [she]162-honoria never would let [him]1672-a poor old man teach [her]162-honoria to catch perch , would [she]162-honoria ? [She]162-honoria was always too tender - hearted . Ah , [squire]588-squire , when [we]1674-we ’re dead and gone,—dead and gone,—squire , [they]4123-they ’ll be the pride of [Whitford]7-whitford still ! And [they]4123-they ’ll keep up [the old place]4124-the old place — won’t [you]588-squire , [[my]150-argemone darlings]4125-my darlings ? And the old name , too ! For , [you]588-squire know , there must always be a [Lavington]276-mr. lavington in [Whitford]7-whitford Priors , till [the Nun]300-the nun ’s pool runs up to [Ashy Down]66-ashy down . ’[150-argemone] ‘ And a curse upon [the Lavingtons]248-the lavingtons , ’[150-argemone] sighed [Argemone]150-argemone to [herself]150-argemone in an undertone . [Lancelot]172-lancelot heard what [she]150-argemone said . [The vicar]3366-the vicar entered , but [he]3366-the vicar was too late . [The old man]3135-the old man ’s strength was failing , and [his]3135-the old man mind began to wander . ‘ [Windy]301-windy , ’[3135-the old man] [he]3135-the old man murmured to [himself]3135-the old man , ‘ windy , dark and windy — birds wo n’t lie — not old [Harry]174-old harry ’s fault . How black it grows ! [We]4126-we must be gone by nightfall , [squire]588-squire . Where ’s that young dog gone ? [Arter the larks]302-arter the larks , [the brute]4128-the brute . ’[3135-the old man] [Old Squire Lavington]136-squire lavington sobbed like [a child]3467-a child . ‘ [You]3135-the old man will soon be [home]452-home , [[my]3366-the vicar man]3527-my man , ’[3366-the vicar] said [the vicar]3366-the vicar . ‘ Remember that [you]3135-the old man have [a Saviour]4131-a saviour in [heaven]1101-heaven . Cast [yourself]3135-the old man on [His]4131-a saviour mercy . ’[3366-the vicar] [Harry]174-old harry shook [his]174-old harry head . ‘ Very good words , [very kind,—very heavy gamebag]4133-very kind,—very heavy gamebag , though . Come [you]173-tregarva here , [Paul Tregarva]173-tregarva . ’[174-old harry] [He]174-old harry pulled [Tregarva]173-tregarva ’s face down to [his]174-old harry own , and whispered , — ‘ [Them]4139-them ’s the bells a - ringing for [Miss Honor]162-honoria ’s wedding . ’[174-old harry] [Paul]173-tregarva started and drew back . [Harry]174-old harry chuckled and grinned for a moment in [his]174-old harry old foxy , peering way , and then wandered off again . ‘ What ’s that thumping and roaring ? ’[174-old harry] Alas ! it was the failing pulsation of [his]174-old harry own heart . ‘ It ’s the weir , the weir — a - washing [me]174-old harry away — thundering over me.—Squire , [I]174-old harry ’m[174-old harry] drowning,—drowning and choking ! Oh , [Lord]1679-lord , how deep ! Now it ’s running quieter — now [I]0-i can breathe again — swift and oily — running on , running on , down to [the sea]636-the sea . See how the grayling sparkle ! There ’s a pike ! ’ Tain’t [my]174-old harry fault , [squire]588-squire , so help [me]174-old harry — Don’t swear , now , [squire]588-squire ; [old men]4142-old men and [dying maun’t]4143-dying maun’t swear , [squire]588-squire . How steady [the river]505-the river runs down ? Lower and slower — lower and slower : now it ’s quite still — still — still — ’[174-old harry] [His]174-old harry voice sank away — [he]174-old harry was dead ! No ! once more the light flashed up in the socket . [He]174-old harry sprang upright in the bed , and held out [his]174-old harry withered paw with a kind of wild majesty , as [he]174-old harry shouted , — ‘ There ai n’t [such a head of hares on [any manor in [the county]4101-the county]4147-any manor in the county]4146-such a head of hares on any manor in the county . And [them]4149-them ’s the last words of [Harry Verney]174-old harry ! ’[174-old harry] [He]174-old harry fell back — shuddered — a rattle in [his]174-old harry throat — another — and all was over . [Argemone]150-argemone need never have known of [Lancelot]172-lancelot ’s share in the poaching affray ; but [he]174-old harry dared not conceal anything from [her]150-argemone . And so [he]174-old harry boldly went up the next day to [the Priory]534-the priory , not to beg pardon , but to justify [himself]174-old harry , and succeeded . And , before long , [he]174-old harry found [himself]174-old harry fairly installed as [[her]150-argemone pupil]1682-her pupil , nominally in spiritual matters , but really in subjects of which [she]150-argemone little dreamed . Every day [he]174-old harry came to read and talk with [her]150-argemone , and whatever objections [Mrs. Lavington]158-mrs. lavington expressed were silenced by [Argemone]150-argemone . [She]150-argemone would have it so , and [[her]150-argemone mother]1404-her mother neither dared nor knew how to control [her]150-argemone . [The daughter]1684-the daughter had utterly out - read and out - thought [[her]150-argemone less educated parent]1685-her less educated parent , who was clinging in honest bigotry to the old forms , while [Argemone]150-argemone was wandering forth over the chaos of the strange new age,—a poor homeless [Noah]303-noah ’s dove , seeking rest for the sole of [her]150-argemone foot and finding none . And now all motherly influence and sympathy had vanished , and [Mrs. Lavington]158-mrs. lavington , in fear and wonder , let [[her]158-mrs. lavington daughter]1686-her daughter go [her]1686-her daughter own way . [She]150-argemone could not have done better , perhaps ; for [Providence]304-providence had found for [Argemone]150-argemone a better guide than [[her]150-argemone mother]1404-her mother could have done , and [[her]150-argemone new pupil]1688-her new pupil was rapidly becoming [[her]150-argemone teacher]1689-her teacher . [She]150-argemone was matched , for the first time , with [a man who was [her]150-argemone own equal in intellect and knowledge]1690-a man who was her own equal in intellect and knowledge ; and [she]150-argemone felt how real was that sexual difference which [she]150-argemone had been accustomed to consider as an insolent calumny against [woman]458-woman . Proudly and indignantly [she]150-argemone struggled against the conviction , but in vain . Again and again [she]150-argemone argued with [him]1690-a man who was her own equal in intellect and knowledge , and was vanquished,—or , at least , what is far better , made to see how many different sides there are to every question . All appeals to authority [he]1690-a man who was her own equal in intellect and knowledge answered with a contemptuous smile . ‘ [The best authorities]4150-the best authorities ? ’[1690-a man who was her own equal in intellect and knowledge] [he]1690-a man who was her own equal in intellect and knowledge used to say . ‘ On what question do [not the best authorities]4151-not the best authorities flatly contradict [each other]565-each other ? And why ? Because [every man]3304-every man believes just what it suits [him]3304-every man to believe . Do n’t fancy that [men]612-men reason [themselves]612-men into convictions ; the prejudices and feelings of [their]612-men hearts give [them]612-men some idea or theory , and then [they]612-men find facts at [their]612-men leisure to prove [their]612-men theory true . [Every man]3304-every man sees facts through narrow spectacles , red , or green , or blue , as [[his]3304-every man nation]4156-his nation or [his]3304-every man temperament colours [them]4157-them : and [he]3304-every man is quite right , only [he]3304-every man must allow [us]4158-our the liberty of having [our]4158-our spectacles too . Authority is only good for proving facts . [We]4158-our must draw [our]4158-our own conclusions . ’[1690-a man who was her own equal in intellect and knowledge] And [Argemone]150-argemone began to suspect that [he]1692-his was right,—at least to see that [her]150-argemone opinions were mere hearsays , picked up at [her]150-argemone own will and fancy ; while [his]1692-his were living , daily - growing ideas . [Her]150-argemone mind was beside [his]1692-his as the vase of cut flowers by the side of the rugged tree , whose roots are feeding deep in [the mother earth]1693-the mother earth . In [him]1692-his [she]150-argemone first learnt how one great truth received into the depths of the soul germinates there , and bears fruit a thousandfold ; explaining , and connecting , and glorifying innumerable things , apparently the most unlike and insignificant ; and daily [she]150-argemone became [a more reverent listener]1694-a more reverent listener , and gave [herself]150-argemone up , half against [her]150-argemone will and conscience , to the guidance of [a man whom [she]150-argemone knew to be [her]150-argemone inferior in morals and in orthodoxy]1695-a man whom she knew to be her inferior in morals and in orthodoxy . [She]150-argemone had worshipped intellect , and now it had become [her]150-argemone tyrant ; and [she]150-argemone was ready to give up every belief which [she]150-argemone once had prized , to flutter like a moth round its fascinating brilliance . Who can blame [her]150-argemone , [poor girl]1696-poor girl ? For [Lancelot]172-lancelot ’s humility was even more irresistible than [his]172-lancelot eloquence . [He]172-lancelot assumed no superiority . [He]172-lancelot demanded [her]150-argemone assent to truths , not because they were [his]172-lancelot opinions , but simply for the truth ’s sake ; and on all points which touched the heart [he]172-lancelot looked up to [her]150-argemone as infallible and inspired . In questions of morality , of taste , of feeling , [he]172-lancelot listened not as [a lover]1697-a lover to [[his]172-lancelot mistress]1698-his mistress , but rather as [a baby]3501-a baby to [its mother]1700-its mother ; and thus , half unconsciously to [himself]172-lancelot , [he]172-lancelot taught [her]150-argemone where [her]150-argemone true kingdom lay,—that the heart , and not the brain , enshrines the priceless pearl of womanhood , the oracular jewel , the ‘ Urim and Thummim , ’[172-lancelot] before which [gross man]1701-gross man can only inquire and adore . And , in the meantime , a change was passing upon [Lancelot]172-lancelot . [His]172-lancelot morbid vanity — that [brawl - begotten child of struggling self - conceit and self - disgust]1702-brawl - begotten child of struggling self - conceit and self - disgust — was vanishing away ; and as [Mr. Tennyson]163-mr. tennyson says in one of those priceless idyls of [his]163-mr. tennyson , before which the shade of [Theocritus]305-theocritus must hide [his]172-lancelot diminished head , — ‘ [He]172-lancelot was altered , and began To move about [the house]3485-the house with joy , And with the certain step of [man]564-man . ’[172-lancelot] [He]172-lancelot had , at last , found [one person who could appreciate [him]172-lancelot]1703-one person who could appreciate him . And in deliberate confidence [he]172-lancelot set to work to conquer [her]150-argemone , and make [her]150-argemone [his]172-lancelot own . It was a traitorous return , but a very natural one . And [she]150-argemone , sweet creature ! walked straight into the pleasant snare , utterly blind , because [she]150-argemone fancied that [she]150-argemone saw clearly . In the pride of [her]150-argemone mysticism , [she]150-argemone had fancied [herself]150-argemone above so commonplace a passion as love . It was a curious feature of lower humanity , which [she]150-argemone might investigate and analyse harmlessly as [a cold scientific spectator]1704-a cold scientific spectator ; and , in [her]150-argemone mingled pride and purity , [she]150-argemone used to indulge [Lancelot]172-lancelot in metaphysical disquisitions about love and beauty , like that first one in [their]1705-their walk [home]452-home from [Minchampstead]39-minchampstead , from which a less celestially innocent soul would have shrunk . [She]150-argemone thought , forsooth , as the old proverb says , that [she]150-argemone could deal in honey , without putting [her]150-argemone hand to [her]150-argemone mouth . But [Lancelot]172-lancelot knew better , and marked [her]150-argemone for [his]172-lancelot own . And daily [his]172-lancelot self - confidence and sense of rightful power developed , and with [them]1707-them , paradoxical as it may seem , the bitterest self - abasement . The contact of [her]150-argemone stainless innocence , the growing certainty that the destiny of that innocence was irrevocably bound up with [his]172-lancelot own , made [him]172-lancelot shrink from [her]150-argemone whenever [he]172-lancelot remembered [his]172-lancelot own guilty career . To remember that there were passages in it which [she]150-argemone must never know — that [she]150-argemone would cast [him]172-lancelot from [her]150-argemone with abhorrence if [she]150-argemone once really understood [their]1708-their vileness ? To think that , amid all the closest bonds of love , there must for ever be an awful , silent gulf in the past , of which [they]1708-their must never speak!—That [she]150-argemone would bring to [him]172-lancelot what [he]172-lancelot could never , never bring to her!—The thought was unbearable . And as hideous recollections used to rise before [him]172-lancelot , devilish caricatures of [[his]172-lancelot former self]1709-his former self , mopping and mowing at [him]172-lancelot in [his]172-lancelot dreams , [he]172-lancelot would start from [his]172-lancelot lonely bed , and pace [the room]3190-the room for hours , or saddle [his]172-lancelot horse , and ride all night long aimlessly through [the awful woods]1711-the awful woods , vainly trying to escape [himself]172-lancelot . How gladly , at those moments , [he]172-lancelot would have welcomed centuries of a material hell , to escape from the more awful spiritual hell within [him,—to]1712-him,—to buy back that pearl of innocence which [he]172-lancelot had cast recklessly to be trampled under the feet of [his]172-lancelot own swinish passions ! But , no ; that which was done could never be undone,—never , to all eternity . And more than once , as [he]172-lancelot wandered restlessly from [one room]1713-one room to another , the barrels of [his]172-lancelot pistols seemed to glitter with a cold , devilish smile , and call to [him]172-lancelot , — ‘ Come to [us]4161-us ! and with one touch of [your]172-lancelot finger , send that bursting spirit which throbs against [your]172-lancelot brow to flit forth free , and nevermore to defile [her]1714-her purity by [your]172-lancelot presence ! ’[172-lancelot] But no , again : a voice within seemed to command [him]172-lancelot to go on , and claim [her]1714-her , and win [her]1714-her , spite of [his]172-lancelot own vileness . And in after years , slowly , and in fear and trembling , [he]172-lancelot knew it for the voice of [God]281-god , who had been leading [him]172-lancelot to become worthy of [her]1714-her through that bitter shame of [his]172-lancelot own unworthiness . As One higher than [them]1715-them would have it , [she]1714-her took a fancy to read [Homer]213-homer in the original , and [Lancelot]172-lancelot could do no less than offer [his]172-lancelot services as [translator]1716-translator . [She]1714-her would prepare for [him]172-lancelot portions of the Odyssey , and every day that [he]172-lancelot came up to the Priory [he]172-lancelot used to comment on it to [her]1714-her ; and so for many a week , in [the dark wainscoted library]1717-the dark wainscoted library , and in [the clipt yew - alleys of [the old gardens]1719-the old gardens]1718-the clipt yew - alleys of the old gardens , and under the brown autumn trees , [they]1715-them quarried together in [that unexhausted mine]1720-that unexhausted mine , among the records of [the rich Titan - youth of man]1721-the rich titan - youth of man . And step by step [Lancelot]172-lancelot opened to [her]1714-her the everlasting significance of the poem ; the unconscious purity which lingers in it , like the last rays of the Paradise dawn ; its sense of the dignity of [man]564-man as [man]564-man ; the religious reverence with which it speaks of all human ties , human strength and beauty — ay , even of merely animal human appetites , as [God]281-god - given and Godlike symbols . [She]1714-her could not but listen and admire , when [he]172-lancelot introduced [her]1714-her to the sheer paganism of [[Schiller]190-schiller ’s Gods of [Greece]67-greece]1724-schiller ’s gods of greece ; for on this subject [he]172-lancelot was more eloquent than on any . [He]172-lancelot had gradually , in fact , as [we]1725-we have seen , dropped all faith in anything but Nature ; the slightest fact about a bone or a weed was more important to [him]172-lancelot than all the books of divinity which [Argemone]150-argemone lent [him]172-lancelot — to be laid by unread . ‘ What do [you]172-lancelot believe in ? ’[1714-her] [she]1714-her asked [him]172-lancelot one day , sadly . ‘ In this ! ’[172-lancelot] [he]172-lancelot said , stamping [his]172-lancelot foot on the ground . ‘ In [the earth]866-the earth [I]172-lancelot stand on , and the things [I]172-lancelot see walking and growing on it . There may be something beside it — what [you]4163-you call [a spiritual world]4164-a spiritual world . But if [He]172-lancelot who made [me]172-lancelot intended [me]172-lancelot to think of spirit first , [He]172-lancelot would have let [me]172-lancelot see it first . But as [He]172-lancelot has given [me]172-lancelot material senses , and put [me]172-lancelot in [a material world]4165-a material world , [I]172-lancelot take it as a fair hint that [I]172-lancelot am meant to use those senses first , whatever may come after . [I]172-lancelot may be intended to understand [the unseen world]4166-the unseen world , but if so , it must be , as [I]172-lancelot suspect , by understanding the visible one : and there are enough wonders there to occupy [me]172-lancelot for some time to come . ’[172-lancelot] ‘ But the Bible ? ’[150-argemone] ( [Argemone]150-argemone had given up long ago wasting words about the ‘ Church . ’[172-lancelot] ) ‘ [My]150-argemone only Bible as yet is [Bacon]235-bacon . [I]150-argemone know that [he]235-bacon is right , whoever is wrong . If that Hebrew Bible is to be believed by [me]150-argemone , it must agree with what [I]150-argemone know already from science . ’[150-argemone] What was to be done with so intractable [a heretic]1726-a heretic ? Call [him]1726-a heretic [an infidel]1727-an infidel and [a Materialist]1728-a materialist , of course , and cast [him]1726-a heretic off with horror . But [Argemone]150-argemone was beginning to find out that , when [people]3181-people are really in earnest , it may be better sometimes to leave [God]281-god ’s methods of educating [them]3181-people alone , instead of calling [the poor honest seekers]1730-the poor honest seekers hard names , which [the speakers themselves]1731-the speakers themselves do n’t understand . But words would fail sometimes , and in default of them [Lancelot]172-lancelot had recourse to drawings , and manifested in [them]1732-their a talent for thinking in visible forms which put the climax to all [Argemone]150-argemone ’s wonder . A single profile , even [a mere mathematical figure]1733-a mere mathematical figure , would , in [his]172-lancelot hands , become the illustration of a spiritual truth . And , in time , every fresh lesson on the Odyssey was accompanied by its illustration,—some bold and simple outline drawing . In [Argemone]150-argemone ’s eyes , the sketches were immaculate and inspired ; for [their]1732-their chief , almost [their]1732-their only fault , was just those mere anatomical slips which [a woman]3251-a woman would hardly perceive , provided the forms were generally graceful and bold . One day [his]172-lancelot fancy attempted a bolder flight . [He]172-lancelot brought a large pen - and - ink drawing , and laying it silently on the table before [her]3251-a woman , fixed [his]172-lancelot eyes intensely on [her]3251-a woman face . The sketch was labelled , the ‘ Triumph of [Woman]458-woman . ’[172-lancelot] In the foreground , to the right and left , were scattered groups of [men]612-men , in the dresses and insignia of every period and occupation . The distance showed , in a few bold outlines , [a dreary desert , broken by alpine ridges]1736-a dreary desert , broken by alpine ridges , and furrowed here and there by [a wandering watercourse]1737-a wandering watercourse . Long shadows pointed to the half - risen sun , whose disc was climbing above the waste horizon . And in front of the sun , down the path of the morning beams , came [Woman]306-woman , clothed only in the armour of [her]306-woman own loveliness . [Her]306-woman bearing was stately , and yet modest ; in [her]306-woman face pensive tenderness seemed wedded with earnest joy . In [her]306-woman right hand lay a cross , the emblem of self - sacrifice . [Her]306-woman path across [the desert]1738-the desert was marked by the flowers which sprang up beneath [her]306-woman steps ; [the wild gazelle]1739-the wild gazelle stept forward trustingly to lick [her]306-woman hand ; a single wandering butterfly fluttered round [her]306-woman head . As [the group , one by one]1740-the group , one by one , caught sight of [her]306-woman , a human tenderness and intelligence seemed to light up every face . [The scholar]1741-the scholar dropt [his]1741-the scholar book , [the miser]1742-the miser [his]1741-the scholar gold , [the savage]1743-the savage [his]1741-the scholar weapons ; even in the visage of [the half - slumbering sot some nobler recollection]1744-the half - slumbering sot some nobler recollection seemed wistfully to struggle into life . [The artist]3180-the artist caught up [his]3180-the artist pencil , [the poet]1746-the poet [his]1741-the scholar lyre , with eyes that beamed forth sudden inspiration . [The sage , whose broad brow rose above [the group like some torrent furrowed Alp , scathed with all the temptations]1748-the group like some torrent furrowed alp , scathed with all the temptations and all the sorrows of [his]1747-the sage , whose broad brow rose above the group like some torrent furrowed alp , scathed with all the temptations and all the sorrows of his race race]1747-the sage , whose broad brow rose above the group like some torrent furrowed alp , scathed with all the temptations and all the sorrows of his race , watched with a thoughtful smile that preacher more mighty than [himself]1747-the sage , whose broad brow rose above the group like some torrent furrowed alp , scathed with all the temptations and all the sorrows of his race . [A youth , decked out in the most fantastic fopperies of the middle age]1749-a youth , decked out in the most fantastic fopperies of the middle age , stood with clasped hands and brimming eyes , as remorse and pleasure struggled in [his]1749-a youth , decked out in the most fantastic fopperies of the middle age face ; and as [he]1749-a youth , decked out in the most fantastic fopperies of the middle age looked , the fierce sensual features seemed to melt , and [his]1749-a youth , decked out in the most fantastic fopperies of the middle age flesh came again to [him]1749-a youth , decked out in the most fantastic fopperies of the middle age like the flesh of [a little child]1750-a little child . [The slave]1751-the slave forgot [his]1751-the slave fetters ; [little children]1752-little children clapped [their]1752-little children hands ; and [the toil - worn , stunted , savage woman]1753-the toil - worn , stunted , savage woman sprung forward to kneel at [her]1753-the toil - worn , stunted , savage woman feet , and see [herself]1753-the toil - worn , stunted , savage woman transfigured in that new and divine ideal of [her]1753-the toil - worn , stunted , savage woman sex . Descriptions of drawings are clumsy things at best ; [the reader]576-the reader must fill up the sketch for [himself]576-the reader by the eye of faith . Entranced in wonder and pleasure , [Argemone]150-argemone let [her]150-argemone eyes wander over the drawing . And [her]150-argemone feelings for [Lancelot]172-lancelot amounted almost to worship , as [she]150-argemone apprehended the harmonious unity of the manifold conception,—the rugged boldness of [the groups in front]1755-the groups in front , the soft grandeur of the figure which was the lodestar of all [their]1756-their emotions — the virginal purity of the whole . And when [she]150-argemone fancied that [she]150-argemone traced in those bland aquiline lineaments , and in the crisp ringlets which floated like a cloud down to the knees of the figure , some traces of [her]150-argemone own likeness , a dream of a new destiny flitted before [her,—she]150-argemone blushed to [her]150-argemone very neck ; and as [she]150-argemone bent [her]150-argemone face over the drawing and gazed , [her]150-argemone whole soul seemed to rise into [her]150-argemone eyes , and a single tear dropped upon the paper . [She]150-argemone laid [her]150-argemone hand over it , and then turned hastily away . ‘ [You]150-argemone do not like it ! [I]150-argemone have been too bold,’—said [Lancelot]172-lancelot , fearfully . ‘[150-argemone] Oh , no ! no ! It is so beautiful — so full of deep wisdom ! But — but — [You]150-argemone may leave it . ’ [Lancelot]172-lancelot slipped silently out of [the room]3190-the room , [he]172-lancelot hardly knew why ; and when [he]172-lancelot was gone , [Argemone]150-argemone caught up the drawing , pressed it to [her]150-argemone bosom , covered it with kisses , and hid it , as too precious for any eyes but [her]150-argemone own , in the farthest corner of [her]150-argemone secrétaire . And yet [she]150-argemone fancied that [she]150-argemone was not in love ! [The vicar]3366-the vicar saw the growth of this intimacy with a fast - lengthening face ; for it was very evident that [Argemone]150-argemone could not serve [two masters]4170-two masters so utterly contradictory as [himself]150-argemone and [Lancelot]172-lancelot , and that either [the lover]4171-the lover or [the father - confessor]4172-the father - confessor must speedily resign office . [The vicar]3366-the vicar had had great disadvantages , by the bye , in fulfilling the latter function ; for [his]3366-the vicar visits at [the Priory]534-the priory had been all but forbidden ; and [Argemone]150-argemone ’s ‘[1758-he] spiritual state ’ had been directed by means of a secret correspondence,—a method which [some clergymen]4175-some clergymen , and [some young ladies]4176-some young ladies too , have discovered , in the last few years , to be quite consistent with moral delicacy and filial obedience . [John Bull]234-john bull , like [a stupid fellow]4177-a stupid fellow as [he]234-john bull is , has still [his]234-john bull doubts upon the point ; but [he]234-john bull should remember that though [St. Paul]197-st. paul tells [women]3246-women when [they]3246-women want advice to ask [[their]3246-women husbands]4179-their husbands at [home]452-home , yet if [the poor woman]4181-the poor woman has [no husband]4182-no husband , or , as often happens , [[her]4181-the poor woman husband]4183-her husband ’s advice is unpleasant , to whom is [she]4181-the poor woman to go but to the next best substitute , [her]4181-the poor woman spiritual cicisbeo , or [favourite clergyman]4184-favourite clergyman ? In sad earnest , [neither husband]4185-neither husband nor [parent]4186-parent deserves pity in the immense majority of such cases . [Woman]458-woman will have guidance . It is [her]458-woman delight and glory to be led ; and if [[her]458-woman husband]4183-her husband or [[her]458-woman parents]4189-her parents will not meet the cravings of [her]458-woman intellect , [she]458-woman must go elsewhere to find [a teacher]4190-a teacher , and run into the wildest extravagances of private judgment , in the very hope of getting rid of it , just as [poor Argemone]150-argemone had been led to do . And , indeed , [she]458-woman had , of late , wandered into very strange paths : would to [God]281-god [they]4191-they were as uncommon as strange ! Both [she]458-woman and [the vicar]3366-the vicar had a great wish that [she]458-woman should lead a ‘[1758-he] devoted life ; ’ but then [they]4191-they both disdained to use common means for [their]4191-they object . The good old English plan of district visiting , by which [ladies]3255-ladies can have mercy on the bodies and souls of [those below [them]3255-ladies]4194-those below them , without casting off the holy discipline which [a home]4195-a home , [even the most ungenial , alone supplies]4196-even the most ungenial , alone supplies , savoured too much of mere ‘[1758-he] Protestantism . ’ It might be [God]281-god ’s plan for christianising [England]3-england just now , but that was no reason , alas ! for its being [their]4191-they plan : [they]4191-they wanted something more ‘[1758-he] Catholic , ’ more in accordance with Church principles ( for , indeed , is it not the business of [the Church]863-the church to correct the errors of Providence ! ) ; and what [they]4191-they sought [they]4191-they found at once in [a certain favourite establishment of [the vicar]3366-the vicar ’s]4198-a certain favourite establishment of the vicar ’s , [a Church - of - England béguinage]68-a church - of - england béguinage , or [quasi - Protestant nunnery]4200-quasi - protestant nunnery , which [he]3366-the vicar fostered in [a neighbouring city]4201-a neighbouring city , and went thither on all high tides to confess [the young ladies , who were in all things nuns]4202-the young ladies , who were in all things nuns , but bound by no vows , except , of course , such as [they]4191-they might choose to make for [themselves]4191-they in private . Here [they]4191-they laboured among the lowest haunts of misery and sin , piously and self - denyingly enough , sweet souls ! in hope of ‘[1758-he] the peculiar crown , ’ and a higher place in [heaven]1101-heaven than [the relations whom [they]4191-they had left behind [them]4191-they]4204-the relations whom they had left behind them ‘[1758-he] in [the world]475-the world , ’ and unshackled by the interference of [parents]4205-parents , and [other such merely fleshly relationships]4206-other such merely fleshly relationships , which , as [they]4191-they can not have been instituted by [God]281-god merely to be trampled under foot on the path to holiness , and can not well have instituted [themselves]4191-they ( unless , after all , [the Materialists]4207-the materialists are right , and [this world]1108-this world does grind of itself , except when [its Maker happens to interfere once every thousand years]4209-its maker happens to interfere once every thousand years ) , must needs have been instituted by the devil . And so [more than one girl in [that nunnery]4211-that nunnery]4210-more than one girl in that nunnery , and out of it , too , believed in [her]4210-more than one girl in that nunnery inmost heart , though [her]4210-more than one girl in that nunnery ‘[1758-he] Catholic principles , ’ by a happy inconsistency , forbade [her]4210-more than one girl in that nunnery to say so . In a moment of excitement , fascinated by the romance of the notion , [Argemone]150-argemone had proposed to [[her]150-argemone mother]1404-her mother to allow [her]150-argemone to enter [this béguinage]4213-this béguinage , and called in [the vicar]3366-the vicar as [advocate]4215-advocate ; which produced a correspondence between [him]1758-he and [Mrs. Lavington]158-mrs. lavington , stormy on [her]158-mrs. lavington side , provokingly calm on [his]1758-he : and when [the poor lady]4216-the poor lady , tired of raging , had descended to an affecting appeal to [his]1758-he human sympathies , entreating [him]1758-he to spare [a mother]1052-a mother ’s feelings , [he]1758-he had answered with the same impassive fanaticism , that ‘[1758-he] [he]1758-he was surprised at [her]1758-he putting [a mother]1052-a mother ’s selfish feelings in competition with the sanctity of [[her]1758-he child]3728-her child , ’ and that ‘[1758-he] had [[his]1758-he own daughter]1761-his own daughter shown such a desire for a higher vocation , [he]1758-he should have esteemed it the very highest honour ; ’ to which [Mrs. Lavington]158-mrs. lavington answered , naively enough , that ‘[1758-he] it depended very much on what [[his]1758-he daughter]1762-his daughter was like . ’—So [he]1758-he was all but forbidden [the house]3485-the house . Nevertheless [he]1758-he contrived , by means of this same secret correspondence , to keep alive in [Argemone]150-argemone ’s mind the longing to turn nun , and fancied honestly that [he]1758-he was doing God service , while [he]1758-he was pampering [the poor girl]4219-the poor girl ’s lust for singularity and self - glorification . But , lately , [Argemone]150-argemone ’s letters had become less frequent and less confiding ; and [the vicar]3366-the vicar , who well knew the reason , had resolved to bring the matter to a crisis . So [he]1758-he wrote earnestly and peremptorily to [[his]1758-he pupil]4221-his pupil , urging [her]4221-his pupil , with all [his]1758-he subtle and refined eloquence , to make a final appeal to [[her]4221-his pupil mother]1404-her mother , and if that failed , to act ‘[1762-his daughter] as [her]1762-his daughter conscience should direct [her]1762-his daughter ; ’ and enclosed an answer from [the superior of [the convent]4224-the convent]4223-the superior of the convent , to a letter which [Argemone]150-argemone had in a mad moment asked [him]1758-he to write . [The superior]4225-the superior ’s letter spoke of [Argemone]150-argemone ’s joining [her]4221-his pupil as a settled matter , and of [[her]4221-his pupil room]4226-her room as ready for [her]4221-his pupil , while it lauded to the skies the peaceful activity and usefulness of [the establishment]4227-the establishment . This letter troubled [Argemone]150-argemone exceedingly . [She]150-argemone had never before been compelled to face [her]150-argemone own feelings , either about [the nunnery]4228-the nunnery or about [Lancelot]172-lancelot . [She]150-argemone had taken up the fancy of becoming [a Sister of Charity]4229-a sister of charity , not as [Honoria]162-honoria might have done , from genuine love of [the poor]698-the poor , but from ‘[1762-his daughter] a sense of duty . ’ Almsgiving and visiting [the sick]4231-the sick were one of the methods of earning heaven prescribed by [her]150-argemone new creed . [She]150-argemone was ashamed of [her]150-argemone own laziness by the side of [Honoria]162-honoria ’s simple benevolence ; and , sad though it may be to have to say it , [she]150-argemone longed to outdo [her]162-honoria by some signal act of self - sacrifice . [She]150-argemone had looked to [this nunnery]4232-this nunnery , too , as an escape , once and for all , from [her]150-argemone own luxury , just as [people who have not strength to be temperate]4233-people who have not strength to be temperate take refuge in teetotalism ; and the thought of menial services towards [the poor]698-the poor , however distasteful to [her]150-argemone , came in quite prettily to fill up the little ideal of a life of romantic asceticisms and mystic contemplation , which gave the true charm in [her]150-argemone eyes to [her]150-argemone wild project . But now — just as a field had opened to [her]150-argemone cravings after poetry and art , wider and richer than [she]150-argemone had ever imagined — just as those simple childlike views of man and nature , which [she]150-argemone had learnt to despise , were assuming an awful holiness in [her]150-argemone eyes — just as [she]150-argemone had found a human soul to whose regeneration [she]150-argemone could devote all [her]150-argemone energies,—to be required to give all up , perhaps for ever ( and [she]150-argemone felt that if at all , it ought to be for ever);—it was too much for [her]150-argemone little heart to bear ; and [she]150-argemone cried bitterly ; and tried to pray , and could not ; and longed for a strong and tender bosom on which to lay [her]150-argemone head , and pour out all [her]150-argemone doubts and struggles ; and there was none . [[Her]150-argemone mother]1404-her mother did not understand — hardly loved [her]150-argemone . [Honoria]162-honoria loved [her]150-argemone ; but understood [her]150-argemone even less than [[her]150-argemone mother]1404-her mother . Pride — the pride of intellect , the pride of self - will — had long since sealed [her]150-argemone lips to [[her]150-argemone own family]4237-her own family ... And then , out of the darkness of [her]150-argemone heart , [Lancelot]172-lancelot ’s image rose before [her]150-argemone stronger than all , tenderer than all ; and as [she]150-argemone remembered [his]172-lancelot magical faculty of anticipating all [her]150-argemone thoughts , embodying for [her]150-argemone all [her]150-argemone vague surmises , [he]172-lancelot seemed to beckon [her]150-argemone towards him.—She shuddered and turned away . And now [she]150-argemone first became conscious how [he]172-lancelot had haunted [her]150-argemone thoughts in the last few months , not as a soul to be saved , but as [a living man]4238-a living man — [his]172-lancelot face , [his]172-lancelot figure , [his]172-lancelot voice , [his]172-lancelot every gesture and expression , rising clear before [her]150-argemone , in spite of [herself]150-argemone , by day and night . And then [she]150-argemone thought of [his]172-lancelot last drawing , and the looks which had accompanied it,—unmistakable looks of passionate and adoring love . There was no denying it — [she]150-argemone had always known that [he]172-lancelot loved [her]150-argemone , but [she]150-argemone had never dared to confess it to [herself]150-argemone . But now the earthquake was come , and all the secrets of [her]150-argemone heart burst upward to the light , and [she]150-argemone faced the thought in shame and terror . ‘[1762-his daughter] How unjust [I]0-i have been to [him]1763-him ! how cruel ! thus to entice [him]1763-him on in hopeless love ! ’ [She]150-argemone lifted up [her]150-argemone eyes , and saw in the mirror opposite the reflection of [her]150-argemone own exquisite beauty . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i could have known what [I]0-i was doing ! [I]0-i knew all the while ! And yet it is so delicious to feel that [any one]936-any one loves [me]0-i ! Is it selfishness ? It is selfishness , to pamper [my]0-i vanity on an affection which [I]0-i do not , will not return . [I]0-i will not be thus in debt to [him]1763-him , even for [his]1763-him love . [I]0-i do not love [him]1763-him — [I]0-i do not ; and even if [I]0-i did , to give [myself]0-i up to [a man of whom [I]0-i know so little , who is not even [a Christian , much less a Churchman]1766-a christian , much less a churchman]1765-a man of whom i know so little , who is not even a christian , much less a churchman ! Ay ! and to give up [my]0-i will to [any man]3336-any man ! to become the subject , [the slave]1751-the slave , of [another human being]1769-another human being ! [I]0-i , who have worshipped the belief in [woman]458-woman ’s independence , the hope of [woman]458-woman ’s enfranchisement , who have felt how glorious it is to live like [the angels]3665-the angels , single and self - sustained ! What if [I]0-i cut the Gordian knot , and here make , once for all , a vow of perpetual celibacy ? ’ [She]458-woman flung [herself]458-woman on [her]458-woman knees — [she]458-woman could not collect [her]458-woman thoughts . ‘[0-i] No , ’ [she]458-woman said , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i am not prepared for this . It is too solemn to be undertaken in this miserable whirlwind of passion .
