[I]0-i will fast , and meditate , and go up formally to [the little chapel]541-the little chapel , and there devote [myself]0-i to [God]281-god ; and , in the meantime , to write at once to [the superior of [the Béguines]1775-the béguines]1774-the superior of the béguines ; to go to [[my]0-i mother]867-my mother , and tell [her]867-my mother once for all — What ? Must [I]0-i lose him?—must [I]0-i give [him]1777-him up ? Not [his]1777-him love — [I]0-i can not give up that — would that [I]0-i could ! but no ! [he]1777-him will love [me]0-i for ever . [I]0-i know it as well as if [an angel]1778-an angel told [me]0-i . But to give up [him]1777-him ! Never to see [him]1777-him ! never to hear [his]1777-him voice ! never to walk with [him]1777-him among [the beech woods]1779-the beech woods any more ! Oh , [Argemone]150-argemone ! Argemone ! [miserable girl]1780-miserable girl ! and is it come to this ? ’ And [she]150-argemone threw [herself]150-argemone on the sofa , and hid [her]150-argemone face in [her]150-argemone hands . Yes , [Argemone]150-argemone , it is come to this ; and the best thing [you]150-argemone can do , is just what [you]150-argemone are doing — to lie there and cry [yourself]150-argemone to sleep , while [the angels]3665-the angels are laughing kindly ( if [a solemn public]4240-a solemn public , who settles everything for [them]3665-the angels , will permit [them]3665-the angels to laugh ) at [the rickety old windmill of sham - Popery which [you]150-argemone have taken for [a real giant]4242-a real giant]4241-the rickety old windmill of sham - popery which you have taken for a real giant . At that same day and hour , as it chanced , [Lancelot]172-lancelot , little dreaming what [the said windmill]4243-the said windmill was grinding for [him]172-lancelot , was scribbling a hasty and angry answer to a letter of [Luke]137-mr. smith ’s , which , perhaps , came that very morning in order to put [him]172-lancelot into a proper temper for the demolishing of [windmills]4244-windmills . It ran thus , — ‘[307-my good cousin,—so] Ay , [[my]0-i good Cousin,—So]307-my good cousin,—so [I]0-i expected — ‘ Suave mari magno turbantibus æquora ventis E terra magnum alterius spectare laborem ... Pleasant and easy for [you]150-argemone Protestants ( for [I]307-my good cousin,—so will call [you]150-argemone what [you]150-argemone are , in spite of [your]150-argemone own denials , [a truly consistent and logical Protestant]4245-a truly consistent and logical protestant — and therefore a Materialist)—easy for [you]150-argemone , [I]307-my good cousin,—so say , to sit on [the shore]4246-the shore , in cold , cruel self - satisfaction , and tell the poor wretch buffeting with the waves what [he]172-lancelot ought to do while [he]172-lancelot is choking and drowning ... Thank Heaven , the storm has stranded [me]307-my good cousin,—so upon [the everlasting Rock of Peter;—but]4247-the everlasting rock of peter;—but it has been a sore trouble to reach [it]4247-the everlasting rock of peter;—but . [Protestants]1112-protestants , who look at creeds as things to be changed like coats , whenever [they]1112-protestants seem not to fit [them]1112-protestants , little know what [we]4249-we [Catholic - hearted ones]4250-catholic - hearted ones suffer ... If [they]4250-catholic - hearted ones did , [they]4250-catholic - hearted ones would be more merciful and more chary in the requirements of [us]4249-we , just as [we]4249-we are in the very throe of a new - born existence . [The excellent man]4251-the excellent man , to whose care [I]307-my good cousin,—so have committed [myself]307-my good cousin,—so , has a wise and a tender heart ... [he]4251-the excellent man saw no harm in [my]307-my good cousin,—so concealing from [[my]307-my good cousin,—so father]3846-my father the spiritual reason of [my]307-my good cousin,—so giving up [my]307-my good cousin,—so curacy ( for [I]307-my good cousin,—so have given it up ) , and only giving the outward , but equally true reason , that [I]307-my good cousin,—so found it on the whole an ineligible and distressing post .... [I]307-my good cousin,—so know [you]4253-you will apply to such an act that disgusting monosyllable of which [Protestants]220-protestants are so fond . [He]4251-the excellent man felt with [me]307-my good cousin,—so and for [me]307-my good cousin,—so — for [my]307-my good cousin,—so horror of giving pain to [[my]307-my good cousin,—so father]3846-my father , and for [my]307-my good cousin,—so wearied and excited state of mind ; and strangely enough — to show how differently , according to the difference of the organs , the same object may appear to [two people]4255-two people — [he]4251-the excellent man quoted in [my]307-my good cousin,—so favour that very verse which [you]4253-you wrest against [me]307-my good cousin,—so . [He]4251-the excellent man wished [me]307-my good cousin,—so to show [[my]307-my good cousin,—so father]3846-my father that [I]307-my good cousin,—so had only changed [my]307-my good cousin,—so heaven , and not [my]307-my good cousin,—so character , by becoming [an Ultramontane - Catholic]4257-an ultramontane - catholic ... that , as far as [his]4251-the excellent man esteem and affection were founded on anything in [me]307-my good cousin,—so , the ground of it did not vanish with [my]307-my good cousin,—so conversion . If [I]307-my good cousin,—so had told [him]4251-the excellent man at once of [my]307-my good cousin,—so altered opinions , [he]4251-the excellent man would have henceforth viewed every word and action with a perjudiced eye ... [Protestants]1112-protestants are so bigoted ... but if , after seeing [me]307-my good cousin,—so for a month or two the same Luke that [he]4251-the excellent man had ever known [me]307-my good cousin,—so , [he]4251-the excellent man were gradually informed that [I]307-my good cousin,—so had all the while held that creed which [he]4251-the excellent man had considered incompatible with such a life as [I]307-my good cousin,—so hope [mine]307-my good cousin,—so would be — [you]4259-you must see the effect which it ought to have ... [I]307-my good cousin,—so do n’t doubt that [you]4259-you will complain of all this ... All [I]307-my good cousin,—so can say is , that [I]307-my good cousin,—so can not sympathise with that superstitious reverence for mere verbal truth , which is so common among [Protestants]1112-protestants ... It seems to [me]307-my good cousin,—so [they]1112-protestants throw away the spirit of truth , in [their]1112-protestants idolatry of its letter . For instance,—what is the use of informing [a man]445-a man of a true fact but to induce a true opinion in [him]445-a man ? But if , by clinging to the exact letter of the fact , [you]4259-you create a false opinion in [his]445-a man mind , as [I]307-my good cousin,—so should do in [[my]307-my good cousin,—so father]3846-my father ’s case , if by telling [him]445-a man at once of [my]307-my good cousin,—so change , [I]307-my good cousin,—so gave [him]445-a man an unjust horror of Catholicism,—you do not tell [him]445-a man the truth ... [You]4259-you may speak what is true to [you,—but]4263-you,—but it becomes an error when received into [his]445-a man mind ... . If [his]445-a man mind is a refracting and polarising medium — if the crystalline lens of [his]445-a man soul ’s eye has been changed into tourmaline or Labrador spar — the only way to give [him]445-a man a true image of the fact , is to present it to [him]445-a man already properly altered in form , and adapted to suit the obliquity of [his]445-a man vision ; in order that the very refractive power of [his]445-a man faculties may , instead of distorting it , correct it , and make it straight for [him]445-a man ; and so a verbal wrong in fact may possess [him]445-a man with a right opinion ... ‘[307-my good cousin,—so] [You]1781-you see the whole question turns on [your]1781-you Protestant deification of the intellect ... If [you]1781-you really believed , as [you]1781-you all say [you]1781-you do , that the nature of [man]564-man , and therefore [his]564-man intellect among the rest , was utterly corrupt , [you]1781-you would not be so superstitiously careful to tell the truth ... as [you]1781-you call it ; because [you]1781-you would know that [man]564-man ’s heart , if not [his]564-man head , would needs turn the truth into a lie by its own corruption ... The proper use of reasoning is to produce opinion,—and if the subject in which [you]1781-you wish to produce the opinion is diseased , [you]1781-you must adapt the medicine accordingly . ’ To all which [Lancelot]172-lancelot , with several strong curses , scrawled the following answer : — ‘[308-luke!—well] And this is [[my]0-i Cousin]1784-my cousin [Luke!—Well]308-luke!—well , [I]0-i shall believe henceforward that there is , after all , a thousand times greater moral gulf fixed between Popery and Tractarianism , than between Tractarianism and the extremest Protestantism . [[My]0-i dear]1114-my dear fellow,—I wo n’t bother [you]1781-you , by cutting up [your]1781-you charming ambiguous middle terms , which make reason and reasoning identical , or [your]1781-you theory that the office of reasoning is to induce [opinions—(the devil]1786-opinions—(the devil take opinions , right or wrong — [I]0-i want facts , faith in real facts!)—or about deifying the intellect — as if all sound intellect was not in itself divine light — a revelation to man of absolute laws independent of [him]564-man , as [the very heathens]1787-the very heathens hold . But this [I]0-i will do — thank [you]1781-you most sincerely for the compliment [you]1781-you pay [us]1788-we [Cismontane heretics]1789-cismontane heretics . [We]1788-we do retain some dim belief in [a God]1165-a god — even [I]0-i am beginning to believe in believing in [Him]1165-a god . And therefore , as [I]0-i begin to suppose , it is , that [we]1788-we reverence facts , as the work of [God]281-god , [His]281-god acted words and will , which [we]1788-we dare not falsify ; which [we]1788-we believe will tell [their]1791-their own story better than [we]1788-we can tell it for [them]1791-their . If [our]1788-we eyes are dimmed , [we]1788-we think it safer to clear them , which do belong to [us]1788-we , than to bedevil , by the light of those very already dimmed eyes , the objects round , which do not belong to [us]1788-we . Whether [we]1788-we are consistent or not about the corruptness of [man]564-man , [we]1788-we are about the incorruptness of [God]281-god ; and therefore about that of the facts by which [God]281-god teaches [men]612-men : and believe , and will continue to believe , that the blackest of all sins , the deepest of all Atheisms , that which , above all things , proves no faith in [God]281-god ’s government of [the universe]3109-the universe , no sense of [His]281-god presence , no understanding of [His]281-god character , is — a lie . ‘ One word more — Unless [you]4264-you tell [[your]4264-you father]3830-your father within twenty - four hours after receiving this letter , [I]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway will . And [I]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway , being [a Protestant]4266-a protestant ( if cursing Popery means Protestantism ) , mean what [I]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway say . ’[272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway] As [Lancelot]172-lancelot walked up to [the Priory]534-the priory that morning , [the Reverend Panurgus O’Blareaway]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway dashed out of [a cottage by the roadside]1796-a cottage by the roadside , and seized [him]172-lancelot unceremoniously by the shoulders . [He]172-lancelot was a specimen of humanity which [Lancelot]172-lancelot could not help at once liking and despising ; a quaint mixture of conceit and earnestness , uniting the shrewdness of [a stockjobber]1797-a stockjobber with the frolic of [a schoolboy]1798-a schoolboy broke loose . [He]172-lancelot was rector of a place in [the west of [Ireland]69-ireland]1799-the west of ireland , containing [some ten Protestants]1800-some ten protestants and [some thousand Papists]1801-some thousand papists . Being , unfortunately for [himself]172-lancelot , [a red - hot Orangeman]1802-a red - hot orangeman , [he]172-lancelot had thought fit to quarrel with [the priest]1803-the priest , in consequence of which [he]172-lancelot found [himself]172-lancelot deprived both of tithes and congregation ; and after receiving three or four Rockite letters , and a charge of slugs through [his]172-lancelot hat ( of which [he]172-lancelot always talked as if being shot at was the most pleasant and amusing feature of Irish life ) , [he]172-lancelot repaired to [England]3-england , and there , after trying to set up as [popular preacher in [London]46-london]1804-popular preacher in london , declaiming at [Exeter Hall]2-exeter hall , and writing for all the third - rate magazines , found [himself]172-lancelot incumbent of [Lower Whitford]48-lower whitford . [He]172-lancelot worked [there]992-there , as [he]172-lancelot said [himself]172-lancelot , ‘ like a horse ; ’[172-lancelot] spent [his]172-lancelot mornings in [the schools]1806-the schools , [his]172-lancelot afternoons in [the cottages]1262-the cottages ; preached four or five extempore sermons every week to [overflowing congregations]1808-overflowing congregations ; took the lead , by virtue of the ‘ gift of the gab , ’[172-lancelot] at all ‘ religious ’[172-lancelot] meetings for ten miles round ; and really did a great deal of good in [his]172-lancelot way . [He]172-lancelot had an unblushing candour about [his]172-lancelot own worldly ambition , with a tremendous brogue ; and prided [himself]172-lancelot on exaggerating deliberately both of these excellences . ‘ The top of the morning to [ye]172-lancelot , [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith . [Ye]172-lancelot have n’t such a thing as a cegar about [ye]172-lancelot ? [I]172-lancelot ’ve been preaching to [school - children]4267-school - children till [me]172-lancelot throat ’s as dry as [the slave of a lime - burner]4268-the slave of a lime - burner ’s coat . ’[172-lancelot] ‘ [I]172-lancelot am very sorry ; but , really , [I]172-lancelot have left [my]172-lancelot case at [home]452-home . ’[172-lancelot] ‘ Oh ! ah ! faix and [I]172-lancelot forgot . [Ye]172-lancelot must n’t be smokin ’[172-lancelot] the nasty things going up to [the castle]1809-the castle . Och , [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith , but [you]172-lancelot ’re [the lucky man]4270-the lucky man ! ’[172-lancelot] ‘ [I]172-lancelot am much obliged to [you]172-lancelot for the compliment , ’[172-lancelot] said [Lancelot]172-lancelot , gruffly ; ‘ but really [I]172-lancelot do n’t see how [I]172-lancelot deserve it . ’[172-lancelot] ‘ Desarve it ! Sure luck ’s all , and that ’s [your]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway luck , and not [your]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway deserts at all . To have [the handsomest girl in [the county]4101-the county dying for love of ye’—(Panurgus]4271-the handsomest girl in the county dying for love of ye’—(panurgus had a happy knack of blurting out truths — when they were pleasant ones ) . ‘[1810-she] And [she]1810-she just the beautifulest creature that ever spilte shoe - leather , barring [Lady Philandria Mountflunkey]309-lady philandria mountflunkey , of [Castle Mountflunkey]71-castle mountflunkey , Quane ’s County , that shall be nameless . ’ ‘[272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway] Upon [my]0-i word , [O’Blareaway]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway , [you]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway seem to be better acquainted with [my]0-i matters than [I]0-i am . Do n’t [you]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway think , on the whole , it might be better to mind [your]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway own business ? ’ ‘[0-i] [Me]0-i own business ! [Poker o ’ Moses]4273-poker o ’ moses ! and ai n’t it [me]4273-poker o ’ moses own business ? Have n’t [ye]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway spilte [my]4273-poker o ’ moses tenderest hopes ? And good luck to [ye]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway in that same , for [ye’re]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway as pretty [a rider as ever kicked coping - stones out of a wall]4274-a rider as ever kicked coping - stones out of a wall ; and poor [Paddy]310-paddy loves [a sportsman]4275-a sportsman by nature . Och ! but [ye’ve]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway got a hand of trumps this time . Did n’t [I]4273-poker o ’ moses mate [the vicar]3366-the vicar the other day , and spake [my]4273-poker o ’ moses mind to [him]3366-the vicar ? ’[4273-poker o ’ moses] ‘ What do [you]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway mean ? ’[172-lancelot] asked [Lancelot]172-lancelot , with a strong expletive . ‘ [Faix]311-faix , [I]172-lancelot told [him]3366-the vicar [he]3366-the vicar might as well Faugh a ballagh — make [a rid road]4277-a rid road , and get out of that , with [his]3366-the vicar bowings and [his]3366-the vicar crossings , and [[his]3366-the vicar Popery]4278-his popery made asy for small minds , for there was a gun a - field that would wipe [his]3366-the vicar eye,—maning [yourself]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway , [ye]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway Prathestant . ’[172-lancelot] ‘ All [I]312-the good - natured irishman can say is , that [you]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway had really better mind [your]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway own business , and [I]312-the good - natured irishman ’ll mind [my]312-the good - natured irishman own . ’[312-the good - natured irishman] ‘ Och , ’[312-the good - natured irishman] said [the good - natured Irishman]312-the good - natured irishman , ‘ and it ’s [you]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway must mind [my]312-the good - natured irishman business , and [I]312-the good - natured irishman ’ll mind [yours]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway ; and that ’s all fair and aqual . [Ye’ve]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway cut [me]312-the good - natured irishman out intirely at [the Priory]534-the priory , [ye]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway Tory , and so [ye’re]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway bound to give [me]312-the good - natured irishman a lift somehow . Could n’t [ye]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway look [me]312-the good - natured irishman out [a fine fat widow]4280-a fine fat widow , with an illigant little fortune ? For what ’s [England]3-england made for except to find [poor [Paddy]310-paddy [a wife]4282-a wife and money]4281-poor paddy a wife and money ? Ah , [ye]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway may laugh , but [I]312-the good - natured irishman ’d buy [me]312-the good - natured irishman [a chapel at [the West - end]4284-the west - end]4283-a chapel at the west - end : [me]312-the good - natured irishman talents are thrown away here intirely , wasting [me]312-the good - natured irishman swateness on [the desert]1738-the desert air , as [Tom Moore]313-tom moore says ’[312-the good - natured irishman] ( [Panurgus]272-the reverend panurgus o’blareaway used to attribute all quotations whatsoever to [Irish geniuses]1811-irish geniuses ) ; ‘ and [I]1359-the boy flatter [meself]1359-the boy [I]1359-the boy ’m[1359-the boy] [the boy]1359-the boy to shute the Gospel to [the aristocracy]1813-the aristocracy . ’ [Lancelot]172-lancelot burst into a roar of laughter , and escaped over the next gate : but [the Irishman]4286-the irishman ’s coarse hints stuck by [him]172-lancelot as they were intended to do . ‘[1359-the boy] Dying for the love of [me]0-i ! ’ [He]172-lancelot knew it was an impudent exaggeration , but , somehow , it gave [him]172-lancelot confidence ; ‘[312-the good - natured irishman] there is no smoke , ’ [he]172-lancelot thought , ‘[312-the good - natured irishman] without fire . ’ And [his]172-lancelot heart beat high with new hopes , for which [he]172-lancelot laughed at [himself]172-lancelot all the while . It was just the cordial which [he]172-lancelot needed . That conversation determined the history of [his]172-lancelot life . [He]172-lancelot met [Argemone]150-argemone that morning in [the library]4287-the library , as usual ; but [he]172-lancelot soon found that [she]150-argemone was not thinking of [Homer]213-homer . [She]150-argemone was moody and abstracted ; and [he]172-lancelot could not help at last saying , — ‘[0-i] [I]0-i am afraid [I]0-i and [[my]0-i classics]1814-my classics are de trop this morning , [Miss Lavington]189-miss lavington . ’ ‘[189-miss lavington] Oh , no , no . Never that . ’ [She]150-argemone turned away [her]150-argemone head . [He]172-lancelot fancied that it was to hide a tear . Suddenly [she]150-argemone rose , and turned to [him]172-lancelot with a clear , calm , gentle gaze . ‘[189-miss lavington] Listen to [me]0-i , [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith . [We]1815-we must part to - day , and for ever . This intimacy has gone on — too long , [I]0-i am afraid , for [your]137-mr. smith happiness . And now , like all pleasant things in [this miserable world]1816-this miserable world , it must cease . [I]0-i can not tell [you]137-mr. smith why ; but [you]137-mr. smith will trust [me]0-i . [I]0-i thank [you]137-mr. smith for it — [I]0-i thank [God]281-god for it . [I]0-i have learnt things from it which [I]0-i shall never forget . [I]0-i have learnt , at least from it , to esteem and honour [you]137-mr. smith . [You]137-mr. smith have vast powers . Nothing , nothing , [I]0-i believe , is too high for [you]137-mr. smith to attempt and succeed . But [we]1815-we must part ; and now , [God]281-god be with [you]137-mr. smith . Oh , that [you]137-mr. smith would but believe that these glorious talents are [His]281-god loan ! That [you]137-mr. smith would but be [a true and loyal knight to [him]281-god who said—“Learn of [me]0-i , for [I]0-i am meek and lowly of heart , and [ye]137-mr. smith shall find rest unto [your]137-mr. smith souls!”—Ay]1817-a true and loyal knight to him who said—“learn of me , for i am meek and lowly of heart , and ye shall find rest unto your souls!”—ay , ’ [she]4288-she went on , more and more passionately , for [she]4288-she felt that not [she]4288-she , but One mightier than [herself]4288-she was speaking through [her]4288-she , ‘[1817-a true and loyal knight to him who said—“learn of me , for i am meek and lowly of heart , and ye shall find rest unto your souls!”—ay] then [you]137-mr. smith might be great indeed . Then [I]0-i might watch [your]137-mr. smith name from afar , rising higher and higher daily in the ranks of [[God]281-god ’s own heroes]1818-god ’s own heroes . [I]0-i see it — and [you]137-mr. smith have taught [me]0-i to see it — that [you]137-mr. smith are meant for a faith nobler and deeper than all doctrines and systems can give . [You]137-mr. smith must become [the philosopher , who can discover new truths]1819-the philosopher , who can discover new truths — [the artist who can embody them in new forms]1820-the artist who can embody them in new forms , while poor [I]0-i — And that is another reason why [we]1821-we should part.—Hush ! hear [me]0-i out . [I]0-i must not be a clog , to drag [you]137-mr. smith down in [your]137-mr. smith course . Take this , and farewell ; and remember that [you]137-mr. smith once had [a friend called [Argemone]150-argemone]1822-a friend called argemone . ’ [She]1822-a friend called argemone put into [his]0-i hands a little Bible . [He]0-i took it , and laid it down on the table . For a minute [he]0-i stood silent and rooted to the spot . Disappointment , shame , rage , hatred , all boiled up madly within [him]0-i . The bitterest insults rose to [his]0-i lips—‘Flirt , [cold - hearted pedant]4289-cold - hearted pedant , [fanatic]4290-fanatic ! ’[1822-a friend called argemone] but they sank again unspoken , as [he]0-i looked into the celestial azure of those eyes , calm and pure as a soft evening sky . A mighty struggle between good and evil shook [his]0-i heart to the roots ; and , for the first time in [his]0-i life , [his]0-i soul breathed out one real prayer , that [God]281-god would help [him]0-i now or never to play [the man]738-the man . And in a moment the darkness passed ; a new spirit called out all the latent strength within [him]0-i ; and gently and proudly [he]0-i answered [her]1824-you , — ‘ Yes , [I]1825-i will go . [I]1825-i have had mad dreams , conceited and insolent , and have met with [[my]1825-i deserts]4291-my deserts . [Brute]314-brute and fool as [I]1825-i am , [I]1825-i have aspired even to [you]1824-you ! And [I]1825-i have gained , in the sunshine of [your]1824-you condescension , strength and purity.—Is not that enough for [me]1825-i ? And now [I]1825-i will show [you]1824-you that [I]1825-i love [you]1824-you — by obeying [you]1824-you . [You]1824-you tell [me]1825-i to depart — [I]1825-i go for ever . ’[1825-i] [He]1825-i turned away . Why did [she]1826-she almost spring after [him]1825-i ? ‘ [Lancelot]172-lancelot ! one word ! Do not misunderstand [me]1825-i , as [I]1825-i know [you]1824-you will . [You]1824-you will think [me]1825-i so cold , heartless , fickle.—Oh , [you]1824-you do not know — [you]1824-you never can know — how much [I]1825-i , too , have felt ! ’[1825-i] [He]1825-i stopped , spell - bound . In an instant [his]1825-i conversation with [the Irishman]4286-the irishman flashed up before [him]1825-i with new force and meaning . A thousand petty incidents , which [he]1825-i had driven contemptuously from [his]1825-i mind , returned as triumphant evidences ; and , with an impetuous determination , [he]1825-i cried out , — ‘ [I]1825-i see — [I]1825-i see it all , [Argemone]150-argemone ! [We]4292-we love [each other]565-each other ! [You]150-argemone are [mine]1825-i , never to be parted ! ’[1825-i] What was [her]1828-her womanhood , that it could stand against the energy of [his]1825-i manly will ! The almost coarse simplicity of [his]1825-i words silenced [her]1828-her with a delicious violence . [She]1828-her could only bury [her]1828-her face in [her]1828-her hands and sob out , — ‘ Oh , [Lancelot]172-lancelot , [Lancelot]172-lancelot , whither are [you]1825-i forcing [me]1828-her ? ’[1828-her] ‘ [I]1825-i am forcing [you]150-argemone no whither . [God]281-god , [the Father of spirits]4294-the father of spirits , is leading [you]150-argemone ! [You]150-argemone , who believe in [Him]281-god , how dare [you]150-argemone fight against [Him]281-god ? ’[1825-i] ‘ [Lancelot]172-lancelot , [I]1828-her cannot — [I]1828-her can not listen to [you]1829-him — read that ! ’[1828-her] And [she]1828-her handed [him]1829-him [the vicar]3366-the vicar ’s letter . [He]1829-him read it , tossed it on the carpet , and crushed it with [his]1829-him heel . ‘ [Wretched pedant]4295-wretched pedant ! Can [your]150-argemone intellect be deluded by such barefaced sophistries ? “ [God]281-god ’s will , ” forsooth ! And if [[your]150-argemone mother]4296-your mother ’s opposition is not a sign that [God]281-god ’s will — if it mean anything except [your]150-argemone own will , or that — [that man’s]4297-that man’s — is against this mad project , and not for it , what sign would [you]150-argemone have ? So “ celibacy is the highest state ! ” And why ? Because “ it is [the safest and the easiest road to heaven]4298-the safest and the easiest road to heaven ? ” A pretty reason , [vicar]4299-vicar ! [I]1829-him should have thought that that was a sign of a lower state and not a higher . [Noble spirits]4300-noble spirits show [their]4300-noble spirits nobleness by daring the most difficult paths . And even if marriage was but one weed - field of temptations , as [these miserable pedants]4301-these miserable pedants say , who have either never tried it , or misused it to [their]4301-these miserable pedants own shame , it would be a greater deed to conquer [its]4302-its temptations than to flee from [them]4300-noble spirits in cowardly longings after ease and safety ! ’[1829-him] [She]1831-me did not answer [him]1829-him , but kept [her]1831-me face buried in [her]1831-me hands . ‘ Again , [I]1831-me say , [Argemone]150-argemone , will [you]150-argemone fight against Fate — Providence — [God]281-god — call it what [you]150-argemone will ? Who made [us]4303-us meet at [the chapel]558-the chapel ? Who made [me]1831-me , by [my]1831-me accident , a guest in [[[your]150-argemone father]3830-your father ’s house]4306-your father ’s house ! Who put it into [your]150-argemone heart to care for [[my]1831-me poor soul]4307-my poor soul ? Who gave [us]4303-us this strange attraction towards [each other]565-each other , in spite of [our]4303-us unlikeness ? Wonderful that the very chain of circumstances which [you]150-argemone seem to fancy [the offspring of chance]4309-the offspring of chance or [the devil]600-the devil , should have first taught [me]1831-me to believe that there is [a God who guides [us]4303-us]4311-a god who guides us ! [Argemone]150-argemone ! speak , tell [me]1831-me , if [you]150-argemone will , to go for ever ; but tell [me]1831-me first the truth — [You]150-argemone love [me]1831-me ! ’[1831-me] A strong shudder ran through [her]1832-her frame — the ice of artificial years cracked , and the clear stream of [[her]1832-her woman]1833-her woman ’s nature welled up to the light , as pure as when [she]1832-her first lay on [[her]1832-her mother]1404-her mother ’s bosom : [she]1832-her lifted up [her]1832-her eyes , and with one long look of passionate tenderness [she]1832-her faltered out , — ‘ [I]1832-her love [you]1835-him ! ’[1832-her] [He]1835-him did not stir , but watched [her]1832-her with clasped hands , like one who in dreams finds [himself]1835-him in [some fairy palace]1836-some fairy palace , and fears that a movement may break the spell . ‘ Now , go , ’[1832-her] [she]1832-her said ; ‘ go , and let [me]1832-her collect [my]1832-her thoughts . All this has been too much for [me]1832-her . Do not look sad — [you]1835-him may come again to - morrow . ’[1832-her] [She]1832-her smiled and held out [her]1832-her hand . [He]1835-him caught it , covered it with kisses , and pressed it to [his]1835-him heart . [She]1832-her half drew it back , frightened . The sensation was new to [her]1832-her . Again the delicious feeling of being utterly in [his]1835-him power came over [her]1832-her , and [she]1832-her left [her]1832-her hand upon [his]1835-him heart , and blushed as [she]1832-her felt its passionate throbbings . [He]1835-him turned to go — not as before . [She]1832-her followed with greedy eyes [her]1832-her new - found treasure ; and as the door closed behind [him]1835-him , [she]1832-her felt as if [Lancelot]172-lancelot was [the whole world]1313-the whole world , and there was nothing beside [him]1835-him , and wondered how a moment had made [him]1835-him all in all to [her]1832-her ; and then [she]1832-her sank upon [her]1832-her knees , and folded [her]1832-her hands upon [her]1832-her bosom , and [her]1832-her prayers for [him]1835-him were like the prayers of [a little child]1750-a little child . But what had become of the ‘ bit of writing ’[1832-her] which [Harry Verney]174-old harry , by the instigation of [his]174-old harry evil genius , had put into [the squire]3125-the squire ’s fly - book ? [Tregarva]173-tregarva had waited in terrible suspense for many weeks , expecting the explosion which [he]173-tregarva knew must follow its discovery . [He]173-tregarva had confided to [Lancelot]172-lancelot the contents of the paper , and [Lancelot]172-lancelot had tried many stratagems to get possession of it , but all in vain . [Tregarva]173-tregarva took this as calmly as [he]173-tregarva did everything else . Only once , on the morning of the éclaircissement between [Lancelot]172-lancelot and [Argemone]150-argemone , [he]173-tregarva talked to [Lancelot]172-lancelot of leaving [[his]173-tregarva place]1840-his place , and going out to seek [his]173-tregarva fortune ; but some spell , which [he]173-tregarva did not explain , seemed to chain [him]173-tregarva to [the Priory]534-the priory . [Lancelot]172-lancelot thought it was the want of money , and offered to lend [him]172-lancelot ten pounds whenever [he]172-lancelot liked ; but [Tregarva]173-tregarva shook [his]173-tregarva head . ‘ [You]173-tregarva have treated [me]173-tregarva , [sir]753-sir , as [no one else]3868-no one else has done — like [a man]445-a man and [a friend]4315-a friend ; but [I]173-tregarva am not going to make a market of [your]173-tregarva generosity . [I]173-tregarva will owe [no man]1477-no man anything , save to love [one another]1081-one another . ’[173-tregarva] ‘ But how do [you]173-tregarva intend to live ? ’[172-lancelot] asked [Lancelot]172-lancelot , as [they]1842-they stood together in [the cloisters]1843-the cloisters . ‘ There ’s enough of [me]172-lancelot , [sir]753-sir , to make a good navigator if all trades fail . ’[172-lancelot] ‘ Nonsense ! [you]173-tregarva must not throw [yourself]173-tregarva away so . ’[173-tregarva] ‘ Oh , [sir]753-sir , there ’s good to be done , believe [me]173-tregarva , among [those poor fellows]4320-those poor fellows . [They]4320-those poor fellows wander up and down [the land]4321-the land like hogs and [heathens]4322-heathens , and [no one]555-no one tells [them]4320-those poor fellows that [they]4320-those poor fellows have a soul to be saved . [Not one parson in a thousand]4324-not one parson in a thousand gives a thought to [them]4320-those poor fellows . [They]4320-those poor fellows can manage [old folks]4325-old folks and [little children]1752-little children , [sir]753-sir , but , somehow , [they]4320-those poor fellows never can get hold of [the young men]4328-the young men — just those who want [them]4328-the young men most . There ’s a talk about [ragged schools]4329-ragged schools , now . Why do n’t [they]4320-those poor fellows try [ragged churches]4330-ragged churches , [sir]753-sir , and a ragged service ? ’[173-tregarva] ‘ What do [you]753-sir mean ? ’[172-lancelot] ‘ Why , [sir]753-sir , [the parsons]3377-the parsons are ready enough to save [souls]4334-souls , but it must be only according to rule and regulation . Before the Gospel can be preached there must be three thousand pounds got together for [a church]3584-a church , and a thousand for an endowment , not to mention the thousand pounds that [the clergyman]781-the clergyman ’s education costs : [I]173-tregarva do n’t think of [[his]781-the clergyman own keep]4337-his own keep , [sir]753-sir ; that ’s little enough , often ; and [those that work hardest]4339-those that work hardest get least pay , it seems to [me]173-tregarva . But after all that expense , when [they]4320-those poor fellows ’ve built [the church]863-the church , it ’s [the tradesmen]4341-the tradesmen , and [the gentry]1349-the gentry , and [the old folk that fill [it]863-the church]4343-the old folk that fill it , and [the working men]4344-the working men never come near [it]863-the church from one year ’s end to another . ’[173-tregarva] ‘ What ’s the cause , do [you]172-lancelot think ? ’[172-lancelot] asked [Lancelot]172-lancelot , who had [himself]172-lancelot remarked the same thing more than once . ‘ Half of the reason , [sir]753-sir , [I]172-lancelot do believe , is that same Prayer - book . Not that the Prayer - book ai n’t a fine book enough , and a true one ; but , do n’t [you]753-sir see , [sir]753-sir , to understand the virtue of it , [the poor fellows]4347-the poor fellows ought to be already just what [you]753-sir want to make [them]4347-the poor fellows . ’[172-lancelot] ‘ [You]172-lancelot mean that [they]4347-the poor fellows ought to be [thorough Christians]4348-thorough christians already , to appreciate the spirituality of the liturgy . ’[173-tregarva] ‘ [You]172-lancelot ’ve hit it , [sir]753-sir . And see what comes of the present plan ; how [a navvy]4350-a navvy drops into [a church]3584-a church by accident , and there [he]4350-a navvy has to sit like a fish out of water , through that hour ’s service , staring or sleeping , before [he]4350-a navvy can hear a word that [he]4350-a navvy understands ; and , [sir]753-sir , when the sermon does come at last , it ’s not many of [them]4347-the poor fellows can make much out of those fine book - words and long sentences . Why do n’t [they]1844-they have a short simple service , now and then , that might catch the ears of [the roughs]4353-the roughs and [the blowens]4354-the blowens , without tiring out [the poor thoughtless creatures]4355-the poor thoughtless creatures ’[173-tregarva] patience , as [they]1844-they do now ? ’ ‘[173-tregarva] Because , ’ said [Lancelot,—‘because]315-lancelot,—‘because — [I]173-tregarva really do n’t know why.—But [I]173-tregarva think there is a simpler plan than even a ragged service . ’[173-tregarva] ‘ What , then , [sir]753-sir ? ’[173-tregarva] ‘ Field - preaching . If [the mountain]4357-the mountain wo n’t come to [Mahomet]284-mahomet , let [Mahomet]284-mahomet go to [the mountain]4357-the mountain . ’[173-tregarva] ‘ Right , [sir]753-sir ; right [you]753-sir are . “ Go out into [the highways and hedges]4360-the highways and hedges , and compel [them]1844-they to come in . ” And why are [they]1844-they to speak to [them]1844-they only one by one ? Why not by the dozen and the hundred ? [[We]4361-we [Wesleyans]3565-wesleyans]4362-we wesleyans know , sir,—for the matter of that , [every soldier]4364-every soldier knows,—what virtue there is in getting [a lot of [men]612-men]4365-a lot of men together ; how good and evil spread like wildfire through [a crowd]4367-a crowd ; and [one man]4368-one man , if [you]753-sir can stir [him]4368-one man up , will become leaven to leaven the whole lump . Oh why , [sir]753-sir , are [they]1844-they so afraid of field - preaching ? Was not [[their]1844-they Master]4370-their master and [mine]4371-mine [the prince of [all field - preachers]4373-all field - preachers]4372-the prince of all field - preachers ? Think , if [the Apostles]4374-the apostles had waited to collect subscriptions for [a church]3584-a church before [they]4374-the apostles spoke to [the poor heathens]4376-the poor heathens , where should [we]4377-we have been now ? ’[173-tregarva] [Lancelot]172-lancelot could not but agree . But at that moment [a footman]1845-a footman came up , and , with a face half laughing , half terrified , said , — ‘ [Tregarva]173-tregarva , [master]1667-master wants [you]173-tregarva in [the study]4379-the study . And please , [sir]753-sir , [I]1845-a footman think [you]173-tregarva had better go in too ; [master]1667-master knows [you]173-tregarva ’re[1845-a footman] [here]775-here , and [you]172-lancelot might speak a word for good , for [he]1847-he ’s raging like a mad bull . ’ ‘[1845-a footman] [I]0-i knew it would come at last , ’ said [Tregarva]173-tregarva , quietly , as [he]173-tregarva followed [Lancelot]172-lancelot into [the house]3485-the house . It had come at last . [The squire]3125-the squire was sitting in [[his]3125-the squire study]4384-his study , purple with rage , while [[his]3125-the squire daughters]4385-his daughters were trying vainly to pacify [him]3125-the squire . [All the men]4386-all the men - [servants]1467-servants , [grooms]3842-grooms , and [helpers]4389-helpers , were drawn up in line along the wall , and greeted [Tregarva]173-tregarva , whom [they]4386-all the men all heartily liked , with sly and sorrowful looks of warning , ‘[0-i] Here , [[you]172-lancelot sir]1848-you sir ; [you]172-lancelot — , look at this ! Is this the way [you]172-lancelot repay [me]0-i ? [I]0-i , who have kept [you]172-lancelot out of [the workhouse]933-the workhouse , treated [you]172-lancelot like [[my]0-i own child]1850-my own child ? And then to go and write filthy , rascally , Radical ballads on [me]0-i and [mine]0-i ! This comes of [your]172-lancelot Methodism , [you]172-lancelot canting , [sneaking hypocrite!—you viper]1851-sneaking hypocrite!—you viper — [you]172-lancelot adder — [you]172-lancelot snake — [you]172-lancelot — ! ’ And [the squire , whose vocabulary was not large , at a loss for another synonym]4390-the squire , whose vocabulary was not large , at a loss for another synonym , rounded off [his]4390-the squire , whose vocabulary was not large , at a loss for another synonym oration by a torrent of oaths ; at which [Argemone]150-argemone , taking [Honoria]162-honoria ’s hand , walked proudly out of [the room]3190-the room , with one glance at [Lancelot]172-lancelot of mingled shame and love . ‘[172-lancelot] This is [your]172-lancelot handwriting , [[you]172-lancelot villain]1852-you villain ! [you]172-lancelot know it ’ ( and [the squire]3125-the squire tossed the fatal paper across the table ) ; ‘[172-lancelot] though [I]0-i suppose [you]172-lancelot ’ll lie about it . How can [you]172-lancelot depend on [fellows who speak evil of [their]1853-fellows who speak evil of their betters betters]1853-fellows who speak evil of their betters ? But [all the servants]1854-all the servants are ready to swear it ’s [your]172-lancelot handwriting . ’ ‘[1854-all the servants] Beg [your]172-lancelot pardon , [sir]753-sir , ’ interposed [the old butler]4393-the old butler , ‘[172-lancelot] [we]1856-we did n’t quite say that ; but [we]1856-we ’ll all swear it is n’t [ours]1856-we . ’ ‘[1856-we] The paper is [mine]172-lancelot , ’ said [Tregarva]173-tregarva . ‘[172-lancelot] Confound [your]172-lancelot coolness ! [He]1857-he ’s no more ashamed of it than — Read it out , [Smith]172-lancelot , read it out every word ; and let [them]1854-all the servants all hear how [this pauper]1858-this pauper , [this ballad - singing vagabond , whom [I]0-i have bred up to insult [me]0-i , dares to abuse [[his]1859-this ballad - singing vagabond , whom i have bred up to insult me , dares to abuse his own master own master]1860-his own master]1859-this ballad - singing vagabond , whom i have bred up to insult me , dares to abuse his own master . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i have not abused [you]172-lancelot , [sir]753-sir , ’ answered [Tregarva]173-tregarva . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i will be heard , [sir]753-sir ! ’ [he]0-i went on in a voice which made [the old man]3135-the old man start from [his]3135-the old man seat and clench [his]3135-the old man fist but [he]3135-the old man sat down again . ‘[0-i] Not a word in it is meant for [you]753-sir . [You]753-sir have been [a kind and [a good master]1864-a good master to [me]0-i]1863-a kind and a good master to me . Ask where [you]753-sir will if [I]0-i was ever heard to say a word against [you]753-sir . [I]0-i would have cut off [my]0-i right hand sooner than write about [you]753-sir or [yours]753-sir . But what [I]0-i had to say about [others]3280-others lies there , and [I]0-i am not ashamed of it . ’ ‘[0-i] Not against [me]0-i ? Read it out , [Smith]172-lancelot , and see if every word of it do n’t hit at [me]0-i , and at [[my]0-i daughters]1866-my daughters , too , by — , worst of all ! Read it out , [I]0-i say ! ’ [Lancelot]172-lancelot hesitated ; but [the squire]3125-the squire , who was utterly beside [himself]3125-the squire , began to swear at [him]172-lancelot also , as [masters of hounds]4396-masters of hounds are privileged to do ; and [Lancelot]172-lancelot , to whom the whole scene was becoming every moment more and more intensely ludicrous , thought it best to take up the paper and begin : — ‘[0-i] A ROUGH RHYME ON A ROUGH MATTER . ‘ The merry brown hares came leaping Over [the crest of [the hill]570-the hill]4397-the crest of the hill , Where the clover and corn lay sleeping Under the moonlight still . ‘[0-i] Leaping late and early , Till under [their]1867-their bite and [their]1867-their tread The swedes , and the wheat , and the barley , Lay cankered , and trampled , and dead . ‘ [A poacher ’s widow]4399-a poacher ’s widow sat sighing On the side of [the white chalk bank]4400-the white chalk bank , Where under [the gloomy fir - woods One spot in [the ley throve rank]4402-the ley throve rank]4401-the gloomy fir - woods one spot in the ley throve rank . ‘[1868-she] [She]1868-she watched a long tuft of clover , Where rabbit or hare never ran ; For its black sour haulm covered over The blood of [a murdered man]1869-a murdered man . ‘ [She]1868-she thought of [the dark plantation]4403-the dark plantation , And the hares and [[her]1868-she husband]4183-her husband ’s blood , And the voice of [her]1868-she indignation Rose up to the throne of [God]281-god . ‘[0-i] “ [I]0-i am long past wailing and whining — [I]0-i have wept too much in [my]0-i life : [I]0-i ’ve had twenty years of pining As [[an English labourer]1870-an english labourer ’s wife]1871-an english labourer ’s wife . ‘ “ A labourer in Christian [England]3-england , Where [they]4405-they ca nt of [a Saviour]4131-a saviour ’s name , And yet waste [men]612-men ’s lives like [the vermin]4408-the vermin ’s For a few more brace of game . ‘[0-i] “ There ’s blood on [[your]1872-you new foreign shrubs]1873-your new foreign shrubs , [squire]588-squire ; There ’s blood on [your]1872-you pointer ’s feet ; There ’s blood on the game [you]1872-you sell , [squire]588-squire , And there ’s blood on the game [you]1872-you eat ! ” ’ ‘[1852-you villain] [[You]1872-you villain]1852-you villain ! ’ interposed [the squire]3125-the squire , ‘[1852-you villain] when did [I]0-i ever sell a head of game ? ’ ‘[1872-you] “ [You]1872-you have sold [the labouring man]3396-the labouring man , [squire]588-squire , Body and soul to shame , To pay for [your]1872-you seat in [the House]3485-the house , [squire]588-squire , And to pay for the feed of [your]1872-you game . “ ‘ [You]1872-you made [him]3396-the labouring man [a poacher]3968-a poacher [yourself]1872-you , [squire]588-squire , When [you]1872-you ’d give neither work nor meat ; And [[your]1872-you barley - fed hares]4412-your barley - fed hares robbed the garden At [[our]4413-our starving [children]935-children]4414-our starving children ’s feet ; ‘[1872-you] “ When packed in [one reeking chamber]1881-one reeking chamber , [Man]564-man , [maid]1883-maid , [mother]3233-mother , and [little ones]3732-little ones lay ; While the rain pattered in on the rotting bride - bed , And the walls let in the day ; ‘ “ When [we]1886-we lay in the burning fever On the mud of the cold clay floor , Till [you]1872-you parted [us]1886-we all for three months , [squire]588-squire , At [the cursed workhouse]4417-the cursed workhouse door . “ ‘[1886-we] [We]1886-we quarrelled like [brutes]1887-brutes , and who wonders ? What self - respect could [we]1886-we keep , Worse housed than [your]1888-your hacks and [your]1888-your pointers , Worse fed than [your]1888-your hogs and [your]1888-your sheep ? ” ’ ‘[1889-he] And yet [he]1889-he has the impudence to say [he]1889-he do n’t mean [me]0-i ! ’ grumbled [the old man]3135-the old man . [Tregarva]173-tregarva winced a good deal — as if [he]173-tregarva knew what was coming next ; and then looked up relieved when [he]173-tregarva found [Lancelot]172-lancelot had omitted a stanza — which [I]1889-he shall not omit . ‘[1889-he] “ [[Our]1886-we daughters]1890-our daughters with [base - born babies]1891-base - born babies Have wandered away in [their]1890-our daughters shame ; If [[your]1888-your misses]1892-your misses had slept , [squire]588-squire , where [they]1892-your misses did , [[Your]1888-your misses]1892-your misses might do the same . “ ‘ Can [[your]1888-your lady]4419-your lady patch hearts that are breaking With handfuls of coals and rice , Or by dealing out flannel and sheeting A little below cost price ? “ ‘[1892-your misses] [You]1888-your may tire of [the gaol]1895-the gaol and [the workhouse]933-the workhouse , And take to allotments and [schools]3392-schools , But [you]1888-your ’ve run up a debt that will never Be repaid [us]1886-we by penny - club rules . ‘ “ In the season of shame and sadness , In the dark and dreary day When scrofula , gout , and madness , Are eating [your]1888-your race away ; “ ‘[1888-your] When to [kennels and liveried varlets]1898-kennels and liveried varlets [You]1888-your have cast [[your]1888-your daughters]1899-your daughters ’ bread ; And worn out with liquor and harlots , [[Your]1888-your heir]4420-your heir at [your]1888-your feet lies dead ; “ ‘[1888-your] When [[your]1888-your youngest]1900-your youngest , [the mealy - mouthed rector]1901-the mealy - mouthed rector , Lets [your]1888-your soul rot asleep to the grave , [You]1888-your will find in [your]1888-your God the protector Of [the freeman [you]1888-your fancied [[your]1888-your slave]1903-your slave]1902-the freeman you fancied your slave . ” ‘ [She]1903-your slave looked at the tuft of clover , And wept till [her]1903-your slave heart grew light ; And at last , when [her]1903-your slave passion was over , Went wandering into the night . ‘[1904-the merry brown hares] But [the merry brown hares]1904-the merry brown hares came leaping Over [the uplands]1905-the uplands still , Where the clover and corn lay sleeping On [the side of [the white chalk hill]1907-the white chalk hill]1906-the side of the white chalk hill . ’ ‘[1904-the merry brown hares] Surely , [sir]753-sir , ’ said [Lancelot]172-lancelot , ‘[1904-the merry brown hares] [you]753-sir can not suppose that this latter part applies to [you]753-sir . or [[your]753-sir family]1909-your family ? ’ ‘[753-sir] If it do n’t , it applies to [half the gentlemen in [the vale]518-the vale]1910-half the gentlemen in the vale , and that ’s just as bad . What do n’t [he]1913-such an insolent dog deserve , [I]0-i say ? ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i think , ’ quoth [Lancelot]172-lancelot , ambiguously , ‘[0-i] that [a man who can write such ballads]1914-a man who can write such ballads is not fit to be [[your]753-sir gamekeeper]1915-your gamekeeper , and [I]0-i think [he]1914-a man who can write such ballads feels so [himself]1914-a man who can write such ballads ; ’ and [Lancelot]172-lancelot stole an encouraging look at [Tregarva]173-tregarva . ‘[1914-a man who can write such ballads] And [I]0-i say , [sir]753-sir , ’ [the keeper]3350-the keeper answered , with an effort , ‘[0-i] that [I]0-i leave [Mr. Lavington]276-mr. lavington ’s service here on the spot , once and for all . ’ ‘[0-i] And that [you]0-i may do , [[my]0-i fine fellow]824-my fine fellow ! ’ roared [the squire]3125-the squire . ‘[0-i] Pay [the rascal]1918-the rascal [his]1918-the rascal wages , [steward]1919-steward , and then duck [him]1918-the rascal soundly in the weir - pool . [He]1918-the rascal had better have stayed [there]992-there when [he]1918-the rascal fell in last . ’ ‘[1918-the rascal] So [I]0-i had , indeed , [I]0-i think . But [I]0-i ’ll take none of [your]753-sir money . The day [Harry Verney]174-old harry was buried [I]0-i vowed that [I]0-i ’d touch no more of the wages of blood . [I]0-i ’m going , [sir]753-sir ; [I]0-i never harmed [you]753-sir , or meant a hard word of all this for [you]753-sir , or dreamt that [you]753-sir or [any living soul]4424-any living soul would ever see it . But what [I]0-i ’ve seen [myself]0-i , in spite of [myself]0-i , [I]0-i ’ve set down here , and am not ashamed of it . And woe , ’[0-i] [he]0-i went on with an almost prophetic solemnity in [his]0-i tone and gesture—‘woe to [those who do these things]1921-those who do these things ! and woe to those also who , though [they]1921-those who do these things dare not do [them]1922-them [themselves]1921-those who do these things , yet excuse and defend [them]1921-those who do these things who dare , just because [the world]475-the world calls [them]1921-those who do these things [gentlemen]780-gentlemen , and not [tyrants]1925-tyrants and [oppressors]1926-oppressors . ’ [He]0-i turned to go . [The squire , bursting with passion]4425-the squire , bursting with passion , sprang up with a terrible oath , turned deadly pale , staggered , and dropped senseless on the floor . [They]4426-they all rushed to lift [him]4425-the squire , bursting with passion up . [Tregarva]173-tregarva was the first to take [him]4425-the squire , bursting with passion in [his]173-tregarva arms and place [him]4425-the squire , bursting with passion tenderly in [his]4425-the squire , bursting with passion chair , where [he]4425-the squire , bursting with passion lay back with glassy eyes , snoring heavily in a fit of apoplexy . ‘[281-god] Go ; for [God]281-god ’s sake , go , ’ whispered [Lancelot]172-lancelot to [the keeper]3350-the keeper , ‘[281-god] and wait for [me]0-i at [Lower Whitford]48-lower whitford . [I]0-i must see [you]1927-you before [you]1927-you stir . ’ [The keeper]3350-the keeper slipped away sadly . [The ladies]701-the ladies rushed in — [a groom]499-a groom galloped off for [the doctor]4115-the doctor — met [him]4425-the squire , bursting with passion luckily in [the village]3227-the village , and , in a few minutes , [the squire]3125-the squire was bled and put to bed , and showed hopeful signs of returning consciousness . And as [Argemone]150-argemone and [Lancelot]172-lancelot leant together over [his]172-lancelot pillow , [her]150-argemone hair touched [[her]150-argemone lover]3516-her lover ’s , and [her]150-argemone fragrant breath was warm upon [his]172-lancelot cheek ; and [her]150-argemone bright eyes met [his]172-lancelot and drank light from [them]4435-them , like glittering planets gazing at [their]4435-them sun . The obnoxious ballad produced the most opposite effects on [Argemone]150-argemone and on [Honoria]162-honoria . [Argemone , whose reverence for the formalities and the respectabilities of society]4436-argemone , whose reverence for the formalities and the respectabilities of society , never very great , had , of late , utterly vanished before [Lancelot]172-lancelot ’s bad counsel , could think of it only as a work of art , and conceived the most romantic longing to raise [Tregarva]173-tregarva into [some station where [his]173-tregarva talents might have free play]4437-some station where his talents might have free play . To [Honoria]162-honoria , on the other hand , it appeared only as a very fierce , coarse , and impertinent satire , which had nearly killed [[her]162-honoria father]3219-her father . True , there was not a thought in it which had not at some time or other crossed [her]162-honoria own mind ; but that made [her]162-honoria dislike all the more to see those thoughts put into plain English . That very intense tenderness and excitability which made [her]162-honoria toil [herself]162-honoria among [the poor]698-the poor , and had called out both [her]162-honoria admiration of [Tregarva]173-tregarva and [her]162-honoria extravagant passion at [his]173-tregarva danger , made [her]162-honoria also shrink with disgust from anything which thrust on [her]162-honoria a painful reality , which [she]162-honoria could not remedy . [She]162-honoria was [a staunch believer]4440-a staunch believer , too , in that peculiar creed which allows [every one]807-every one to feel for [the poor]698-the poor , except [themselves]698-the poor , and considers that to plead the cause of [working - men]4443-working - men is , in [a gentleman]3733-a gentleman , the perfection of virtue , but in [a working - man]4445-a working - man [himself]4445-a working - man , sheer high treason . And so beside [[[her]162-honoria father]3219-her father ’s sick - bed]4447-her father ’s sick - bed [she]162-honoria thought of [the keeper]3350-the keeper only as [a scorpion whom [she]162-honoria had helped to warm into life ; and sighing assent to [[her]162-honoria mother]1404-her mother]4449-a scorpion whom she had helped to warm into life ; and sighing assent to her mother , when [she]162-honoria said , ‘[3964-that wretch] [That wretch]3964-that wretch , and [he]3964-that wretch seemed so pious and so obliging ! who would have dreamt that [he]3964-that wretch was such [a horrid Radical]1929-a horrid radical ? ’ [she]162-honoria let [him]3964-that wretch vanish from [her]162-honoria mind and out of [Whitford Priors]144-whitford priors , little knowing the sore weight of manly love [he]3964-that wretch bore with [him]3964-that wretch . As soon as [Lancelot]172-lancelot could leave [the Priory]64-the priory , [he]172-lancelot hastened [home]452-home to find [Tregarva]173-tregarva . [The keeper]3350-the keeper had packed up all [his]3350-the keeper small possessions and brought them down to [Lower Whitford]48-lower whitford , through which [the [London]46-london coach passed]4453-the london coach passed . [He]3350-the keeper was determined to go to [London]46-london and seek [his]3350-the keeper fortune . [He]3350-the keeper talked of turning coal - heaver , [Methodist preacher]4454-methodist preacher , anything that came to hand , provided that [he]3350-the keeper could but keep independence and a clear conscience . And all the while [the man]738-the man seemed to be struggling with some great purpose,—to feel that [he]738-the man had a work to do , though what it was , and how it was to be done , [he]738-the man did not see . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i am [a tall man]1930-a tall man , ’ [he]0-i said , ‘[1930-a tall man] like [Saul]316-saul [the son of [Kish]317-kish]1931-the son of kish ; and [I]0-i am going forth , like [him]316-saul , [sir]753-sir , to find [[my]0-i father]3846-my father ’s asses . [I]0-i doubt [I]0-i sha n’t have to look far for some of them . ’ ‘[0-i] And perhaps , ’ said [Lancelot]172-lancelot , laughing , ‘[0-i] to find [a kingdom]1934-a kingdom . ’ ‘[0-i] May be so , [sir]753-sir . [I]0-i have found one already , by [God]281-god ’s grace , and [I]0-i ’m much mistaken if [I]281-god do n’t begin to see [my]281-god way towards another . ’[281-god] ‘ And what is that ? ’[0-i] ‘ [The kingdom of God on [earth]724-earth]4456-the kingdom of god on earth , [sir]753-sir , as well as in [heaven]1101-heaven . Come it must , [sir]753-sir , and come it will some day . ’[172-lancelot] [Lancelot]172-lancelot shook [his]172-lancelot head . [Tregarva]173-tregarva lifted up [his]173-tregarva eyes and said , — ‘ Are [we]4461-we not taught to pray for the coming of [[His]173-tregarva kingdom]4462-his kingdom , [sir]753-sir ? And do [you]753-sir fancy that [He]173-tregarva who gave the lesson would have set [all mankind]4464-all mankind to pray for what [He]173-tregarva never meant should come to pass ? ’[173-tregarva] [Lancelot]172-lancelot was silent . The words gained a new and blessed meaning in [his]172-lancelot eyes . ‘ Well , ’[172-lancelot] [he]172-lancelot said , ‘ the time , at least , of [their]4465-their fulfilment is far enough off . [Union - workhouses]4466-union - workhouses and [child - murder]4467-child - murder do n’t look much like it . Talking of that , [Tregarva]173-tregarva , what is to become of [your]173-tregarva promise to take [me]172-lancelot to [a village]4468-a village wake , and show [me]172-lancelot what [the poor]698-the poor are like ? ’[172-lancelot] ‘ [I]0-i can keep it this night , [sir]753-sir . There is a revel at Bone - sake , about five miles up [the river]505-the river . Will [you]753-sir go with [a discharged gamekeeper]4472-a discharged gamekeeper ? ’[0-i] ‘ [I]0-i will go with [Paul Tregarva]173-tregarva , whom [I]0-i honour and esteem as [one of [[God]281-god ’s own noblemen]4474-god ’s own noblemen]4473-one of god ’s own noblemen ; who has taught [me]0-i what [a man]445-a man can be , and what [I]0-i am not,’—and [Lancelot]172-lancelot grasped [the keeper]3350-the keeper ’s hand warmly . [Tregarva]173-tregarva brushed [his]173-tregarva hand across [his]173-tregarva eyes , and answered , — ‘[0-i] “ [I]0-i said in [my]0-i haste , [All men]3715-all men are [liars]3951-liars ; ” and [God]281-god has just given [me]0-i the lie back in [my]0-i own teeth . Well , [sir]753-sir , [we]1939-we will go to - night . [You]753-sir are not ashamed of putting on a smock - frock ? For if [you]753-sir go as [a gentleman]3733-a gentleman , [you]753-sir will hear no more of them than a hawk does of a covey of partridges . ’ So the expedition was agreed on , and [Lancelot]172-lancelot and [the keeper]3350-the keeper parted until the evening . But why had [the vicar]3366-the vicar been rambling on all that morning through pouring rain , on the top of [the [London]46-london coach]4479-the london coach ? And why was [he]3366-the vicar so anxious in [his]3366-the vicar inquiries as to the certainty of catching [the up - train]4480-the up - train ? Because [he]3366-the vicar had had considerable experience in that wisdom of the serpent , whose combination with the innocence of the dove , in somewhat ultramontane proportions , is recommended by [certain late leaders of [[his]3366-the vicar school]4482-his school]4481-certain late leaders of his school . [He]3366-the vicar had made up [his]3366-the vicar mind , after [his]3366-the vicar conversation with [the Irishman]4286-the irishman , that [he]3366-the vicar must either oust [Lancelot]172-lancelot at once , or submit to be ousted by [him]172-lancelot , and [he]3366-the vicar was now on [his]3366-the vicar way to [[Lancelot]172-lancelot ’s uncle]1278-lancelot ’s uncle and [trustee]4485-trustee , [the London banker]4486-the london banker . [He]3366-the vicar knew that [the banker]1279-the banker had some influence with [[his]1279-the banker nephew]4488-his nephew , whose whole property was invested in [the bank]3419-the bank , and who had besides a deep respect for the kindly and upright practical mind of [the veteran Mammonite]4490-the veteran mammonite . And [the vicar]3366-the vicar knew , too , that [he]3366-the vicar [himself]3366-the vicar had some influence with [the banker]1279-the banker , whose son [Luke]137-mr. smith had been [[his]3366-the vicar pupil at college]4493-his pupil at college . And when [the young man]749-the young man lay sick of a dangerous illness , brought on by debauchery , into which weakness rather than vice had tempted [him]749-the young man , [the vicar]3366-the vicar had watched and prayed by [his]749-the young man bed , nursed [him]749-the young man as tenderly as [a mother]1052-a mother , and so won over [his]749-the young man better heart that [he]749-the young man became completely reclaimed , and took holy orders with the most earnest intention to play [the man therein]4497-the man therein , as [repentant rakes]4498-repentant rakes will often do , half from a mere revulsion to asceticism , half from real gratitude for [their]4498-repentant rakes deliverance . This good deed had placed [the banker]1279-the banker in [the vicar]3366-the vicar ’s debt , and [he]1279-the banker loved and reverenced [him]1279-the banker in spite of [his]1279-the banker dread of ‘[215-heaven] Popish novelties . ’ And now [the good priest]4501-the good priest was going to open to [him]749-the young man just as much of [his]749-the young man heart as should seem fit ; and by saying a great deal about [Lancelot]172-lancelot ’s evil doings , opinions , and [companions]4502-companions , and nothing at all about [the heiress of [Whitford]144-whitford priors]3677-the heiress of whitford , persuade [the banker]1279-the banker to use all [his]1279-the banker influence in drawing [Lancelot]172-lancelot up to [London]46-london , and leaving a clear stage for [his]1279-the banker plans on [Argemone]150-argemone . [He]1279-the banker caught [the up - train]4480-the up - train , [he]1279-the banker arrived safe and sound in [town]485-town , but what [he]1279-the banker did there must be told in another chapter . Weary with many thoughts , [the vicar]3366-the vicar came to the door of [the bank]3419-the bank . There were [several carriages]4509-several carriages [there]992-there , and [a crowd of people]4511-a crowd of people swarming in and out , like bees round a hive - door , entering with anxious faces , and returning with [cheerful ones]4512-cheerful ones , to stop and talk earnestly in groups round the door . Every moment the mass thickened — there was a run on [the bank]3419-the bank . [An old friend]4514-an old friend accosted [him]1941-you on the steps , — ‘[215-heaven] What ! have [you]1941-you , too , money here , then ? ’ ‘[1941-you] Neither here nor anywhere else , thank [Heaven]215-heaven ! ’ said [the vicar]3366-the vicar . ‘[1941-you] But is anything wrong ? ’ ‘[1941-you] Have not [you]1941-you heard ? [The house]3485-the house has sustained a frightful blow this week — railway speculations , so [they]1943-they say — and is hardly expected to survive the day . So [we]1944-we are all getting [our]1944-we money out as fast as possible . ’ ‘[1944-we] By way of binding up the bruised reed , eh ? ’ ‘[1944-we] Oh ! [every man for [himself]1945-every man for himself]1945-every man for himself . [A man]445-a man is under no obligation to [[his]445-a man banker]1947-his banker , that [I]0-i know of . ’ And [the good man]4516-the good man bustled off with [his]4516-the good man pockets full of gold . [The vicar]3366-the vicar entered . All was hurry and anxiety . [The clerks]4518-the clerks seemed trying to brazen out [their]4518-the clerks own terror , and shovelled the rapidly lessening gold and notes across the counter with an air of indignant nonchalance . [The vicar]3366-the vicar asked to see [the principal]4520-the principal . ‘[0-i] If [you]1941-you want [your]1941-you money , [sir]753-sir — ’ answered [the official]4521-the official , with a disdainful look . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i want no money . [I]0-i must see [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith on private business , and instantly . ’ ‘[137-mr. smith] [He]137-mr. smith is particularly engaged . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i know it , and , therefore , [I]0-i must see [him]137-mr. smith . Take in [my]0-i card , and [he]137-mr. smith will not refuse [me]0-i . ’ A new vista had opened itself before [him]753-sir . [He]753-sir was ushered into [a private room]4522-a private room : and , as [he]753-sir waited for [the banker]1279-the banker , [he]753-sir breathed a prayer . For what ? That [his]753-sir own will might be done — a very common style of petition . [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith entered , hurried and troubled . [He]753-sir caught [the vicar]3366-the vicar eagerly by the hand , as if glad to see a face which did not glare on [him]753-sir with the cold selfish stamp of ‘[137-mr. smith] business , ’ and then drew back again , afraid to commit [himself]753-sir by any sign of emotion . [The vicar]3366-the vicar had settled [his]3366-the vicar plan of attack , and determined boldly to show [his]3366-the vicar knowledge of [the banker]1279-the banker ’s distress . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i am very sorry to trouble [you]1949-your at such an unfortunate moment , [sir]753-sir , and [I]0-i will be brief ; but , as [[your]1949-your nephew]1951-your nephew ’s spiritual pastor — ’ ( [He]753-sir knew [the banker]1279-the banker was [a stout Churchman]4528-a stout churchman . ) ‘[0-i] What of [[my]0-i nephew]1952-my nephew , [sir]753-sir ! Some mésalliance ? ’ interrupted [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith , in a peevish , excited tone . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i thought there was some heiress on the tapis — at least , so [I]0-i heard from [[my]0-i unfortunate son]1955-my unfortunate son , who has just gone over to [Rome]21-rome . There ’s another misfortune.—Nothing but misfortunes ; and [your]1949-your teaching , [sir]753-sir , by the bye , [I]0-i am afraid , has helped [me]0-i to that one . ’ ‘[1949-your] Gone over to [Rome]21-rome ? ’ asked [the vicar]3366-the vicar , slowly . ‘[753-sir] Yes , [sir]753-sir , gone to [Rome]21-rome — to [the pope]1304-the pope , [sir]753-sir ! to the devil , [sir]753-sir ! [I]0-i should have thought [you]753-sir likely to know of it before [I]0-i did ! ’ [The vicar]3366-the vicar stared fixedly at [him]753-sir a moment , and burst into honest tears . [The banker]1279-the banker was moved . ‘[753-sir] ’ Pon [my]753-sir honour , [sir]753-sir , [I]753-sir beg [your]753-sir pardon . [I]753-sir did not mean to be rude , but — but — To be plain with [a clergyman]4533-a clergyman , [sir]753-sir , so many things coming together have quite unmanned [me]753-sir . Pooh , pooh , ’[753-sir] and [he]753-sir shook [himself]753-sir as if to throw off a weight ; and , with a face once more quiet and business - like , asked , ‘ And now , [[my]753-sir dear sir]4535-my dear sir , what of [[my]753-sir nephew]1952-my nephew ? ’[753-sir] ‘ As for [that young lady]4537-that young lady , [sir]753-sir , of whom [you]753-sir spoke , [I]753-sir can assure [you]753-sir , once for all , as [[her]4537-that young lady clergyman]4539-her clergyman , and therefore more or less [[her]4537-that young lady confidant]4540-her confidant , that [[your]753-sir nephew]1951-your nephew has not the slightest chance or hope in that quarter . ’[753-sir] ‘ How , [sir]753-sir ? [You]753-sir will not throw obstacles in the way ? ’[753-sir] ‘ [Heaven]215-heaven , [sir]753-sir , [I]753-sir think , has interposed far more insuperable obstacles — in [the young lady]4544-the young lady ’s own heart — than [I]753-sir could ever have done . [[Your]753-sir nephew]1951-your nephew ’s character and opinions , [I]753-sir am sorry to say , are not such as are likely to command the respect and affection of [a pure and pious Churchwoman]4546-a pure and pious churchwoman . ’[753-sir] ‘ Opinions , [sir]753-sir ? What , is [he]1951-your nephew turning [Papist]3840-papist , too ? ’[753-sir] ‘ [I]753-sir am afraid , [sir]753-sir , and more than afraid , for [he]1951-your nephew makes no secret of it [himself]1951-your nephew , that [his]1951-your nephew views tend rather in the opposite direction ; to an infidelity so subversive of the commonest principles of morality , that [I]753-sir expect , weekly , to hear of some unblushing and disgraceful outrage against decency , committed by [him]1951-your nephew under its fancied sanction . And [you]753-sir know , as well as [myself]753-sir , the double danger of some profligate outbreak , which always attends the miseries of a disappointed earthly passion . ’[753-sir] ‘ True , very true . [We]4550-we must get [the boy]1359-the boy out of the way , [sir]753-sir . [I]753-sir must have [him]1359-the boy under [my]753-sir eye . ’[753-sir] ‘ Exactly so , [sir]753-sir , ’[1961-the subtle vicar , who had been driving at this very point] said [the subtle vicar , who had been driving at this very point]1961-the subtle vicar , who had been driving at this very point . ‘ How much better for [him]1359-the boy to be [here]775-here , using [his]1359-the boy great talents to the advantage of [[his]1359-the boy family]4555-his family in an honourable profession , than to remain where [he]1359-the boy is , debauching body and mind by hopeless dreams , godless studies , and frivolous excesses . ’[1961-the subtle vicar , who had been driving at this very point] ‘ When do [you]753-sir return , [sir]753-sir ? ’[753-sir] ‘ An hour hence , if [I]1279-the banker can be of service to [you]753-sir . ’[1279-the banker] [The banker]1279-the banker paused a moment . ‘ [You]753-sir are [a gentleman]3733-a gentleman ’[1279-the banker] ( with emphasis on the word ) , ‘ and as such [I]1279-the banker can trust [you]753-sir . ’[1279-the banker] ‘ Say , rather , as [a clergyman]4533-a clergyman . ’[753-sir] ‘ Pardon [me]753-sir , but [I]753-sir have found [your]753-sir cloth give little additional cause for confidence . [I]753-sir have been as much bitten by [clergymen]784-clergymen — [I]753-sir have seen as sharp practice among [them]784-clergymen , in money matters as well as in religious squabbles , as [I]753-sir have in any class . The slipperiness , [sir]753-sir , of [one staggering parson]4564-one staggering parson , has set rolling this very avalanche , which gathers size every moment , and threatens to overwhelm [me]3366-the vicar now , unless [that idle dog Lancelot]4565-that idle dog lancelot will condescend to bestir [himself]4565-that idle dog lancelot , and help [me]3366-the vicar . ’[3366-the vicar] [The vicar]3366-the vicar heard , but said nothing . ‘ [Me]3366-the vicar , at least , [you]753-sir can trust , ’[3366-the vicar] [he]3366-the vicar answered proudly ; and honestly , too — for [he]3366-the vicar was [a gentleman]3733-a gentleman by birth and breeding , unselfish and chivalrous to a fault — and yet , when [he]3366-the vicar heard [the banker]1279-the banker ’s words , it was as if the inner voice had whispered to [him]3366-the vicar , ‘ [Thou]3366-the vicar art [the man]738-the man ! ’[1279-the banker] ‘ When do [you]137-mr. smith go down ? ’[137-mr. smith] again asked [Mr. Smith]137-mr. smith . ‘ To tell [you]137-mr. smith the truth , [I]3366-the vicar was writing to [Lancelot]172-lancelot when [you]137-mr. smith were announced ! but the post will not reach [him]172-lancelot till to - morrow at noon , and [we]4567-we are all so busy here , that [I]3366-the vicar have [no one whom [I]3366-the vicar can trust to carry down [an express]4569-an express]4568-no one whom i can trust to carry down an express . ’[3366-the vicar] [The vicar]3366-the vicar saw what was coming . [A cab]1970-a cab was called , and [the clergyman]781-the clergyman rattled off to [the railway terminus]1972-the railway terminus . ‘ Well , ’[781-the clergyman] said [he]781-the clergyman to [himself]781-the clergyman , ‘ [God]281-god has indeed blessed [my]781-the clergyman errand ; giving , as always , “ exceeding abundantly more than [we]4575-we are able to ask or think ! ” For some weeks , at least , [this poor lamb]4576-this poor lamb is safe from [the destroyer]4577-the destroyer ’s clutches . [I]781-the clergyman must improve to the utmost those few precious days in strengthening [her]4576-this poor lamb in [her]4576-this poor lamb holy purpose . But , after all , [he]781-the clergyman will return , daring and cunning as ever ; and then will not the fascination recommence ? ’[781-the clergyman] And , as [he]781-the clergyman mused , [a little fiend]1973-a little fiend passed by , and whispered , ‘ Unless [he]781-the clergyman comes up to - night , [he]781-the clergyman is [a ruined man]4574-a ruined man . ’[1973-a little fiend] It was Friday , and [the vicar]3366-the vicar had thought it a fit preparation for so important an errand to taste no food that day . Weakness and hunger , joined to the roar and bustle of [London]46-london , had made [him]781-the clergyman excited , nervous , unable to control [his]781-the clergyman thoughts , or fight against a stupifying headache ; and [his]781-the clergyman self - weakened will punished [him]781-the clergyman , by yielding [him]781-the clergyman up an easy prey to [his]781-the clergyman own fancies . ‘ Ay , ’[781-the clergyman] [he]781-the clergyman thought , ‘ if [he]781-the clergyman were ruined , after all , it would be well for [God]281-god ’s cause . [The Lavingtons]248-the lavingtons , at least , would find no temptation in [his]781-the clergyman wealth : and [Argemone]150-argemone — [she]150-argemone is too proud , too luxurious , to marry [a beggar]4579-a beggar . [She]150-argemone might embrace a holy poverty for the sake of [her]150-argemone own soul ; but for the gratification of an earthly passion , never ! Base and carnal delights would never tempt [her]150-argemone so far . ’[781-the clergyman] Alas , [poor pedant]1975-poor pedant ! Among all that [thy]1976-thee books taught [thee]1976-thee , they did not open to [thee]1976-thee much of the depths of that human heart which [thy]1976-thee dogmas taught [thee]1976-thee to despise as diabolic . Again [the little fiend]1977-the little fiend whispered , — ‘ Unless [he]781-the clergyman comes up to - night , [he]781-the clergyman is [a ruined man]4574-a ruined man . ’[1977-the little fiend] ‘ And what if [he]781-the clergyman is ? ’[3366-the vicar] thought [the vicar]3366-the vicar . ‘ Riches are a curse ; and poverty a blessing . Is it not [his]781-the clergyman wealth which is ruining [his]781-the clergyman soul ? But [the vicar]3366-the vicar was yet honest . Again [the little fiend]1977-the little fiend whispered , — ‘ Unless [he]781-the clergyman comes up to - night [he]781-the clergyman is [a ruined man]4574-a ruined man . ’[1977-the little fiend] A terrible sensation seized him.—Why should [he]1977-the little fiend give the letter to - night ? ‘ [You]1977-the little fiend promised , ’[1985-the inner voice] whispered [the inner voice]1985-the inner voice . ‘ No , [I]1985-the inner voice did not promise exactly , in so many words ; that is , [I]1985-the inner voice only said [I]1985-the inner voice would be at [home]452-home to - night , if [God]281-god pleased . And what if [God]281-god should not please?—I promised for [his]781-the clergyman good . What if , on second thoughts , it should be better for [him]781-the clergyman not to keep [my]1985-the inner voice promise ? ’[1985-the inner voice] A moment afterwards , [he]1977-the little fiend tossed the temptation from [him]1977-the little fiend indignantly : but back it came . At every [gaudy shop]1986-gaudy shop , at [every smoke - grimed manufactory]1987-every smoke - grimed manufactory , at the face of [every anxious victim of [Mammon]186-mammon]1988-every anxious victim of mammon , of [every sturdy , cheerful artisan]1989-every sturdy , cheerful artisan , [the fiend]1990-the fiend winked and pointed , crying , ‘ And what if [he]781-the clergyman be ruined ?
